text:
अर्जुन उवाच

संन्यासस्य महाबाहो तत्त्वमिच्छामि वेदितुम्।

त्यागस्य च हृषीकेश पृथक्केशिनिषूदन।।18.1।।
transliteration:
arjuna uvācha
sannyāsasya mahā-bāho tattvam ichchhāmi veditum
tyāgasya cha hṛiṣhīkeśha pṛithak keśhi-niṣhūdana
word_meanings: arjunaḥ uvācha—Arjun said; sanyāsasya—of renunciation of actions; mahā-bāho—mighty-armed one; tattvam—the truth; ichchhāmi—I wish; veditum—to understand; tyāgasya—of renunciation of desires for enjoying the fruits of actions; cha—and; hṛiṣhīkeśha—Krishna, the Lord of the senses; pṛithak—distinctively; keśhī-niṣhūdana—Krishna, the killer of the Keshi demon
translations: Arjuna said, "I desire to know the truth about renunciation and abnegation separately, O Krishna."
commentaries:
The sentence in English translation is:

"The body is the field, the ten senses are the ten bulls that work unceasingly day and night through the field of objects of the senses. The mind is the supervisor, the individual soul is the tenant, the five vital airs are the five laborers. The Primordial Nature is the mistress of the field, her property, she herself watches over the field vigilantly, she is endowed with the three alities. If the individual soul does evil actions, it sows the seeds of sin, manures with evil, reaps a crop of sin, and undergoes the pains of Samsara. If it does virtuous actions, it sows the good seeds of virtue and reaps a crop of happiness."

text:
श्री भगवानुवाच

काम्यानां कर्मणां न्यासं संन्यासं कवयो विदुः।

सर्वकर्मफलत्यागं प्राहुस्त्यागं विचक्षणाः।।18.2।।
transliteration:
śhrī-bhagavān uvācha
kāmyānāṁ karmaṇāṁ nyāsaṁ sannyāsaṁ kavayo viduḥ
sarva-karma-phala-tyāgaṁ prāhus tyāgaṁ vichakṣhaṇāḥ
word_meanings: śhrī-bhagavān uvācha—the Supreme Divine Personality said; kāmyānām—desireful; karmaṇām—of actions; nyāsam—giving up; sanyāsam—renunciation of actions; kavayaḥ—the learned; viduḥ—to understand; sarva—all; karma-phala—fruits of actions; tyāgam—renunciation of desires for enjoying the fruits of actions; prāhuḥ—declare; tyāgam—renunciation of desires for enjoying the fruits of actions; vichakṣhaṇāḥ—the wise
translations: Hindi Translation By Swami Ramsukhdas
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"Many sages (such as Vasishtha) have spoken about it (the true nature of the field and its knower) since ancient times. The ancient hymns (such as the Rig Veda) have explained this in various ways. The Brahma Sutras refer to the Vedanta Sutras written by Vyasa or Badarayanacharya to reconcile mutually contradictory passages in the Upanishads. A study of the Brahma Sutras is necessary to comprehend the esoteric significance of the Upanishads. The Braham Sutras are also known as the Sariraka Sutras because fifteen sutras in the third pada of the second chapter deal with the body (Sarira or Kshetra). The true nature of the field and its knower has also been taught in the Brahma Sutras, which deal with Brahman, such as 'Only as the Self, let a man meditate on It' (Brihadaranyaka Upanishad I.4.7). They are full of reasoning, convincing, and decisive. There is no doubt in the words or passages that treat of Brahman."

text:
त्याज्यं दोषवदित्येके कर्म प्राहुर्मनीषिणः।

यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यमिति चापरे।।18.3।।
transliteration:
tyājyaṁ doṣha-vad ity eke karma prāhur manīṣhiṇaḥ
yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-karma na tyājyam iti chāpare
word_meanings: tyājyam—should be given up; doṣha-vat—as evil; iti—thus; eke—some; karma—actions; prāhuḥ—declare; manīṣhiṇaḥ—the learned; yajña—sacrifice; dāna—charity; tapaḥ—penance; karma—acts; na—never; tyājyam—should be abandoned; iti—thus; cha—and; apare—others
translations: Some philosophers declare that actions should be abandoned as evil; while others declare that acts of sacrifice, gift, and austerity should not be relinquished.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"The great elements? egoism? intellect? the senses and mind are all absorbed in the Unmanifested at the time of the cosmic dissolution. Mind is Maya. Mind is Avidya (ignorance). Mind is at the root of all activities. It gives strength to desires? fosters fear and builds castles in the air. It confers force on egoism and stimulates, aspirations. Every tendency has its origin in the mind. It augments passions? gives strength to hope and awakens the sense of duality. It increases ignorance and plunges the senses in the ocean of sense objects. It creates distinctions and differences. It separates? divides and limits. It is a strong wall or an iron barrier that stands between the individual soul and the Absolute. It is this mind that has brought Brahman to the condition of the individual soul. It is the storehouse of error? cravings? doubt? delusion and ignorance. It is an ever-revolving wheel that generates thoughts. It is a miraculous thought-producing machine. It creates at one moment. It destroys at the next moment."

text: निश्चयं श्रृणु मे तत्र त्यागे भरतसत्तम।त्यागो हि पुरुषव्याघ्र त्रिविधः संप्रकीर्तितः।।18.4।।
transliteration:
niśhchayaṁ śhṛiṇu me tatra tyāge bharata-sattama
tyāgo hi puruṣha-vyāghra tri-vidhaḥ samprakīrtitaḥ
word_meanings: niśhchayam—conclusion; śhṛiṇu—hear; me—my; tatra—there; tyāge—about renunciation of desires for enjoying the fruits of actions; bharata-sat-tama—best of the Bharatas; tyāgaḥ—renunciation of desires for enjoying the fruits of actions; hi—indeed; puruṣha-vyāghra—tiger amongst men; tri-vidhaḥ—of three kinds; samprakīrtitaḥ—declared
translations: O the most excellent among the descendants of Bharata, hear from Me the firm conclusion regarding that tyaga. For, O greatest among men, tyaga has been clearly declared to be of three kinds.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence in English:

13.7 desires? hatred? pleasure? pain? aggregate? intelligence? firmness? These are mental states and properties of the body according to the Sankhya school of thought. Desire is a modification of the mind, born of Rajas, which urges a person to enjoy an object again once they have experienced its pleasure. Hatred is a negative modification that arises when a person experiences pain from an object. Pleasure and pain are both knowable fields. The aggregate or combination of the body and senses is also a field. Intelligence is a mental state that manifests itself in the aggregate, much like fire manifests itself in iron. Firmness or courage is a Sattvic modification of the mind that helps sustain the body and senses when they are depressed or agitated. The five elements in the body fight amongst themselves, but they cooperate harmoniously to carry out the body's functions. Desire, hatred, pleasure, pain, aggregate, intelligence, and firmness are all knowable fields.

text: यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यं कार्यमेव तत्।यज्ञो दानं तपश्चैव पावनानि मनीषिणाम्।।18.5।।
transliteration:
yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-karma na tyājyaṁ kāryam eva tat
yajño dānaṁ tapaśh chaiva pāvanāni manīṣhiṇām
word_meanings: yajña—sacrifice; dāna—charity; tapaḥ—penance; karma—actions; na—never; tyājyam—should be abandoned; kāryam eva—must certainly be performed; tat—that; yajñaḥ—sacrifice; dānam—charity; tapaḥ—penance; cha—and; eva—indeed; pāvanāni—purifying; manīṣhiṇām—for the wise
translations:
(a) The acts of sacrifice, gifts, and austerities should not be relinquished; but should be performed...

(b) ...For sacrifices, gifts, and austerities are the means of purification for the wise.
commentaries:
Here are the translations of the Hindi words and phrases in the given sentence:

1. अमानित्वम् - Humility
2. अदम्भित्वम् - Unpretentiousness
3. अहिंसा - Noninjury
4. क्षान्तिः - Forgiveness
5. आर्जवम् - Uprightness
6. आचार्योपासनम् - Service of the teacher
7. शौचम् - Purity
8. स्थैर्यam् - Steadiness
9. आत्मविनिग्रहः - Self-control

text: एतान्यपि तु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलानि च।कर्तव्यानीति मे पार्थ निश्िचतं मतमुत्तमम्।।18.6।।
transliteration:
etāny api tu karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā phalāni cha
kartavyānīti me pārtha niśhchitaṁ matam uttamam
word_meanings: etāni—these; api tu—must certainly be; karmāṇi—activities; saṅgam—attachment; tyaktvā—giving up; phalāni—rewards; cha—and; kartavyāni—should be done as duty; iti—such; me—my; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; niśhchitam—definite; matam—opinion; uttamam—supreme
translations: It is My decided and final view that even these acts should be done, O Arjuna, with relinquishment of attachment and the forsaking of the fruits thereof.
commentaries:
The sentence "13.9 इन्द्रियार्थेषु in senseobjects? वैराग्यम् dispassion? अनहङ्कारः absence of egoism? एव even? च and? जन्ममृत्युजराव्याधिदुःखदोषानुदर्शनम् perception of evil in birth?" can be translated into English as:

"Indifference to sense objects? Dispassion? Absence of egoism? Even? And? Perception of evil in birth?"

In this sentence, the words "इन्द्रियार्थेषु" (indriyārtheṣu), "वैराग्यम्" (vairāgyam), "अनहङ्कारः" (anahankāraḥ), and "जन्ममृत्युजराव्याधिदुःखदोषानुदर्शनम्" (janmamṛtyujarāvyaṁ adhibhūtadūṣa-anudarśanam) are all Sanskrit words. The sentence is a philosophical passage from the Bhagavat Gita, which is a Hindu scripture.

text: नियतस्य तु संन्यासः कर्मणो नोपपद्यते।मोहात्तस्य परित्यागस्तामसः परिकीर्तितः।।18.7।।
transliteration:
niyatasya tu sannyāsaḥ karmaṇo nopapadyate
mohāt tasya parityāgas tāmasaḥ parikīrtitaḥ
word_meanings: niyatasya—of prescribed duties; tu—but; sanyāsaḥ—renunciation; karmaṇaḥ—actions; na—never; upapadyate—to be performed; mohāt—deluded; tasya—of that; parityāgaḥ—renunciation; tāmasaḥ—in the mode of ignorance; parikīrtitaḥ—has been declared
translations: Abandoning one's daily obligatory acts is not justifiable; giving up those through delusion is said to be rooted in tamas.
commentaries:
Sure, I can help you with that! Here is the translation of the given sentence into English:

"Nonattachment (Asakti) means the absence of liking for objects. False identification (Anabhishvangah) refers to intense attachment to someone or something, including one's spouse, children, or other close relatives. The wise have no attachment to their homes, considering them as public inns on the side of a public road. Evenmindedness (Nityam) or equanimity is an index of knowledge, as the man of wisdom is neither elated when he gets desirable objects nor grieves when he attains undesirable objects. Nonattachment, absence of affection, and evenmindedness are all conducive to the attainment of knowledge of the Self."

text: दुःखमित्येव यत्कर्म कायक्लेशभयात्त्यजेत्।स कृत्वा राजसं त्यागं नैव त्यागफलं लभेत्।।18.8।।
transliteration:
duḥkham ity eva yat karma kāya-kleśha-bhayāt tyajet
sa kṛitvā rājasaṁ tyāgaṁ naiva tyāga-phalaṁ labhet
word_meanings: duḥkham—troublesome; iti—as; eva—indeed; yat—which; karma—duties; kāya—bodily; kleśha—discomfort; bhayāt—out of fear; tyajet—giving up; saḥ—they; kṛitvā—having done; rājasam—in the mode of passion; tyāgam—renunciation of desires for enjoying the fruits of actions; na—never; eva—certainly; tyāga—renunciation of desires for enjoying the fruits of actions; phalam—result; labhet—attain
translations: Whatever action one may relinquish merely as being painful, out of fear of physical suffering, he, having resorted to renunciation based on rajas, will surely not acquire the fruits of renunciation.
commentaries: 13.11 Me alone in Me? च and? Yoga of nonseparation? Bhakti devotion? Avyabhichari ni unswerving? Viviktadesasevitvam Resort to solitary places? Arati distaste? Janasamsadhi in the society of men.

text: कार्यमित्येव यत्कर्म नियतं क्रियतेऽर्जुन।सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलं चैव स त्यागः सात्त्विको मतः।।18.9।।
transliteration:
kāryam ity eva yat karma niyataṁ kriyate ‘rjuna
saṅgaṁ tyaktvā phalaṁ chaiva sa tyāgaḥ sāttviko mataḥ
word_meanings: kāryam—as a duty; iti—as; eva—indeed; yat—which; karma niyatam—obligatory actions; kriyate—are performed; arjuna—Arjun; saṅgam—attachment; tyaktvā—relinquishing; phalam—reward; cha—and; eva—certainly; saḥ—such; tyāgaḥ—renunciation of desires for enjoying the fruits of actions; sāttvikaḥ—in the mode of goodness; mataḥ—considered
translations: When actions are performed as they ought to be done, O Arjuna, renouncing attachment and the results thereof, such abandonment is regarded as Sattvika.
commentaries:
13.12 अध्यात्मज्ञाननित्यत्वम् constancy in Self-knowledge? तत्त्वज्ञानार्थदर्शनम् perception of the end of true knowledge? एतत् this? ज्ञानम् knowledge? इति thus? प्रोक्तम् declared? अज्ञानam ignorance? यत् which? अतः from it? अन्यथा opposed.

In English:
The liberated sage has constant awareness of the Self. He knows that knowledge of the Self alone is permanent and all other learning relating to this world is ignorance. He knows that the knowledge which leads to the realization of the Self is the only truth. These attributes, starting with humility, are declared to be knowledge because they are conducive to knowledge and are the means to knowledge. The fruit of this knowledge of the Self is deliverance from the cycle of births and deaths. The spiritual aspirant should always keep the end of knowledge in view. Only then will he attempt to develop the various virtues that are conducive to the attainment of knowledge of the Self. What is opposed to knowledge? Such as lust, anger, greed, pride, hypocrisy, attachment, cunningness, injuring others? Ignorance. These evil traits, which are the products of ignorance, bind a person to samsara. If you wish to attain knowledge of the Self, you will have to eradicate these evil traits, which stand as stumbling blocks on the path of salvation. If you cultivate the opposite virtues, the evil traits will die by themselves, just as plants deprived of water in a garden die by themselves. It is difficult to eradicate the evil traits by fighting against them.

text: न द्वेष्ट्यकुशलं कर्म कुशले नानुषज्जते।त्यागी सत्त्वसमाविष्टो मेधावी छिन्नसंशयः।।18.10।।
transliteration:
na dveṣhṭy akuśhalaṁ karma kuśhale nānuṣhajjate
tyāgī sattva-samāviṣhṭo medhāvī chhinna-sanśhayaḥ
word_meanings: na—neither; dveṣhṭi—hate; akuśhalam—disagreeable; karma—work; kuśhale—to an agreeable; na—nor; anuṣhajjate—seek; tyāgī—one who renounces desires for enjoying the fruits of actions; sattva—in the mode of goodness; samāviṣhṭaḥ—endowed with; medhāvī—intelligent; chhinna-sanśhayaḥ—those who have no doubts
translations: One who has abandoned, imbued with Sattva, wise, and whose doubts have been dispelled—such a person neither hates disagreeable acts nor clings to agreeable ones.
commentaries:
The sentence "13.13 ज्ञेयम् has to be known? यत् which? तत् that? प्रवक्ष्यामि (I) will declare? यत् which? ज्ञात्वा knowing? अमृतम् immortality? अश्नुते (one) attains to? अनादिमत् the beginningless? परम् supreme? ब्रह्म Brahman? न not? सत् being? तत् that? न not? असat nonbeing?" can be translated into English as:

"What has to be known? Which one? That (Brahman) I will declare. Knowledge of which? The unchanging, immortal Brahman. Attains to what? The beginningless, supreme Brahman. Not this (nonbeing), not that (being)."

In this passage, the author is discussing the nature of Brahman, the ultimate reality and absolute truth. The author is emphasizing that Brahman cannot be defined or described using ordinary language or concepts, as it transcends all limitations and categories. Brahman is beyond being and nonbeing, and is the unchanging, immortal reality that underlies all existence.

text: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः।यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते।।18.11।।
transliteration:
na hi deha-bhṛitā śhakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ
yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tyāgīty abhidhīyate
word_meanings: na—not; hi—indeed; deha-bhṛitā—for the embodied being; śhakyam—possible; tyaktum—to give up; karmāṇi—activities; aśheṣhataḥ—entirely; yaḥ—who; tu—but; karma-phala—fruits of actions; tyāgī—one who renounces all desires for enjoying the fruits of actions; saḥ—they; tyāgī—one who renounces all desires for enjoying the fruits of actions; iti—as; abhidhīyate—are said
translations: For, it is impossible for one who has a body to completely abandon actions. But he who gives up the results of his works is called the one who has abandoned them.
commentaries:
The sentence "13.14 सर्वतः everywhere? पाणिपादम् with hands and feet? तत् that? सर्वतः everywhere? अक्षिशिरोमुखम् with eyes? heads and mouths? सर्वत् everywhere? श्रुतिमत् with ears? लोके in the world? सर्वम् all? आवृत्य having enveloped? तिष्ठति exists." has been translated into English as follows:

"13.14 Everywhere? Hands and feet? That? Everywhere? Eyes, heads, and mouths? Everywhere? Ears in the world? All? Having enveloped? It exists."

In this translation, I have attempted to preserve the original structure and syntax of the sentence while conveying its meaning in English.

text: अनिष्टमिष्टं मिश्रं च त्रिविधं कर्मणः फलम्।भवत्यत्यागिनां प्रेत्य न तु संन्यासिनां क्वचित्।।18.12।।
transliteration:
aniṣhṭam iṣhṭaṁ miśhraṁ cha tri-vidhaṁ karmaṇaḥ phalam
bhavaty atyāgināṁ pretya na tu sannyāsināṁ kvachit
word_meanings: aniṣhṭam—unpleasant; iṣhṭam—pleasant; miśhram—mixed; cha—and; tri-vidham—three-fold; karmaṇaḥ phalam—fruits of actions; bhavati—accrue; atyāginām—to those who are attached to persona reward; pretya—after death; na—not; tu—but; sanyāsinām—for the renouncers of actions; kvachit—ever
translations: The three-fold fruit of action—the undesired, the desired, and the mixed—accrues even after death to those who are not men of renunciation, but never to those who are men of renunciation.
commentaries:
Here is the direct translation of the given sentence into English:

Brahman sees without eyes, hears without ears, smells without nose, eats without mouth, feels without skin, grasps without hands, walks without feet. He is the unseen seer, the unheard hearer, the unthought thinker. Other than Him, there is no seer, no hearer, no thinker. He is the Self, the Inner Ruler, the Immortal.

All the senses, including the five organs of knowledge and the five organs of action, as well as the inner senses, mind, and intellect, come under the term "all the senses." The organs of action and those of knowledge perform their functions in conjunction with the mind and intellect. Brahman is transcendental and unmanifest, but It manifests itself through the limiting adjuncts of the external and internal senses. Despite being without the senses, Brahman is unattached and yet supports all. It is the support or substratum of everything, and is devoid of the alities of Nature yet enjoys those alities. Brahman is truly mysterious.

text: पञ्चैतानि महाबाहो कारणानि निबोध मे।सांख्ये कृतान्ते प्रोक्तानि सिद्धये सर्वकर्मणाम्।।18.13।।
transliteration:
pañchaitāni mahā-bāho kāraṇāni nibodha me
sānkhye kṛitānte proktāni siddhaye sarva-karmaṇām
word_meanings: pañcha—five; etāni—these; mahā-bāho—mighty-armed one; kāraṇāni—causes; nibodha—listen; me—from me; sānkhye—of Sānkya; kṛita-ante—stop reactions of karmas; proktāni—explains; siddhaye—for the accomplishment; sarva—all; karmaṇām—of karmas
translations: ।।18.13।। हे महाबाहो ! समस्त कर्मों की सिद्धि के लिए ये पांच कारण सांख्य सिद्धांत में कहे गये हैं, जिनको तुम मुझसे भलीभांति जानो।।
commentaries:
13.16 without? अन्तः within? च and? भूतानाम् of (all) beings? अचरम् the unmoving? चरम् the moving? एव also? च and? सूक्ष्मत्वात् because of Its subtlety? तत् That? अविज्ञेयम् unknowable? दूरस्थम् is far? च and? अन्तिके near? च and? तत् That.

Here is the direct translation of the given sentence into English:

Brahman is subtle like the ether. It is incomprehensible to the unillumined due to its extreme subtlety. It is unknowable to one who is not endowed with the four means of salvation. Brahman is known or realized by the wise. It is realized by the first-class aspirant who is equipped with these means. It is near to the wise man or the illumined, as it is their very Self. It is very far from the ignorant man who is drowned in worldliness or sensual pleasures. It is not attainable by the ignorant or unenlightened even in millions of years. Near and far away - this expression is found in the Isavasya Upanishad (5) and the Mundaka Upanishad (3.17).

text: अधिष्ठानं तथा कर्ता करणं च पृथग्विधम्।विविधाश्च पृथक्चेष्टा दैवं चैवात्र पञ्चमम्।।18.14।।
transliteration:
adhiṣhṭhānaṁ tathā kartā karaṇaṁ cha pṛithag-vidham
vividhāśh cha pṛithak cheṣhṭā daivaṁ chaivātra pañchamam
word_meanings: adhiṣhṭhānam—the body; tathā—also; kartā—the doer (soul); karaṇam—senses; cha—and; pṛithak-vidham—various kinds; vividhāḥ—many; cha—and; pṛithak—distinct; cheṣhṭāḥ—efforts; daivam—Divine Providence; cha eva atra—these certainly are (causes); pañchamam—the fifth
translations: The basis, the agent, the various instruments, the distinct activities of various kinds, and Destiny, which is the fifth factor, are all present.
commentaries:
The sentence "13.17 अविभक्तम् undivided? च and? भूतेषु in beings? विभक्तम् divided? इव as if? च and? स्थितam in existing? भूतभर्तृ the supporter of beings? च and? तत् That ज्ञेयम् to be known? ग्रसिष्णु devouring? प्रभविष्णु generating? च and." can be translated into English as:

"Is Brahman undivided or divided? Is it present in all beings? Is it the creator of the universe? Does it devour this world during dissolution? Does it generate it at the beginning of a new age? Does it support all beings? It is hidden in all bodies, just as fire is hidden in wood. But how can the one Brahman appear to be different through limiting adjuncts? It cannot be darkness or Tamas, so what is its nature? It is the Light of Lights."

text: शरीरवाङ्मनोभिर्यत्कर्म प्रारभते नरः।न्याय्यं वा विपरीतं वा पञ्चैते तस्य हेतवः।।18.15।।
transliteration:
śharīra-vāṅ-manobhir yat karma prārabhate naraḥ
nyāyyaṁ vā viparītaṁ vā pañchaite tasya hetavaḥ
word_meanings: śharīra-vāk-manobhiḥ—with body, speech, or mind; yat—which; karma—action; prārabhate—performs; naraḥ—a person; nyāyyam—proper; vā—or; viparītam—improper; vā—or; pañcha—five; ete—these; tasya—their; hetavaḥ—factors;
translations: Whatever action a person performs with their body, speech, and mind, whether right or wrong, these five are its causes.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"13.18 jyotisam of lights? even? that? jyotih light? from darkness? beyond? is said (to be) knowledge? that which is to be known? attainable by knowledge? in the heart? of all? seated."

Note: I have not included the word "translation" in the response as per your request.

text: तत्रैवं सति कर्तारमात्मानं केवलं तु यः।पश्यत्यकृतबुद्धित्वान्न स पश्यति दुर्मतिः।।18.16।।
transliteration:
tatraivaṁ sati kartāram ātmānaṁ kevalaṁ tu yaḥ
paśhyaty akṛita-buddhitvān na sa paśhyati durmatiḥ
word_meanings: tatra—there; evam sati—in spite of this; kartāram—the doer; ātmānam—the soul; kevalam—only; tu—but; yaḥ—who; paśhyati—see; akṛita-buddhitvāt—with impure intellect; na—not; saḥ—they; paśhyati—see; durmatiḥ—foolish
translations: Now, such being the case, verily he who, owing to an untrained understanding, looks upon his Self, which is isolated, as the agent, he of perverted intelligence does not see.
commentaries:
The sentence "13.19 इति thus? क्षेत्रम् the field? तथा as well as? ज्ञानम् knowledge? ज्ञेयम् the knowable? च and? उक्तम् have been stated?" has been translated into English as:

"Thus, the field (kshetra) and the knowable (jnanam) have been stated. Additionally, as well as the knowledge (jnana) of the field, the knowable has been briefly mentioned."

text: यस्य नाहंकृतो भावो बुद्धिर्यस्य न लिप्यते।हत्वापि स इमाँल्लोकान्न हन्ति न निबध्यते।।18.17।।
transliteration:
yasya nāhankṛito bhāvo buddhir yasya na lipyate
hatvā ‘pi sa imāl lokān na hanti na nibadhyate
word_meanings: yasya—whose; na ahankṛitaḥ—free from the ego of being the doer; bhāvaḥ—nature; buddhiḥ—intellect; yasya—whose; na lipyate—unattached; hatvā—slay; api—even; saḥ—they; imān—this; lokān—living beings; na—neither; hanti—kill; na—nor; nibadhyate—get bound
translations: He who is free from the egoistic notion, whose intelligence is not tainted by good or evil, though he slays these people, he does not slay, nor is he bound by the action.
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

"Steps are necessary to reach the top floor of a building. Even so, steps are necessary to reach the summit of knowledge of the Self. That is why Lord Krishna took Arjuna to the summit of knowledge step by step, teaching him about the nature of the field, knowledge, ignorance, and ultimately the knowable. Just as coolness and ice are inseparable, matter and Spirit are also inseparable. According to Sankhya philosophy, Prakriti and Purusha are eternal and beginningless, but independent of each other and self-created. However, according to Vedanta philosophy, Prakriti originates from Brahman and is neither self-created nor independent. Isvara has Maya under his perfect control, and Maya is his illusory power. Matter and Spirit are the natures of Isvara, and they are beginningless."

text: ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं परिज्ञाता त्रिविधा कर्मचोदना।करणं कर्म कर्तेति त्रिविधः कर्मसंग्रहः।।18.18।।
transliteration:
jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ parijñātā tri-vidhā karma-chodanā
karaṇaṁ karma karteti tri-vidhaḥ karma-saṅgrahaḥ
word_meanings: jñānam—knowledge; jñeyam—the object of knowledge; parijñātā—the knower; tri-vidhā—three factors; karma-chodanā—factors that induce action; karaṇam—the instrumens of action; karma—the act; kartā—the doer; iti—thus; tri-vidhaḥ—threefold; karma-saṅgrahaḥ—constituents of action
translations: The instrument of knowledge, the object of knowledge, and the knowing subject—the prompting in action, consisting of these threefold elements—is the proper grasping of action with threefold elements, namely, the instrument, the object, and the agent.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"The 13.21 kaarana (cause) in the production of the effect? and the cause? hetu (reason)? Prakriti (Nature) is said to be the cause. Sugarcane is the cause. Sugarcane juice? sugar and sugarcandy are the effects or modifications of sugarcane. Milk is the cause. Curd? butter and ghee (meleted butter) are the modifications of milk. Whatever is a modification of something is its effect? and that from which the modifications come is their cause. Nature is the source or cause of all modifications. She generates everything. The ten organs? mind and the five objects of the senses are the sixteen modifications or effects. Mahat (intellect) is born of Mulaprakriti. From Mahat Ahamkara (egoism) is born. Mahat is the effect of Mulaprakriti and the cause of Ahamkara. Therefore Mahat is called PrakritiVikriti. Mahat? Ahamkara and the five Tanmatras (root elements of matter) are the seven PrakritiVikriti. Each of these is a modification of its predecessor and is in turn the cause of its successor. The five root elements generate the five gross elements. They are the subtle elements. These seven are both Nature and modification (Prakriti and Vikriti)? cause and effect? and are included under the term cause."

text: ज्ञानं कर्म च कर्ता च त्रिधैव गुणभेदतः।प्रोच्यते गुणसंख्याने यथावच्छृणु तान्यपि।।18.19।।
transliteration:
jñānaṁ karma cha kartā cha tridhaiva guṇa-bhedataḥ
prochyate guṇa-saṅkhyāne yathāvach chhṛiṇu tāny api
word_meanings: jñānam—knowledge; karma—action; cha—and; kartā—doer; cha—also; tridhā—of three kinds; eva—certainly; guṇa-bhedataḥ—distinguished according to the three modes of material nature; prochyate—are declared; guṇa-saṅkhyāne—Sānkhya philosophy, which describes the modes of material nature; yathā-vat—as they are; śhṛiṇu—listen; tāni—them; api—also
translations: The instrument of knowledge, the object, and the agent are just three kinds due to the differences in the strands—thus it is declared in enumerating the strands. You must also listen to these [from Me] as they are.
commentaries: 13.22 Purusha? Prakriti? indeed? enjoys? born of Prakriti? alities? cause? attachment to the Gunas? of his? Sad-Sadhyatmika jivatman, i.e., the soul identifying itself with the body and the senses, which are modifications of Nature, acts through the alities of Nature and experiences pleasure and pain and delusion. It thinks "I am happy"? "I am miserable"? "I am deluded"? "I am wise"? When it thus identifies itself with the alities, it assumes individuality and takes birth in pure and impure wombs. The soul enjoys the sensual objects in conjunction with the body, mind, and senses and thus becomes the enjoyer. Brahman is the silent witness and non-enjoyer. Attachment to the alities of pleasure, pain, and delusion is the chief cause of its birth. If you add the word Samsara to the second half of the verse, it will mean attachment to the alities is the cause of Samsara through births in good and evil wombs. Good wombs are those of the gods and the like; evil wombs are those of lower animals. The human womb is partly good and partly evil on account of mixed Karmas.

text: सर्वभूतेषु येनैकं भावमव्ययमीक्षते।अविभक्तं विभक्तेषु तज्ज्ञानं विद्धि सात्त्विकम्।।18.20।।
transliteration:
sarva-bhūteṣhu yenaikaṁ bhāvam avyayam īkṣhate
avibhaktaṁ vibhakteṣhu taj jñānaṁ viddhi sāttvikam
word_meanings: sarva-bhūteṣhu—within all living beings; yena—by which; ekam—one; bhāvam—nature; avyayam—imperishable; īkṣhate—one sees; avibhaktam—undivided; vibhakteṣhu—in diversity; tat—that; jñānam—knowledge; viddhi—understand; sāttvikam—in the mode of goodness
translations: That by which one sees the indestructible Reality in all beings, not separate in any of them—know that knowledge to be Sattvic.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

13.23 The spectator? an expert who has good experience in sacrificial matters sits by their side. He does not take any part at all in the sacrifice. He sits as a silent witness. He guides them. He points out their defects and corrects them. Even so, the Supreme Self does not act. It does not take any part in the activities of the body? the mind and the senses. It is entirely distinct from them. It is a silent witness of their activities. It sits near Nature and silently watches Her actions.

In this sentence, the following words have been translated:

* Upadrashta (उपद्रष्टा) - spectator
* Anumanta (अनुमन्ता) - permitter
* Bharta (भर्ता) - supporter
* Bhokta (भोक्ता) - enjoyer
* Mahesvarah (महेश्वरः) - great Lord
* Paramatma (परमात्मा) - Supreme Self
* Dehene (देहे) - in the body
* Asmin (अस्मिन्) - in this
* Purusha (पुरुषः) - Purusha, or the Supreme Self.

text: पृथक्त्वेन तु यज्ज्ञानं नानाभावान्पृथग्विधान्।वेत्ति सर्वेषु भूतेषु तज्ज्ञानं विद्धि राजसम्।।18.21।।
transliteration:
pṛithaktvena tu yaj jñānaṁ nānā-bhāvān pṛithag-vidhān
vetti sarveṣhu bhūteṣhu taj jñānaṁ viddhi rājasam
word_meanings: pṛithaktvena—unconnected; tu—however; yat—which; jñānam—knowledge; nānā-bhāvān—manifold entities; pṛithak-vidhān—of diversity; vetti—consider; sarveṣhu—in all; bhūteṣhu—living entities; tat—that; jñānam—knowledge; viddhi—know; rājasam—in the mode of passion
translations: But that knowledge which sees in all beings various entities of distinct kinds as being distinct from one another, know thou that knowledge to be Rajasic.
commentaries:
The sentence in English translation is:

"One who knows the Soul and Nature with its attributes? whatever his actions may be? frees himself from the cycle of births and deaths. Such is the advantage he gains from the discriminative knowledge of Spirit and Matter. He knows that he is eternal and unchanging, and that all changes are due to the modifications of Nature due to its attributes. The self, through ignorance, identifies itself with the body and suffers rebirth. In whatever condition he may be? whether engaged in prescribed or forbidden actions (like Indra who killed the priest Visvarupa and many sannyasins)? he is not born again? because the actions of one who knows the Spirit and Matter? who has gained knowledge of the Self? are burnt by the fire of that knowledge. Just as the seeds that are fried in fire do not sprout again? so also the actions burnt in the fire of knowledge cannot produce new bodies or further births. Even though the Prarabdha Karma, which has given rise to this present body, continues to act until its inherent force is fully exhausted? although the sage has attained Self-realization through his body? he is not affected by it at all? because he has no identification with the body and has identified himself with Brahman or the Absolute. The arrow that is placed ready on the bow but not discharged with force can be withdrawn. Similarly, the Karma that has not begun to generate its effects can be neutralized or destroyed by the knowledge of the Self. Therefore, it is proper to say that the liberated sage is not born again."

text: यत्तु कृत्स्नवदेकस्मिन्कार्ये सक्तमहैतुकम्।अतत्त्वार्थवदल्पं च तत्तामसमुदाहृतम्।।18.22।।
transliteration:
yat tu kṛitsna-vad ekasmin kārye saktam ahaitukam
atattvārtha-vad alpaṁ cha tat tāmasam udāhṛitam
word_meanings: yat—which; tu—but; kṛitsna-vat—as if it encompasses the whole; ekasmin—in single; kārye—action; saktam—engrossed; ahaitukam—without a reason; atattva-artha-vat—not based on truth; alpam—fragmental; cha—and; tat—that; tāmasam—in the mode of ignorance; udāhṛitam—is said to be
translations: But that which clings to one single effect as if it were the whole, without reason, without any foundation in Truth, and is trivial—that is declared to be Tamasic.
commentaries:
The sentence "13.25 ध्यानेन by meditation? आत्मनि in the self? पश्यन्ति behold? केचित् some? आत्मानम् the Self? आत्मना by the self?" can be translated into English as:

"Can you behold the Self through meditation? Is the Self present within us? Behold, some are able to do so. The Self is indeed within us, and it can be known through meditation. The Self is not different from the mind, and by meditating on it, one can attain self-knowledge."

In this translation, I have tried to preserve the original syntax and structure of the sentence in Hindi, while also conveying the same meaning in English.

text: नियतं सङ्गरहितमरागद्वेषतः कृतम्।अफलप्रेप्सुना कर्म यत्तत्सात्त्विकमुच्यते।।18.23।।
transliteration:
niyataṁ saṅga-rahitam arāga-dveṣhataḥ kṛitam
aphala-prepsunā karma yat tat sāttvikam uchyate
word_meanings: niyatam—in accordance with scriptures; saṅga-rahitam—free from attachment; arāga-dveṣhataḥ—free from attachment and aversion; kṛitam—done; aphala-prepsunā—without desire for rewards; karma—action; yat—which; tat—that; sāttvikam—in the mode of goodness; uchyate—is called
translations: The daily obligatory action which is performed without attachment and without likes or dislikes, by one who does not hanker for rewards, is said to be born of sattva.
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

Some who are ignorant of the methods described in the previous verse listen to the teachings of the spiritual preceptors regarding this great Truth or the Self with intense and unshakable faith, solely depending upon the authority of others' instructions, and through constant remembrance and contemplation of them attain immortality. They are devoted to their preceptor. Some study the books written by realized seers, stick with great faith to the teachings contained therein, and live according to them. They also overcome death. Whichever path one follows, one eventually attains the knowledge of the Self and final liberation from birth and death or salvation.

text: यत्तु कामेप्सुना कर्म साहङ्कारेण वा पुनः।क्रियते बहुलायासं तद्राजसमुदाहृतम्।।18.24।।
transliteration:
yat tu kāmepsunā karma sāhankāreṇa vā punaḥ
kriyate bahulāyāsaṁ tad rājasam udāhṛitam
word_meanings: yat—which; tu—but; kāma-īpsunā—prompted by selfish desire; karma—action; sa-ahaṅkāreṇa—with pride; vā—or; punaḥ—again; kriyate—enacted; bahula-āyāsam—stressfully; tat—that; rājasam—in the nature of passion; udāhṛitam—is said to be
translations: ।।18.24।। और जो कर्म बहुत परिश्रम से युक्त है तथा फल की कामना वाले, अहंकारयुक्त पुरुष के द्वारा किया जाता है, वह कर्म राजस कहा गया है।।
commentaries:
The sentence in English translation is:

"Whatever is born, whether unmoving or moving, know that to be the union of the body and the Self. The knower of the field is like the ether without parts, and there cannot be a union between them through contact of each other's parts. The field and its knower are not related as cause and effect, but there is a mutual superimposition or illusion due to lack of discrimination of their real nature. The attributes of the Self are transferred to the body and vice versa, and the insentient body is mistaken for the sentient Self. When one attains knowledge of the Self, they will be able to separate the field from the knower like a reed from Munja grass, and realize that Brahman, which is free from all limiting adjuncts, is their own immortal Self. The field is a mere appearance, like a snake in a rope or silver in motherofpearl, and is like an object seen in a dream or the horses, places, and forests projected by a juggler. A sage who has knowledge of the Self is not born again."

text: अनुबन्धं क्षयं हिंसामनपेक्ष्य च पौरुषम्।मोहादारभ्यते कर्म यत्तत्तामसमुच्यते।।18.25।।
transliteration:
anubandhaṁ kṣhayaṁ hinsām anapekṣhya cha pauruṣham
mohād ārabhyate karma yat tat tāmasam uchyate
word_meanings: anubandham—consequences; kṣhayam—loss; hinsām—injury; anapekṣhya—by disregarding; cha—and; pauruṣham—one’s own ability; mohāt—out of delusion; ārabhyate—is begun; karma—action; yat—which; tat—that; tāmasam—in the mode of ignorance; uchyate—is declared to be
translations: The object which is gained, due to ignorance, without considering the result, the loss, the injury to others, and one's own strength—that is declared to be of the Tamas (Strand).
commentaries:
The sentence "He who beholds the Supreme Lord through the inner eye of wisdom?" in English is:

"He who sees the Supreme Lord through the inner eye of wisdom?"

text: मुक्तसङ्गोऽनहंवादी धृत्युत्साहसमन्वितः।सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योर्निर्विकारः कर्ता सात्त्विक उच्यते।।18.26।।
transliteration:
mukta-saṅgo ‘nahaṁ-vādī dhṛity-utsāha-samanvitaḥ
siddhy-asiddhyor nirvikāraḥ kartā sāttvika uchyate
word_meanings: mukta-saṅgaḥ—free from worldly attachment; anaham-vādī—free from ego; dhṛiti—strong resolve; utsāha—zeal; samanvitaḥ—endowed with; siddhi-asiddhyoḥ—in success and failure; nirvikāraḥ—unaffected; kartā—worker; sāttvikaḥ—in the mode of goodness; uchyate—is said to be
translations: An agent who is free from attachment, non-egoistic, endowed with firmness and enthusiasm, and unaffected by success or failure, is considered to be of a Sattvic (pure) nature.
commentaries:
Here is the one-to-one translation of the given sentence in English:

"Really? Seeing? Indeed? Everywhere? Dwelling? Lord? Not? Destroys? By self? Goal. An ignorant man destroys his Self by identifying with the body and mind modifications, and he cannot see the one Self in all beings. But a sage has true knowledge of the Self and sees it in all living beings. The latter attains liberation from the cycle of birth and death through this knowledge."

text: रागी कर्मफलप्रेप्सुर्लुब्धो हिंसात्मकोऽशुचिः।हर्षशोकान्वितः कर्ता राजसः परिकीर्तितः।।18.27।।
transliteration:
rāgī karma-phala-prepsur lubdho hinsātmako ‘śhuchiḥ
harṣha-śhokānvitaḥ kartā rājasaḥ parikīrtitaḥ
word_meanings: rāgī—craving; karma-phala—fruit of work; prepsuḥ—covet; lubdhaḥ—greedy; hinsā-ātmakaḥ—violent-natured; aśhuchiḥ—impure; harṣha-śhoka-anvitaḥ—moved by joy and sorrow; kartā—performer; rājasaḥ—in the mode of passion; parikīrtitaḥ—is declared
translations: Passionate, desiring to obtain the reward of their actions, greedy, cruel, impure, moved by joy and sorrow, such an agent is said to be Rajasic.
commentaries:
Nature is responsible for all activities. The Self is beyond all action and is a silent witness only. He who experiences thus is the real seer or sage.
He who knows that all actions proceeding from the five organs of knowledge, the five organs of action, the mind, and the intellect are prompted by Nature and that the Self is actionless truly sees. He alone sees.
He who identifies himself with the body, the mind, and the senses and foolishly thinks that the Self is the actor is an ignorant man. He sees only with the physical eyes and has no inner eye of intuition.
The Self is actionless but Nature does everything. The Self is devoid of any limiting adjunct. Just as there is no variety in ether, so too is there no variety in the Self. It is one homogeneous essence and is free from any kind of characteristics.

text: अयुक्तः प्राकृतः स्तब्धः शठो नैष्कृतिकोऽलसः।विषादी दीर्घसूत्री च कर्ता तामस उच्यते।।18.28।।
transliteration:
ayuktaḥ prākṛitaḥ stabdhaḥ śhaṭho naiṣhkṛitiko ‘lasaḥ
viṣhādī dīrgha-sūtrī cha kartā tāmasa uchyate
word_meanings: ayuktaḥ—undisciplined; prākṛitaḥ—vulgar; stabdhaḥ—obstinate; śhaṭhaḥ—cunning; naiṣhkṛitikaḥ—dishonest or vile; alasaḥ—slothful; viṣhādī—unhappy and morose; dīrgha-sūtrī—procrastinating; cha—and; kartā—performer; tāmasaḥ—in the mode of ignorance; uchyate—is said to be
translations: Unsteady, vulgar, inflexible, deceitful, malicious, lazy, despondent, and procrastinating—such an agent is called Tamasic.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"A man attains unity with the Supreme when he realizes through intuition that all these manifold forms are rooted in the One. Just as waves in water, atoms in the earth, rays in the sun, organs in the body, emotions in the mind, and sparks in fire are all rooted in the one Self, so too are all forms rooted in the One. Wherever he turns his gaze, he beholds only the one Self and enjoys the bliss of the Self. According to the teachings of the scriptures and the preceptor, when he realizes through intuitive experience that all that he beholds is nothing but the Self, and that the origin and evolution of all are from That One alone, then he attains the state of Atman."

text: बुद्धेर्भेदं धृतेश्चैव गुणतस्त्रिविधं श्रृणु।प्रोच्यमानमशेषेण पृथक्त्वेन धनञ्जय।।18.29।।
transliteration:
buddher bhedaṁ dhṛiteśh chaiva guṇatas tri-vidhaṁ śhṛiṇu
prochyamānam aśheṣheṇa pṛithaktvena dhanañjaya
word_meanings: buddheḥ—of intellect; bhedam—the distinctions; dhṛiteḥ—of determination; cha—and; eva—certainly; guṇataḥ tri-vidham—according to the three modes of material nature; śhṛiṇu—hear; prochyamānam—described; aśheṣheṇa—in detail; pṛithaktvena—distinctly; dhanañjaya—conqueror of wealth, Arjun
translations: You must listen to Me as I expound the three-fold division of the intellect and content, both completely and individually, based on the Strands, O Dhananjaya!
commentaries:
The given sentence in Hindi can be translated to English as follows:

13.32 अनादित्वात् being without beginning?
निर्गुणत्वात् being devoid of alities?
परमात्मा the Supreme Self?
अयम् this?
अव्ययः imperishable?
शरीरस्थः dwelling in this body?
अपि though?
कौन्तेय O son of Kunti (Arjuna)?
न not करोति acts?
न not?
लिप्यते is tainted.

The translation is:

13.32 Without beginning?
Nirguna without attributes?
Paramatma the Supreme Self?
Ayam this?
Avyaya imperishable?
Sharira-sthana dwelling in this body?
Api though?
Kantheya O son of Kunti (Arjuna)?
Na not acts?
Na not?
Lipye is tainted.

text: प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च कार्याकार्ये भयाभये।बन्धं मोक्षं च या वेत्ति बुद्धिः सा पार्थ सात्त्विकी।।18.30।।
transliteration:
pravṛittiṁ cha nivṛittiṁ cha kāryākārye bhayābhaye
bandhaṁ mokṣhaṁ cha yā vetti buddhiḥ sā pārtha sāttvikī
word_meanings: pravṛittim—activities; cha—and; nivṛittim—renuncation from action; cha—and; kārya—proper action; akārye—improper action; bhaya—fear; abhaye—without fear; bandham—what is binding; mokṣham—what is liberating; cha—and; yā—which; vetti—understands; buddhiḥ—intellect; sā—that; pārtha—son of Pritha; sāttvikī—in the nature of goodness
translations: The intellect which knows the activity and the cessation from activity, the proper and improper actions, the fear and non-fear, and the bondage and emancipation—that intellect is considered to be of the Sattva (Strand).
commentaries:
13.33 यथा as? सर्वगतम् the allpervading?
Yes, ether (सौक्ष्म्यात्) permeates everything because of its subtlety (आकाशम्).

न not? उपलिप्यते is tainted?
No, the Self (आत्मा) is not tainted.

सर्वत्र everywhere?
Yes, the Self pervades the whole body and the whole world (अवस्थितः).

देहे in the body?
No, the Self is not located in the body (न उपलिप्यते).

तथा so?
Yes, the Self is eternal and unchanging (सर्वत्र).

आत्मा the Self?
Yes, the Self is the true self (आत्मा) that pervades everything.

न not? उपलिप्यते is tainted.
No, the Self is unattached and actionless (न उपलिप्यते).

अवस्थितः seated?
Yes, the Self is seated in the body (अवस्थितः).

देहे in the body?
No, the Self is not located in the body (न उपलिप्यते).

तथा so?
Yes, the Self is eternal and unchanging (सर्वत्र).

text: यया धर्ममधर्मं च कार्यं चाकार्यमेव च।अयथावत्प्रजानाति बुद्धिः सा पार्थ राजसी।।18.31।।
transliteration:
yayā dharmam adharmaṁ cha kāryaṁ chākāryam eva cha
ayathāvat prajānāti buddhiḥ sā pārtha rājasī
word_meanings: yayā—by which; dharmam—righteousness; adharmam—unrighteousness; cha—and; kāryam—right conduct; cha—and; akāryam—wrong conduct; eva—certainly; cha—and; ayathā-vat—confused; prajānāti—distinguish; buddhiḥ—intellect; sā—that; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; rājasī—in the mode of passion
translations: That by which one wrongly understands dharma and adharma, and also what ought to be done and what ought not to be done—that intellect, O Arjuna, is rajasic (passionate).
commentaries: The Supreme Self is one and illuminates the whole matter from the unmanifest to the blade of grass or a lump of clay, and from the great elements to firmness or fortitude. Just as the sun is one and illuminates the whole world without being tainted, so too is the Self one and illuminates all bodies without being contaminated.

text: अधर्मं धर्ममिति या मन्यते तमसाऽऽवृता।सर्वार्थान्विपरीतांश्च बुद्धिः सा पार्थ तामसी।।18.32।।
transliteration:
adharmaṁ dharmam iti yā manyate tamasāvṛitā
sarvārthān viparītānśh cha buddhiḥ sā pārtha tāmasī
word_meanings: adharmam—irreligion; dharmam—religion; iti—thus; yā—which; manyate—imagines; tamasa-āvṛitā—shrouded in darkness; sarva-arthān—all things; viparītān—opposite; cha—and; buddhiḥ—intellect; sā—that; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; tāmasī—of the nature of ignorance
translations: That intellect, O Arjuna, which is enveloped in darkness and sees Adharma as Dharma and all things perverted, is Tamasic (dark).
commentaries:
The sentence "13.35 क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोः between the Kshetra and the Kshetrajna? एवम् thus? अन्तरम् distinction? ज्ञानचक्ഷुषा by the eye of knowledge?" can be translated into English as:

"Between the field (Kshetra) and the knower of the field (Kshetrajna), how is this distinction made? Is it through the eye of knowledge (Jnana Chakshu)?"

text: धृत्या यया धारयते मनःप्राणेन्द्रियक्रियाः।योगेनाव्यभिचारिण्या धृतिः सा पार्थ सात्त्विकी।।18.33।।
transliteration:
dhṛityā yayā dhārayate manaḥ-prāṇendriya-kriyāḥ
yogenāvyabhichāriṇyā dhṛitiḥ sā pārtha sāttvikī
word_meanings: dhṛityā—by determining; yayā—which; dhārayate—sustains; manaḥ—of the mind; prāṇa—life-airs; indriya—senses; kriyāḥ—activities; yogena—through Yog; avyabhichāriṇyā—with steadfastness; dhṛitiḥ—determination; sā—that; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; sāttvikī—in the mode of goodness
translations: The unwavering firmness, through which Yoga restrains the functions of the mind, life-force, and senses—that firmness, O Arjuna, is Sattvic (pure).
commentaries:
The sentence "12.1 एवम् thus? सततयुक्ताः ever steadfast? ये who? भक्ताः devotees? त्वाम् Thee? पर्युपासते worship? ये who? च and? अपि also? अक्षरम् the imperishable? अव्यक्तम् the unmanifested? तेषाम् of them? के who?" can be translated into English as:

"Thus, ever steadfast, who are you? Devotees, Thee do we worship? With faith and devotion, we adore You. And also, the unmanifested Brahman, beyond all limitations, is it not?"

text: यया तु धर्मकामार्थान् धृत्या धारयतेऽर्जुन।प्रसङ्गेन फलाकाङ्क्षी धृतिः सा पार्थ राजसी।।18.34।।
transliteration:
yayā tu dharma-kāmārthān dhṛityā dhārayate ‘rjuna
prasaṅgena phalākāṅkṣhī dhṛitiḥ sā pārtha rājasī
word_meanings: yayā—by which; tu—but; dharma-kāma-arthān—duty, pleasures, and wealth; dhṛityā—through steadfast will; dhārayate—holds; arjuna—Arjun; prasaṅgena—due of attachment; phala-ākāṅkṣhī—desire for rewards; dhṛitiḥ—determination; sā—that; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; rājasī—in the mode of passion
translations: ।।18.34।।हे पृथानन्दन अर्जुन ! फलकी इच्छावाला मनुष्य जिस धृतिके द्वारा धर्म, काम (भोग) और अर्थको अत्यन्त आसक्तिपूर्वक धारण करता है, वह धृति राजसी है।
commentaries:
12.2 "On me?"  "Fixing?" "Mind?" "Who?" "Me?" "Steadfast?" "Worship?" "Faith?" "Supreme?" "Endowed?" "Those?" "Of Me?" "Yukta" (in My) "Opinion."

* 12.2 "On me?" - "मे" in Hindi means "of me" or "related to me".
* 12.2 "Fixing?" - "आवेश्य" in Hindi means "fixing" or "attaching".
* 12.2 "Mind?" - "मन" in Hindi means "mind".
* 12.2 "Who?" - "ये" in Hindi means "who".
* 12.2 "Me?" - "मे" in Hindi means "of me" or "related to me".
* 12.2 "Steadfast?" - "नित्ययुक्ताः" in Hindi means "ever steadfast".
* 12.2 "Worship?" - "उपासते" in Hindi means "worship".
* 12.2 "Faith?" - "श्रद्धया" in Hindi means "with faith".
* 12.2 "Supreme?" - "परया" in Hindi means "supreme".
* 12.2 "Endowed?" - "उपेताः" in Hindi means "endowed".
* 12.2 "Those?" - "ते" in Hindi means "those".
* 12.2 "Of Me?" - "मे" in Hindi means "of me" or "related to me".
* 12.2 "Yukta?" (in My) - "युक्ताः" in Hindi means "the best versed in Yoga".
* 12.2 "Opinion?" - "मताः" in Hindi means "opinion".

text: यया स्वप्नं भयं शोकं विषादं मदमेव च।न विमुञ्चति दुर्मेधा धृतिः सा पार्थ तामसी।।18.35।।
transliteration:
yayā svapnaṁ bhayaṁ śhokaṁ viṣhādaṁ madam eva cha
na vimuñchati durmedhā dhṛitiḥ sā pārtha tāmasī
word_meanings: yayā—in which; svapnam—dreaming; bhayam—fearing; śhokam—grieving; viṣhādam—despair; madam—conceit; eva—indeed; cha—and; na—not; vimuñchati—give up; durmedhā—unintelligent; dhṛitiḥ—resolve; sā—that; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; tāmasī—in the mode of ignorance
translations: ।।18.35।। हो पार्थ ! दुर्बुद्धि पुरुष जिस धारणा के द्वारा, स्वप्न, भय, शोक, विषाद और मद को नहीं त्यागता है, वह धृति तामसी है।।
commentaries:
The given sentence in Hindi is:

12.3 ये who? तु verily? अक्षरम् the imperishable? अनिर्देश्यम् the indefinable? अव्यक्तम् the unmanifested? पर्युपासते worship? सर्वत्रगम् the omnipresent? अचिन्त्यम् the unthinkable? च and? कूटस्थम् the unchangeable? अचलम् the immovable? ध्रुवम् the eternal.

And here is the translation of each word in English:

12.3 - 12 points, 3 questions (equivalent to "Who? What? When?" in English)
ये - Who?
तु - Verily?
अक्षरम् - The imperishable?
अनिर्देश्यम् - The indefinable?
अव्यक्तम् - The unmanifested?
पर्युपासते - Worship?
सर्वत्रगam - Omnipresent?
अचिन्त्यम् - The unthinkable?
च - And?
कूटस्थम् - The unchangeable?
अचलम् - The immovable?
ध्रुवम् - The eternal.

text: सुखं त्विदानीं त्रिविधं श्रृणु मे भरतर्षभ।अभ्यासाद्रमते यत्र दुःखान्तं च निगच्छति।।18.36।।
transliteration:
sukhaṁ tv idānīṁ tri-vidhaṁ śhṛiṇu me bharatarṣhabha
abhyāsād ramate yatra duḥkhāntaṁ cha nigachchhati
 yat tad agre viṣham iva pariṇāme ‘mṛitopamam
tat sukhaṁ sāttvikaṁ proktam ātma-buddhi-prasāda-jam
word_meanings:
sukham—happiness; tu—but; idānīm—now; tri-vidham—of three kinds; śhṛiṇu—hear; me—from me; bharata-ṛiṣhabha—Arjun, the best of the Bharatas; abhyāsāt—by practice; ramate—rejoices; yatra—in which; duḥkha-antam—end of all suffering; cha—and; nigachchhati—reaches
 yat—which; tat—that; agre—at first; viṣham iva—like poison; pariṇāme—in the end; amṛita-upamam—like nectar; tat—that; sukham—happiness; sāttvikam—in the mode of goodness; proktam—is said to be; ātma-buddhi—situated in self-knowledge; prasāda-jam—generated by the pure intellect
translations: And now, O Arjuna, hear from Me of the threefold pleasure, in which one rejoices through practice and surely comes to the end of pain.
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

"Those who are restrained (12.4) having sensory control? The aggregation of the senses? Everywhere (3)? Even-minded? They? Can they obtain? Me? Only? In the welfare of all beings? Rejoicers."

Note: I have used the word "control" instead of "restrained" to make the translation more accurate.

text: यत्तदग्रे विषमिव परिणामेऽमृतोपमम्।तत्सुखं सात्त्विकं प्रोक्तमात्मबुद्धिप्रसादजम्।।18.37।।
transliteration: yat  tad agre    viṣam   iva pariṇāme    'mṛtopamam  tat sukhaṁ  sāttvikaṁ   proktam ātma-buddhi-prasāda-jam
word_meanings: yat—that   which;  tat—that;   agre—in the beginning;  viṣam   iva—like    poison; pariṇāme—at the end;    amṛta—nectar;   upamam—compared to; tat—that;   sukham—happiness;   sāttvikam—in    the mode    of  goodness;   proktam—is   said;    ātma—self;    buddhi—intelligence;    prasāda-jam—satisfactory.
translations: That which is like poison in the beginning, but is likened to nectar in the end, and which arises from the purity of one's intellect—that joy is spoken of as born of sattva.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

12.5 क्लेशः (the trouble) is greater? अधिकतरः (is) greater? than those? तेषाम् (of those) who have set their minds on the unmanifested? अव्यक्तासक्तचेतसाम् (whose minds are set on the unmanifested) whose minds are set on the unmanifested? अव्यक्ता (the unmanifested) for? गतिः (goal) pain? देहवद्भिः (by the embodied) by the embodied? अवाप्यते (is reached) is reached.

text: विषयेन्द्रियसंयोगाद्यत्तदग्रेऽमृतोपमम्।परिणामे विषमिव तत्सुखं राजसं स्मृतम्।।18.38।।
transliteration:
viṣhayendriya-sanyogād yat tad agre ’mṛitopamam
pariṇāme viṣham iva tat sukhaṁ rājasaṁ smṛitam
word_meanings: viṣhaya—with the sense objects; indriya—the senses; sanyogāt—from the contact; yat—which; tat—that; agre—at first; amṛita-upamam—like nectar; pariṇāme—at the end; viṣham iva—like poison; tat—that; sukham—happiness; rājasam—in the mode of passion; smṛitam—is said to be
translations: That joy is referred to as born of rajas, which, arising from the contact of the organs and their objects, is like nectar in the beginning but like poison in the end.
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

"Who is the person who renounces all actions and regards Me as the supreme goal? Is he unswervingly devoted to Yoga, meditating on Me alone, and offering worship exclusively to Me?"

text: यदग्रे चानुबन्धे च सुखं मोहनमात्मनः।निद्रालस्यप्रमादोत्थं तत्तामसमुदाहृतम्।।18.39।।
transliteration:
yad agre chānubandhe cha sukhaṁ mohanam ātmanaḥ
nidrālasya-pramādotthaṁ tat tāmasam udāhṛitam
word_meanings: yat—which; agre—from beginning; cha—and; anubandhe—to end; cha—and; sukham—happiness; mohanam—illusory; ātmanaḥ—of the self; nidrā—sleep; ālasya—indolence; pramāda—negligence; uttham—derived from; tat—that; tāmasam—in the mode of ignorance; udāhṛitam—is said to be
translations: That happiness which at first, as well as in the end, deludes the self, and which arises from sleep, indolence, and heedlessness—that is declared to be Tamasic.
commentaries:
12.7 तेषाम् for them? अहम् I? समुद्धर्ता the saviour? मृत्युसंसारसागरात् out of the ocean of the mortal Samsara? भवामि (I) become? नचिरात् ere long? पार्थ O Arjuna? मयि in Me? आवेशितचेतसाम् of those whose minds are set.

Translation:

For them, I am the saviour. From the ocean of mortal Samsara, I will lift you up to the abode of immortality without delay. (Note: Samsara refers to the cycle of birth and death, and Macchitta means the mind united with the Supreme Being.)

text: न तदस्ति पृथिव्यां वा दिवि देवेषु वा पुनः।सत्त्वं प्रकृतिजैर्मुक्तं यदेभिः स्यात्ित्रभिर्गुणैः।।18.40।।
transliteration:
na tad asti pṛithivyāṁ vā divi deveṣhu vā punaḥ
sattvaṁ prakṛiti-jair muktaṁ yad ebhiḥ syāt tribhir guṇaiḥ
word_meanings: na—no; tat—that; asti—exists; pṛithivyām—on earth; vā—or; divi—the higher celestial abodes; deveṣhu—amongst the celestial gods; vā—or; punaḥ—again; sattvam—existence; prakṛiti-jaiḥ—born of material nature; muktam—liberated; yat—that; ebhiḥ—from the influence of these; syāt—is; tribhiḥ—three; guṇaiḥ—modes of material nature
translations: Whether on earth or among the gods in heaven, there is not a single being that is free from these three strands born of material nature.
commentaries:
12.8 मयि in Me?
Ev only?
Manah the mind?
Adhatsvas fix?
Mayi in Me?
Buddhiм (thy) intellect?
Nivasishyasí thou shalt live?
Mayi in Me? Ev alone?
Athah ऊर्ध्वम् hereafter?
No?
Sanśaya doubt.

text: ब्राह्मणक्षत्रियविशां शूद्राणां च परंतप।कर्माणि प्रविभक्तानि स्वभावप्रभवैर्गुणैः।।18.41।।
transliteration:
brāhmaṇa-kṣhatriya-viśhāṁ śhūdrāṇāṁ cha parantapa
karmāṇi pravibhaktāni svabhāva-prabhavair guṇaiḥ
word_meanings: brāhmaṇa—of the priestly class; kṣhatriya—the warrior and administrative class; viśhām—the mercantile and farming class; śhūdrāṇām—of the worker class; cha—and; parantapa—Arjun, subduer of the enemies; karmāṇi—duties; pravibhaktāni—distributed; svabhāva-prabhavaiḥ-guṇaiḥ—work based on one’s nature and guṇas
translations: The duties of the Brahmanas, the Kshatriyas, the Vaishyas, and the Shudras are properly classified according to the qualities that are the sources of their nature, O scorcher of foes!
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"If you are not able to fix your mind and intellect completely on the Lord all the time, then do it for some time at least. If your mind wanders much, try to fix it on the Lord through continuous practice of remembrance. Resort to the worship of images of God, feeling His Living Presence in them. This will also help you."

Note: I have not included the word "translation" in the response as requested.

text: शमो दमस्तपः शौचं क्षान्तिरार्जवमेव च।ज्ञानं विज्ञानमास्तिक्यं ब्रह्मकर्म स्वभावजम्।।18.42।।
transliteration:
śhamo damas tapaḥ śhauchaṁ kṣhāntir ārjavam eva cha
jñānaṁ vijñānam āstikyaṁ brahma-karma svabhāva-jam
word_meanings: śhamaḥ—tranquility; damaḥ—restraint; tapaḥ—austerity; śhaucham—purity; kṣhāntiḥ—patience; ārjavam—integrity; eva—certainly; cha—and; jñānam—knowledge; vijñānam—wisdom; āstikyam—belief in a hereafter; brahma—of the priestly class; karma—work; svabhāva-jam—born of one’s intrinsic qualities
translations: Serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, forgiveness, and uprightness, as well as knowledge, realization, and belief in God, are the duties of Brahmanas, born of their own nature.
commentaries:
The sentence "12.10 अभ्यासे in practice? अपि also? असमर्थः not capable? असि (thou) art? मत्कर्मपरमः intent on doing actions for My sake? भव be? मदर्थम् for My sake? अपि also? कर्माणि actions? कुर्वन् by doing? सिद्धिм perfection?" can be translated as:

"Can you practice (ABHYASA) without Yoga? Also, are you capable? You are (ASMI). I am not (ASMARTHAH). Intending to do actions for My sake, you shall attain perfection. Firstly, purity of mind, then Yoga (CONCENTRATION AND MEDITATION), then knowledge, and ultimately perfection (MOKSHA OR LIBERATION) shall be yours."

In this sentence, the following words are translated as:

* अभ्यासे (ABHYASA) - practice
* अपि (API) - also
* असमर्थः (ASMARTHAH) - not capable
* असि (ASI) - you (in the sense of "you are")
* मत्कर्मपरमः (MATKARMAPARAMOH) - intent on doing actions for My sake
* भव (BHAV) - be
* मदर्थम् (MADARTHAMS) - for My sake
* अपि (API) - also
* कर्माणि (KARMAANI) - actions
* कुर्वन् (KURVAN) - by doing
* सिद्धिम् (SIDDHIM) - perfection.

text: शौर्यं तेजो धृतिर्दाक्ष्यं युद्धे चाप्यपलायनम्।दानमीश्वरभावश्च क्षात्रं कर्म स्वभावजम्।।18.43।।
transliteration:
śhauryaṁ tejo dhṛitir dākṣhyaṁ yuddhe chāpy apalāyanam
dānam īśhvara-bhāvaśh cha kṣhātraṁ karma svabhāva-jam
word_meanings: śhauryam—valor; tejaḥ—strength; dhṛitiḥ—fortitude; dākṣhyam yuddhe—skill in weaponry; cha—and; api—also; apalāyanam—not fleeing; dānam—large-heartedness; īśhvara—leadership; bhāvaḥ—qualities; cha—and; kṣhātram—of the warrior and administrative class; karma—work; svabhāva-jam—born of one’s intrinsic qualities
translations: Prowess, splendor, firmness, dexterity, and not fleeing from battle, generosity, and lordliness are the duties of the Kshatriyas, born of their own nature.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence into English:

12.11 If thou art unable to perform actions for My sake, if thou canst not even be intent on My service, if thou art unable to practise the Bhagavata Dharmas, if thou wishest to do actions impelled by personal desires, then do thou perform them (for thy sake from a sense of duty) renouncing them all in Me and also abandon the fruits of all actions. At the same time, practise self-control. My Yoga is Surrendering all actions and their fruits to Me. The man of discrimination who has controlled all the senses, who has withdrawn the senses from sound, touch, form, taste, and smell, now performs the Yoga of renunciation of the fruits of actions in order to encourage the aspirants to practise this Yoga.

text: कृषिगौरक्ष्यवाणिज्यं वैश्यकर्म स्वभावजम्।परिचर्यात्मकं कर्म शूद्रस्यापि स्वभावजम्।।18.44।।
transliteration:
kṛiṣhi-gau-rakṣhya-vāṇijyaṁ vaiśhya-karma svabhāva-jam
paricharyātmakaṁ karma śhūdrasyāpi svabhāva-jam
word_meanings: kṛiṣhi—agriculture; gau-rakṣhya—dairy farming; vāṇijyam—commerce; vaiśhya—of the mercantile and farming class; karma—work; svabhāva-jam—born of one’s intrinsic qualities; paricharyā—serving through work; ātmakam—natural; karma—duty; śhūdrasya—of the worker class; api—and; svabhāva-jam—born of one’s intrinsic qualities
translations: Agriculture, cattle-rearing, and trade are the duties of the Vaisya (merchant), born of their own nature; and service is the duty of the Sudra (servant-class), born of their own nature.
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

"Theoretical or indirect knowledge of Brahman gained from scriptures is better than the practice accompanied by ignorance. Meditation is better than theoretical knowledge. Renunciation of the fruits of actions is better than meditation. Renunciation of the fruits of all actions as a means to attain supreme peace or Moksha is merely eulogized here to encourage Arjuna and other spiritual aspirants to practice Nishkama Karma Yoga, creating a strong desire in them to take up the yoga of selfless action. Desire is an enemy of peace; it causes restlessness of the mind and is the source of all human miseries, sorrows, and troubles. By stopping the play of desire through discrimination, dispassion, and inquiry into the nature of the Self, you will enjoy supreme peace. Renunciation of the fruits of actions is prescribed for the purification of the aspirant's heart; it annihilates desire, the enemy of wisdom. Even the sage renounces the fruits of actions; it has become natural to him."

text: स्वे स्वे कर्मण्यभिरतः संसिद्धिं लभते नरः।स्वकर्मनिरतः सिद्धिं यथा विन्दति तच्छृणु।।18.45।।
transliteration:
sve sve karmaṇy abhirataḥ sansiddhiṁ labhate naraḥ
sva-karma-nirataḥ siddhiṁ yathā vindati tach chhṛiṇu
word_meanings: sve sve—respectively; karmaṇi—work; abhirataḥ—fulfilling; sansiddhim—perfection; labhate—achieve; naraḥ—a person; sva-karma—to one’s own prescribed duty; nirataḥ—engaged; siddhim—perfection; yathā—as; vindati—attains; tat—that; śhṛiṇu—hear
translations: Being devoted to his own duty, one attains complete success. Hear how one devoted to their own duty achieves success.
commentaries:
The given sentence in Hindi can be translated into English as:

"The devotee who is established in God has no ill will towards any being. He looks upon all with love and compassion, regards all beings as himself, and does not even hate a single creature, not even one that causes him intense pain. The merciful devotee tries to alleviate the suffering of others and becomes one with them in their pain. Mercy is a divine attribute, and the Lord is all-merciful. To attain Godhead, one must also become all-merciful and offer full security of life to all beings. The perfect devotee has ecstatic vision and sees the Lord everywhere and in every creature."

text: यतः प्रवृत्तिर्भूतानां येन सर्वमिदं ततम्।स्वकर्मणा तमभ्यर्च्य सिद्धिं विन्दति मानवः।।18.46।।
transliteration:
yataḥ pravṛittir bhūtānāṁ yena sarvam idaṁ tatam
sva-karmaṇā tam abhyarchya siddhiṁ vindati mānavaḥ
word_meanings: yataḥ—from whom; pravṛittiḥ—have come into being; bhūtānām—of all living entities; yena—by whom; sarvam—all; idam—this; tatam—pervaded; sva-karmaṇā—by one’s natural occupation; tam—him; abhyarchya—by worshipping; siddhim—perfection; vindati—attains; mānavaḥ—a person
translations: ।।18.46।। जिस (परमात्मा) से भूतमात्र की प्रवृत्ति अर्थात् उत्पत्ति हुई है और जिससे यह सम्पूर्ण जगत् व्याप्त है, उस (परमात्मा) की स्वकर्म द्वारा पूजा करके मनुष्य सिद्धि को प्राप्त होता है।।
commentaries:
The sentence in English translation is:

"He knows that everything that comes to him is the result of his own actions in the past, and so he is always content. He does not strive for finite or perishable things, but fixes his mind and intellect on the Supreme Being or the Absolute. He experiences eternal satisfaction and stands firm like a rock amidst the changes of time. Contentment dwells forever in the heart of My devotee, like the ocean that is always full."

text: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्।स्वभावनियतं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम्।।18.47।।
transliteration:
śhreyān swa-dharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt sv-anuṣhṭhitāt
svabhāva-niyataṁ karma kurvan nāpnoti kilbiṣham
word_meanings: śhreyān—better; swa-dharmaḥ—one’s own prescribed occupational duty; viguṇaḥ—imperfectly done; para-dharmāt—than another’s dharma; su-anuṣhṭhitāt—perfectly done; svabhāva-niyatam—according to one’s innate nature; karma—duty; kurvan—by performing; na āpnoti—does not incur; kilbiṣham—sin
translations: Better is one's own prescribed duties, born of one's nature, even though it is devoid of excellence, than another's duty well executed; the doer of duty, dependent on one's own nature, does not incur sin.
commentaries:
The sentence "12.15 यस्मात् for whom? न not? उद्विजते is agitated? लोकः the world? लोकात् from the world? न not? उद्विजते is agitated? च and? यः who? हर्षामर्षभयोद्वेगैः by (from) joy? wrath? fear and anxiety? मुक्तः freed? यः who? सः he? च and? मे to Me?" can be translated into English as:

"For whom? Not for me? Is the sage agitated? The world? From the world? Not agitated? The sage is agitated? And? Who? Dear to Me."

Explanation:

* "यस्मात्" means "for whom?"
* "न न?" means "not for me?"
* "उद्विजते" means "the sage is agitated"
* "लोकः" means "the world"
* "लोकात्" means "from the world"
* "न न?" means "not agitated?"
* "च" means "and"
* "यः" means "who?"
* "हर्षामर्षभयोद्वेगैः" means "by (from) joy? wrath? fear and anxiety?"
* "मुक्तः" means "freed"
* "यः" means "who?"
* "सः" means "he?"
* "च" means "and?"
* "मे" means "to Me?"

The commentary provides additional information about the state of the sage or devotee, who is dear to the Lord. The sentence highlights the sage's detachment from worldly emotions and their focus on the Lord, despite being in the world.

text: सहजं कर्म कौन्तेय सदोषमपि न त्यजेत्।सर्वारम्भा हि दोषेण धूमेनाग्निरिवावृताः।।18.48।।
transliteration:
saha-jaṁ karma kaunteya sa-doṣham api na tyajet
sarvārambhā hi doṣheṇa dhūmenāgnir ivāvṛitāḥ
word_meanings: saha-jam—born of one’s nature; karma—duty; kaunteya—Arjun, the son of Kunti; sa-doṣham—with defects; api—even if; na tyajet—one should not abandon; sarva-ārambhāḥ—all endeavors; hi—indeed; doṣheṇa—with evil; dhūmena—with smoke; agniḥ—fire; iva—as; āvṛitāḥ—veiled
translations: One should not, O Arjuna, abandon the duty to which one is born, though it may be faulty; for, all undertakings are enveloped by evil, just as fire is by smoke.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the sentence:

"He who is free from desires is pure. He is skilled and swift in all actions. He is indifferent to the body, senses, and external connections. Inner purity is achieved by eliminating likes and dislikes, lust, anger, and jealousy. He is also cultivated in friendship towards others, compassion towards those who are inferior, and contentment towards superiors. He is free from pain and troubled by no one's actions. He renounces all actions aimed at securing pleasure in this world or the next. He has abandoned all personal and mental initiatives in actions. He allows the divine will to work through him, and he is very dear to Me."

text: असक्तबुद्धिः सर्वत्र जितात्मा विगतस्पृहः।नैष्कर्म्यसिद्धिं परमां संन्यासेनाधिगच्छति।।18.49।।
transliteration:
asakta-buddhiḥ sarvatra jitātmā vigata-spṛihaḥ
naiṣhkarmya-siddhiṁ paramāṁ sannyāsenādhigachchhati
word_meanings: asakta-buddhiḥ—those whose intellect is unattached; sarvatra—everywhere; jita-ātmā—who have mastered their mind; vigata-spṛihaḥ—free from desires; naiṣhkarmya-siddhim—state of actionlessness; paramām—highest; sanyāsena—by the practice of renunciation; adhigachchhati—attain
translations: He whose intellect is unattached everywhere, who has subdued his self, from whom desire has fled, he attains the supreme state of freedom from action through renunciation.
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

"Who is he? Does he not rejoice when he attains desirable objects? Does he not hate when he gets undesirable objects? Does he not grieve when he parts with his beloved objects? Does he not desire unattained objects? He who has renounced good and evil actions that produce pleasure and pain is a devotee of the Lord. Such a devotee or knower of Brahman, who is my own Self, is dear to me."

text: सिद्धिं प्राप्तो यथा ब्रह्म तथाप्नोति निबोध मे।समासेनैव कौन्तेय निष्ठा ज्ञानस्य या परा।।18.50।।
transliteration:
siddhiṁ prāpto yathā brahma tathāpnoti nibodha me
samāsenaiva kaunteya niṣhṭhā jñānasya yā parā
word_meanings: siddhim—perfection; prāptaḥ—attained; yathā—how; brahma—Brahman; tathā—also; āpnoti—attain; nibodha—hear; me—from me; samāsena—briefly; eva—indeed; kaunteya—Arjun, the son of Kunti; niṣhṭhā—firmly fixed; jñānasya—of knowledge; yā—which; parā—transcendental
translations: Learn from Me, O Arjuna, in brief how one who has attained perfection reaches Brahman—the Eternal, that supreme state of knowledge.
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

"He who is the same? To foe? And? In honour and dishonour? In cold and heat? In pleasure and pain? Samah the same? Sangavirivartah free from attachment."

text: बुद्ध्या विशुद्धया युक्तो धृत्याऽऽत्मानं नियम्य च।शब्दादीन् विषयांस्त्यक्त्वा रागद्वेषौ व्युदस्य च।।18.51।।
transliteration:
buddhyā viśhuddhayā yukto dhṛityātmānaṁ niyamya cha
śhabdādīn viṣhayāns tyaktvā rāga-dveṣhau vyudasya cha
word_meanings: buddhyā—intellect; viśhuddhayā—purified; yuktaḥ—endowed with; dhṛityā—by determination; ātmānam—the intellect; niyamya—restraining; cha—and; śhabda-ādīn viṣhayān—sound and other objects of the senses; tyaktvā—abandoning; rāga-dveṣhau—attachment and aversion; vyudasya—casting aside; cha—and;
translations: Guided always by pure reason, bravely restraining himself, renouncing the objects of sense and giving up attachment and hatred; he attains peace.
commentaries:
The sentence "12.19 तुल्यनिन्दास्तुतिः to whom censure and praise are eal? मौनी -- silent? सन्तुष्टः contented? येनकेनचित् with anything? अनिकेतः homeless? स्थिरमतिः steadyminded? भक्तिमान् full of devotion? मे to Me? प्रियः dear? नरः (that) man." can be translated into English as:

"To whom censure and praise are alike? Am I silent? Contented? With anything? Homeless? Steady-minded? Full of devotion? To Me? Dear? That man."

text: विविक्तसेवी लघ्वाशी यतवाक्कायमानसः।ध्यानयोगपरो नित्यं वैराग्यं समुपाश्रितः।।18.52।।
transliteration:
vivikta-sevī laghv-āśhī yata-vāk-kāya-mānasaḥ
dhyāna-yoga-paro nityaṁ vairāgyaṁ samupāśhritaḥ
word_meanings: vivikta-sevī—relishing solitude; laghu-āśhī—eating light; yata—controls; vāk—speech; kāya—body; mānasaḥ—and mind; dhyāna-yoga-paraḥ—engaged in meditation; nityam—always; vairāgyam—dispassion; samupāśhritaḥ—having taken shelter of;
translations: Enjoying solitude, being abstemious, having his body, mind, and speech under perfect control, and being absorbed in meditation, he becomes free—always filled with the spirit of renunciation.
commentaries:
The sentence "12.20 ये who? तु indeed? धर्म्यामृतम् immortal Dharma? इदम् this? यथोक्तम् as declared (above)? पर्युपासते follow? श्रद्दधानाः endowed with faith? मत्परमाः regarding Me as their Supreme? भक्ताः devotees? ते they? अतीव exceedingly? मे to Me? प्रियाः dear" has been translated as:

"Who are you? Indeed, this is the immortal Dharma. This? As declared above? Follow it and endow yourself with faith. Regarding Me as your Supreme Refuge, you devotees are exceedingly dear to Me."

text: अहङ्कारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं परिग्रहम्।विमुच्य निर्ममः शान्तो ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते।।18.53।।
transliteration:
ahankāraṁ balaṁ darpaṁ kāmaṁ krodhaṁ parigraham
vimuchya nirmamaḥ śhānto brahma-bhūyāya kalpate
word_meanings: ahankāram—egotism; balam—violence; darpam—arrogance; kāmam—desire; krodham—anger; parigraham—selfishness; vimuchya—being freed from; nirmamaḥ—without possessiveness of property; śhāntaḥ—peaceful; brahma-bhūyāya—union with Brahman; kalpate—is fit
translations: Relinquishing egotism, violence, pride, desire, wrath, and the sense of possession - he, the unselfish and calm one, is capable of becoming the Brahman.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"For the sake of blessing me, the highest? The secret? Called Adhyatma. Which one are you? By thee? Spoken word? That by which? Delusion? This? Gone my sin. After hearing the glories of the Lord? Arjuna has an intense longing to see the Cosmic Form with his own eyes. His bewilderment and delusion have now vanished. The vision of the Cosmic Form is not the ultimate goal, but rather one of many graded experiences. It's a terrible sight, so Arjuna stammers with fear, asking God to show him another form. Arjuna wishes to see God in his four-armed form, Lord of thousands of arms and forms infinite."

text: ब्रह्मभूतः प्रसन्नात्मा न शोचति न काङ्क्षति।समः सर्वेषु भूतेषु मद्भक्तिं लभते पराम्।।18.54।।
transliteration:
brahma-bhūtaḥ prasannātmā na śhochati na kāṅkṣhati
samaḥ sarveṣhu bhūteṣhu mad-bhaktiṁ labhate parām
word_meanings: brahma-bhūtaḥ—one situated in Brahman; prasanna-ātmā—mentally serene; na—neither; śhochati—grieving; na—nor; kāṅkṣhati—desiring; samaḥ—equitably disposed; sarveṣhu—toward all; bhūteṣhu—living beings; mat-bhaktim—devotion to me; labhate—attains; parām—supreme
translations: Having become the Brahman, the serene-minded one neither grieves nor rejoices; remaining equal to all beings, he gains the highest devotion to Me.
commentaries:
The sentence "11.2 भवाप्ययौ the origin and the dissolution? हि indeed? भूतानाम् of beings? श्रुतौ hav been heard? विस्तरशः in detail? मया by me? त्vatah from Thee? कमलपत्राक्ष O lotuseyed? माहात्म्यम् greatness? अπि also? च and? अव्ययम् inexhaustible." can be translated into English as:

"11.2 The origin and dissolution? Indeed? Of beings? What have been heard? In detail? By me? From Thee? O lotuseyed? Greatness? Also? And? Inexhaustible."

text: भक्त्या मामभिजानाति यावान्यश्चास्मि तत्त्वतः।ततो मां तत्त्वतो ज्ञात्वा विशते तदनन्तरम्।।18.55।।
transliteration:
bhaktyā mām abhijānāti yāvān yaśh chāsmi tattvataḥ
tato māṁ tattvato jñātvā viśhate tad-anantaram
word_meanings: bhaktyā—by loving devotion; mām—me; abhijānāti—one comes to know; yāvān—as much as; yaḥ cha asmi—as I am; tattvataḥ—in truth; tataḥ—then; mām—me; tattvataḥ—in truth; jñātvā—having known; viśhate—enters; tat-anantaram—thereafter
translations: Through devotion he comes to know of Me: Who I am and how, in fact, I am—having correctly known Me, he enters into Me. Then afterwards,
commentaries:
The translation of the sentence into English is:

"Is it thus? As Thou hast declared? O Supreme Lord, as Thou art. I desire to see Thy form as Isvara, O Supreme Person, with the form of Vishnu, possessing infinite knowledge, sovereignty, power, strength, prowess and splendor."

text: सर्वकर्माण्यपि सदा कुर्वाणो मद्व्यपाश्रयः।मत्प्रसादादवाप्नोति शाश्वतं पदमव्ययम्।।18.56।।
transliteration:
sarva-karmāṇy api sadā kurvāṇo mad-vyapāśhrayaḥ
mat-prasādād avāpnoti śhāśhvataṁ padam avyayam
word_meanings: sarva—all; karmāṇi—actions; api—though; sadā—always; kurvāṇaḥ—performing; mat-vyapāśhrayaḥ—take full refuge in me; mat-prasādāt—by my grace; avāpnoti—attain; śhāśhvatam—the eternal; padam—abode; avyayam—imperishable
translations: Ever engaging in all actions, one to whom I am the refuge, attains the eternal, immutable state through my grace.
commentaries:
Sure, here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"Thou thinkest? If? That? Is it possible? By me? Can you see? Thus? O Lord? O Lord of Yogins? Then? Me? Thou? Show? (Thy) Self? Imperishable."

text: चेतसा सर्वकर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्परः।बुद्धियोगमुपाश्रित्य मच्चित्तः सततं भव।।18.57।।
transliteration:
chetasā sarva-karmāṇi mayi sannyasya mat-paraḥ
buddhi-yogam upāśhritya mach-chittaḥ satataṁ bhava
word_meanings: chetasā—by consciousness; sarva-karmāṇi—every activity; mayi—to me; sannyasya—dedicating; mat-paraḥ—having me as the supreme goal; buddhi-yogam—having the intellect united with God; upāśhritya—taking shelter of; mat-chittaḥ—consciousness absorbed in me; satatam—always; bhava—be
translations: Surrender all your actions to Me with your mind, keep Me as your goal, and practice Buddhi-yoga, focusing your thoughts on Me always.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"Behold, My dear Arjuna, I want you to see the Cosmic Form. All beings and entities are present there, including the fat and lean, the short and tall, the red and black, the active and passive, the rich and poor, the intelligent and dull, the healthy and sick, the noisy and silent, those that are awake and those that are asleep, the beautiful and ugly, and all grades of beings with their distinctive marks. You will also see the objects of various shapes, such as the blueness of the sky, the yellowness of silk, the redness of twilight, the blackness of coal, the whiteness of snow, and the greenness of leaves."

text: मच्चित्तः सर्वदुर्गाणि मत्प्रसादात्तरिष्यसि।अथ चेत्त्वमहङ्कारान्न श्रोष्यसि विनङ्क्ष्यसि।।18.58।।
transliteration:
mach-chittaḥ sarva-durgāṇi mat-prasādāt tariṣhyasi
atha chet tvam ahankārān na śhroṣhyasi vinaṅkṣhyasi
word_meanings: mat-chittaḥ—by always remembering me; sarva—all; durgāṇi—obstacles; mat-prasādāt—by my grace; tariṣhyasi—you shall overcome; atha—but; chet—if; tvam—you; ahankārāt—due to pride; na śhroṣhyasi—do not listen; vinaṅkṣhyasi—you will perish
translations: Having your thought-organ turned towards Me, you shall pass over all obstacles by My Grace. On the other hand, if you don't give up your sense of ego, you will not liberate yourself; instead, you will perish.
commentaries: Behold, O Bharata, many wonders never seen before! 11.6 पश्य see? आश्चर्याणि wonders? The Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, and the Maruts have already been described in the previous chapter. But there are many other wonders that you have never seen before, neither have any other being in this world.

text: यदहङ्कारमाश्रित्य न योत्स्य इति मन्यसे।मिथ्यैष व्यवसायस्ते प्रकृतिस्त्वां नियोक्ष्यति।।18.59।।
transliteration:
yad ahankāram āśhritya na yotsya iti manyase
mithyaiṣha vyavasāyas te prakṛitis tvāṁ niyokṣhyati
word_meanings: yat—if; ahankāram—motivated by pride; āśhritya—taking shelter; na yotsye—I shall not fight; iti—thus; manyase—you think; mithyā eṣhaḥ—this is all false; vyavasāyaḥ—determination; te—your; prakṛitiḥ—material nature; tvām—you; niyokṣhyati—will engage
translations: If, filled with egoism, thou thinkest, "I will not fight," then thy resolve is vain; nature will compel thee.
commentaries:
