* श्रृणु (shrNu) - hear

मे of Me?

* मे (me) - of Me

भरतर्षभ O lord of the Bharatas?

* भरतर्षभ (bhRata-rShabha) - O lord of the Bharatas

अभ्यासात् from practice?

* अभ्यासात् (abhyAsaM) - from practice

रमते rejoices?

* रमते (ramate) - rejoices

यत्r in which?

* यत्र (yatR) - in which

दुःखान्तम् the end of pain?

* दुःखान्तम् (duhkha-antam) - the end of pain

च and?

* च (ca) - and

निगच्छति (he) attains to.

* निगच्छति (niGacchati) - he attains to

text:
तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर।

असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः।।3.19।।
transliteration:
tasmād asaktaḥ satataṁ kāryaṁ karma samāchara
asakto hyācharan karma param āpnoti pūruṣhaḥ
word_meanings: tasmāt—therefore; asaktaḥ—without attachment; satatam—constantly; kāryam—duty; karma—action; samāchara—perform; asaktaḥ—unattached; hi—certainly; ācharan—performing; karma—work; param—the Supreme; āpnoti—attains; pūruṣhaḥ—a person
translations: ।।3.19।। इसलिये तू निरन्तर आसक्तिरहित होकर कर्तव्य-कर्मका भलीभाँति आचरण कर; क्योंकि आसक्तिरहित होकर कर्म करता हुआ मनुष्य परमात्माको प्राप्त हो जाता है।
commentaries:
18.37 यत् that?
तत् that?
अग्रे at first?
विषम् poison?
इव like?
परिणामे in the end?
अमृतोपमम् like nectar?
तत् that?
सुखम् pleasure?
सात्त्विकam Sattvic?
प्रोक्तम् is declared (to be)?
आत्मबुद्धिप्रसादजम् born of the purity of ones own mind due to Self-realization.

text:
कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः।

लोकसंग्रहमेवापि संपश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि।।3.20।।
transliteration:
karmaṇaiva hi sansiddhim āsthitā janakādayaḥ
loka-saṅgraham evāpi sampaśhyan kartum arhasi
word_meanings: karmaṇā—by the performance of prescribed duties; eva—only; hi—certainly; sansiddhim—perfection; āsthitāḥ—attained; janaka-ādayaḥ—King Janak and other kings; loka-saṅgraham—for the welfare of the masses; eva api—only; sampaśhyan—considering; kartum—to perform; arhasi—you should;
translations: ।।3.20।। राजा जनक-जैसे अनेक महापुरुष भी कर्मके द्वारा ही परमसिद्धिको प्राप्त हुए हैं। इसलिये लोकसंग्रहको देखते हुए भी तू (निष्कामभावसे) कर्म करनेके योग्य है।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given Hindi sentence into English:

"What is the result of the contact of the senses with objects? Is it happiness or fear? At first, it may seem like nectar, but in the end, it's poison. Indulging in sensual pleasures can lead to pleasure, but it's mixed with pain and fear. Attachment to these pleasures is death, and it brings one back to this world of death again and again. Fear and attachment coexist with sensual pleasure, and one has to exert a lot to obtain money to buy the objects that give them pleasure. However, through this indulgence, one commits many sinful acts and suffers in hell. The next birth will be of a low nature, and one loses their strength, vigor, wealth, and energy. Moreover, their intellect becomes dull, weak, impure, turbid, and perverted. Ultimately, they lose their money and proper understanding."

text:
यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः।

स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते।।3.21।।
transliteration:
yad yad ācharati śhreṣhṭhas tat tad evetaro janaḥ
sa yat pramāṇaṁ kurute lokas tad anuvartate
word_meanings: yat yat—whatever; ācharati—does; śhreṣhṭhaḥ—the best; tat tat—that (alone); eva—certainly; itaraḥ—common; janaḥ—people; saḥ—they; yat—whichever; pramāṇam—standard; kurute—perform; lokaḥ—world; tat—that; anuvartate—pursues
translations: ।।3.21।। श्रेष्ठ मनुष्य जो-जो आचरण करता है, दूसरे मनुष्य वैसा-वैसा ही आचरण करते हैं। वह जो कुछ प्रमाण  देता है,  दूसरे मनुष्य उसीके अनुसार आचरण करते हैं।
commentaries:
18.39 यत् which? अग्रे at first? च and? अनुबन्धे in the seel? च and? सुखम् pleasure? मोहनम् delusive? आत्मनः of the self? निद्रालस्यप्रमादोत्थम् arising from sleep? indolence and heedlessness? तत् that? तामसम् Tamasic? उदाहृतम् is declared.

The sentence can be translated to English as:

"What is it? At first, agra (anger) arises? And again, in the self (atman)? Pleasure? Moohanam (delusive)? Atmanam (of the self)? Nidra (sleep) and heedlessness? That? Tama (Tamasic)? Udahritam (is declared)."

Note: Tamasic refers to something that is dark, inert, or unconscious. In this context, it seems to be used to describe the nature of pleasure arising from evil habits like drinking and eating worthless things, which leads to delusion and heedlessness.

text:
न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किञ्चन।

नानवाप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि।।3.22।।
transliteration:
na me pārthāsti kartavyaṁ triṣhu lokeṣhu kiñchana
nānavāptam avāptavyaṁ varta eva cha karmaṇi
word_meanings: na—not; me—mine; pārtha—Arjun; asti—is; kartavyam—duty; triṣhu—in the three; lokeṣhu—worlds; kiñchana—any; na—not; anavāptam—to be attained; avāptavyam—to be gained; varte—I am engaged; eva—yet; cha—also; karmaṇi—in prescribed duties
translations: ।।3.22।। हे पार्थ! मुझे तीनों लोकोंमें न तो कुछ कर्तव्य है और न कोई प्राप्त करनेयोग्य वस्तु अप्राप्त है, फिर भी मैं कर्तव्यकर्ममें ही लगा रहता हूँ।
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

Everything in the universe, including mortals and deities, is bound by the three alities of Nature - matter (Prakriti), birth (Mukta), and growth (Gunatraya). The threads of matter weave the fabric of creation, just as the three Gunas shape the world we live in. Ignorance keeps the wheel of Samsara spinning, but a liberated sage can break free from the cycle by transcending the three Gunas and resting in their own divine nature as Existence-Knowledge-Bliss Absolute.

text:
यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः।

मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः।।3.23।।
transliteration:
yadi hyahaṁ na varteyaṁ jātu karmaṇyatandritaḥ
mama vartmānuvartante manuṣhyāḥ pārtha sarvaśhaḥ
word_meanings: yadi—if; hi—certainly; aham—I; na—not; varteyam—thus engage; jātu—ever; karmaṇi—in the performance of prescribed duties; atandritaḥ—carefully; mama—my; vartma—path; anuvartante—follow; manuṣhyāḥ—all men; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; sarvaśhaḥ—in all respects
translations: ।।3.23 -- 3.24।।  हे पार्थ! अगर मैं किसी समय सावधान होकर कर्तव्यकर्म न करूँ तो बड़ी हानि हो जाय; क्योंकि मनुष्य सब प्रकारसे मेरे ही मार्गका अनुसरण करते हैं। यदि मैं कर्म न करूँ, तो ये सब मनुष्य नष्ट-भ्रष्ट हो जायँ और मैं वर्णसंकरताको करनेवाला होऊँ तथा इस समस्त प्रजाको नष्ट करनेवाला बनूँ।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"The Brahmanas, Kshatriyas, and Vaisyas are classified according to their natural tendencies (Gunas), which are distributed among them. The Sudras have no claim to the Vedic rites because their profession is to serve the members of the first three castes. There is an organization of humanity into four castes, and each person's life is divided into four stages based on their natural tendencies. By means of these Gunas, individuals can free themselves from the cycle of birth and death and attain Self-realization or knowledge of the Self. Passion (Rajas) mixed with Tamas causes the growth of the merchant caste (Vaisya). Rajas mixed with Tamas is the cause of the appearance of the Sudra. The one human race has been divided into four castes based on the three Gunas, and duties are assigned to each according to their natural tendencies."

text:
उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम्।

सङ्करस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमाः प्रजाः।।3.24।।
transliteration:
utsīdeyur ime lokā na kuryāṁ karma ched aham
sankarasya cha kartā syām upahanyām imāḥ prajāḥ
word_meanings: utsīdeyuḥ—would perish; ime—all these; lokāḥ—worlds; na—not; kuryām—I perform; karma—prescribed duties; chet—if; aham—I; sankarasya—of uncultured population; cha—and; kartā—responsible; syām—would be; upahanyām—would destroy; imāḥ—all these; prajāḥ—living entities
translations: These worlds would be ruined if I did not perform action. And I shall become the agent of intermingling (of castes), and shall be destroying these beings.
commentaries:
The sentence "18.42 शमः serenity? दमः selfrestraint? तपः austerity? शौचम् purity? क्षान्तिः forgiveness? आर्जवam् uprightness? एव even? च and? ज्ञानम् knowledge? विज्ञानम् realisation? आस्तिक्यam् belief in God? ब्रह्मकर्म (are) the duties of Brahmanas?" can be translated directly into English as:

"18.42 Serenity? Selfrestraint? Austerity? Purity? Forgiveness? Uprightness? Even? Knowledge? Realization? Belief in God? The duties of Brahmanas (are)?"

text:
सक्ताः कर्मण्यविद्वांसो यथा कुर्वन्ति भारत।

कुर्याद्विद्वांस्तथासक्तश्िचकीर्षुर्लोकसंग्रहम्।।3.25।।
transliteration:
saktāḥ karmaṇyavidvānso yathā kurvanti bhārata
kuryād vidvāns tathāsaktaśh chikīrṣhur loka-saṅgraham
word_meanings: saktāḥ—attached; karmaṇi—duties; avidvānsaḥ—the ignorant; yathā—as much as; kurvanti—act; bhārata—scion of Bharat (Arjun); kuryāt—should do; vidvān—the wise; tathā—thus; asaktaḥ—unattached; chikīrṣhuḥ—wishing; loka-saṅgraham—welfare of the world
translations: ।।3.25 -- 3.26।। हे भरतवंशोद्भव अर्जुन! कर्ममें आसक्त हुए अज्ञानीजन जिस प्रकार कर्म करते हैं, आसक्तिरहित विद्वान भी लोकसंग्रह करना चाहता हुआ उसी प्रकार कर्म करे।  तत्त्वज्ञ महापुरुष कर्मोंमें आसक्तिवाले अज्ञानी मनुष्योंकी बुद्धिमें भ्रम उत्पन्न न करे, प्रत्युत स्वयं समस्त कर्मोंको अच्छी तरहसे करता हुआ उनसे भी वैसे ही करवाये।
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

18.43 prowess? splendor? firmness? dexterity? in battle? also? not fleeing? generosity? lordship? of Kshatriyas? action? born of nature.

text:
न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम्।

जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान् युक्तः समाचरन्।।3.26।।
transliteration:
na buddhi-bhedaṁ janayed ajñānāṁ karma-saṅginām
joṣhayet sarva-karmāṇi vidvān yuktaḥ samācharan
word_meanings: na—not; buddhi-bhedam—discord in the intellects; janayet—should create; ajñānām—of the ignorant; karma-saṅginām—who are attached to fruitive actions; joṣhayet—should inspire (them) to perform; sarva—all; karmāṇi—prescribed; vidvān—the wise; yuktaḥ—enlightened; samācharan—performing properly
translations: The enlightened man should not disturb the beliefs of the ignorant, who are attached to work. He should remain diligent himself and make them perform all their duties.
commentaries:
18.44 कृषिगौरक्ष्यवाणिज्यम् agriculture?
Agriculture is the duty of the Vaishya caste.

वैश्यकर्म the duties of Vaisya?
The duties of the Vaisya caste include trade and commerce.

स्वभावजम् born of nature?
Each person is born with their own natural abilities and tendencies, regardless of their caste or class.

परिचर्यात्मकम् consisting of service?
The concept of "service" is an integral part of the Hindu system of social hierarchy, with each caste having specific duties and responsibilities.

कर्म action?
Action or work is a key aspect of the Hindu system of social hierarchy, as each person is expected to perform their duty according to their caste or class.

शूद्रस्य of the Sudra?
The Sudra caste is considered the lowest of the four castes in the Hindu social hierarchy, and their duties include serving and assisting the other three castes.

अपि also?
Yes, also.

स्वभावजम् born of nature?
Each person is born with their own natural abilities and tendencies, regardless of their caste or class.

Commentary:
The Apastamba Dharma Sutra declares that men of various castes and orders each devoted to his respective duties reap the fruits of their actions after death and then by the residual Karma attain to births in superior Dharma, span of life, learning, conduct, wealth, happiness and intelligence (2?2?2?3). There is a vivid description in the Puranas also of the different results and worlds which men of the four castes and orders obtain by discharging their respective duties.

text:
प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः।

अहङ्कारविमूढात्मा कर्ताऽहमिति मन्यते।।3.27।।
transliteration:
prakṛiteḥ kriyamāṇāni guṇaiḥ karmāṇi sarvaśhaḥ
ahankāra-vimūḍhātmā kartāham iti manyate
word_meanings: prakṛiteḥ—of material nature; kriyamāṇāni—carried out; guṇaiḥ—by the three modes; karmāṇi—activities; sarvaśhaḥ—all kinds of; ahankāra-vimūḍha-ātmā—those who are bewildered by the ego and misidentify themselves with the body; kartā—the doer; aham—I; iti—thus; manyate—thinks
translations: ।।3.27।। सम्पूर्ण कर्म सब प्रकारसे प्रकृतिके गुणोंद्वारा किये जाते हैं; परन्तु अहंकारसे मोहित अन्तःकरणवाला अज्ञानी मनुष्य 'मैं कर्ता हूँ' -- ऐसा मानता है।
commentaries:
18.45 स्वे in own?
Sure! Here's the translation of the sentence:

18.45 In one's own?

कर्मणि to duty?
Duty?
अभिरतः devoted?
Devoted?
संसिद्धिम् perfection?
Perfection?
लभते attains?
Attains?
नरः a man?
A man?
स्वकर्मनिरतः engaged in his own duty?
Engaged in one's own duty?
सिद्धिम् perfection?
Perfection?
यथा how?
How?
विन्दति finds?
Finds?
तत् that?
That?
श्रृणु hear.
Listen.

text:
तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः।

गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्त इति मत्वा न सज्जते।।3.28।।
transliteration:
tattva-vit tu mahā-bāho guṇa-karma-vibhāgayoḥ
guṇā guṇeṣhu vartanta iti matvā na sajjate
word_meanings: tattva-vit—the knower of the Truth; tu—but; mahā-bāho—mighty-armed one; guṇa-karma—from guṇas and karma; vibhāgayoḥ—distinguish; guṇāḥ—modes of material nature in the shape of the senses, mind, etc; guṇeṣhu—modes of material nature in the shape of objects of perception; vartante—are engaged; iti—thus; matvā—knowing; na—never; sajjate—becomes attached
translations: But he who knows the Truth, O mighty-armed Arjuna, about the divisions of the qualities and their functions, knowing that the Gunas, as senses, move amidst the Gunas, as the sense-objects, is not attached.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"From whom is the evolution? The beings are pervaded by Him. By whom is this performed? All is pervaded by Him. This is carried out with His own duty. He is worshipped with flowers of action, and as a result, He grants dispassion and discrimination. Evolution proceeds from the Lord, the Inner Ruler. Beings are living creatures. Each person performs their own duty according to their caste, and through worshiping the Lord, they attain perfection and become eligible for the dawn of Self-knowledge (for Jnana Yoga)."

text:
प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु।

तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत्।।3.29।।
transliteration:
prakṛiter guṇa-sammūḍhāḥ sajjante guṇa-karmasu
tān akṛitsna-vido mandān kṛitsna-vin na vichālayet
word_meanings: prakṛiteḥ—of material nature; guṇa—by the modes of material nature; sammūḍhāḥ—deluded; sajjante—become attached; guṇa-karmasu—to results of actions; tān—those; akṛitsna-vidaḥ—persons without knowledge; mandān—the ignorant; kṛitsna-vit—persons with knowledge; na vichālayet—should not unsettle
translations: Men, completely deluded by the strands of Prakrti, are attached to the actions of those strands. Those who know fully should not confuse them, whereas the dullards who do not know fully.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"18.47 better? Ones own duty? Destitute of merits? That (the duty) of another? Well performed? Ordained by his own nature? Action? Doing? Not incurring sin? Just as a poisonous substance does not harm the worm born in that substance, so he who does his Svadharma (the duty ordained according to his own nature) does not incur any sin. What is poison to the whole world is sweet to a worm and yet sugarcane juice that is sweet causes its death. So a man's appointed duty which frees him from bondage must therefore be practiced however difficult it may seem. If you try to do the duty of another, it will bring danger. He who has no knowledge of the Self cannot remain even for a moment without doing action."

text:
मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा।

निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः।।3.30।।
transliteration:
mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi sannyasyādhyātma-chetasā
nirāśhīr nirmamo bhūtvā yudhyasva vigata-jvaraḥ
word_meanings: mayi—unto me; sarvāṇi—all; karmāṇi—works; sannyasya—renouncing completely; adhyātma-chetasā—with the thoughts resting on God; nirāśhīḥ—free from hankering for the results of the actions; nirmamaḥ—without ownership; bhūtvā—so being; yudhyasva—fight; vigata-jvaraḥ—without mental fever
translations: ।।3.30।। तू विवेकवती बुद्धिके द्वारा सम्पूर्ण कर्तव्य-कर्मोंको मेरे अर्पण करके कामना, ममता और संताप-रहित होकर युद्धरूप कर्तव्य-कर्मको कर।
commentaries:
The sentence "18.48 सहजम् which is born?" can be translated to English as:

"Born with oneself born with the birth of man."

text:
ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः।

श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्ते तेऽपि कर्मभिः।।3.31।।
transliteration:
ye me matam idaṁ nityam anutiṣhṭhanti mānavāḥ
śhraddhāvanto ’nasūyanto muchyante te ’pi karmabhiḥ
word_meanings: ye—who; me—my; matam—teachings; idam—these; nityam—constantly; anutiṣhṭhanti—abide by; mānavāḥ—human beings; śhraddhā-vantaḥ—with profound faith; anasūyantaḥ—free from cavilling; muchyante—become free; te—those; api—also; karmabhiḥ—from the bondage of karma
translations: ।।3.31।। जो मनुष्य दोष-दृष्टिसे रहित होकर श्रद्धापूर्वक मेरे इस (पूर्वश्लोकमें वर्णित) मतका सदा अनुसरण करते हैं, वे भी कर्मोंके बन्धनसे मुक्त हो जाते हैं।
commentaries: The sentence "18.49 असक्तबुद्धिः whose intellect is unattached?" translates to "Who has an unattached intellect?" in English.

text:
ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम्।

सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः।।3.32।।
transliteration:
ye tvetad abhyasūyanto nānutiṣhṭhanti me matam
sarva-jñāna-vimūḍhāns tān viddhi naṣhṭān achetasaḥ
word_meanings: ye—those; tu—but; etat—this; abhyasūyantaḥ—cavilling; na—not; anutiṣhṭhanti—follow; me—my; matam—teachings; sarva-jñāna—in all types of knowledge; vimūḍhān—deluded; tān—they are; viddhi—know; naṣhṭān—ruined; achetasaḥ—devoid of discrimination
translations: ।।3.32।। परन्तु जो मनुष्य मेरे इस मतमें दोष-दृष्टि करते हुए इसका अनुष्ठान नहीं करते, उन सम्पूर्ण ज्ञानोंमें मोहित और अविवेकी मनुष्योंको नष्ट हुए ही समझो।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence into English:

"When a man has the good fortune to hear wise words from a teacher, dualism and egoism disappear, and his mind rests in union with the Supreme Being. No further action is required for such a man. He has become a Kritakritya (a person of total fulfillment or one who has done everything there is to do). The aspirant receives the Lord's grace by worshiping Him with their proper duty. The Lord gives them dispassion, discrimination, and devotion to knowledge. The Lord removes the veil of ignorance. With love and compassion, I will describe the Yoga of discrimination by which they come to Me. Out of My own compassion, I dwell within their Self and destroy the darkness born of ignorance with the luminous lamp of knowledge."

Note: The translation is done directly without any mistranslation or interpretation.

text:
सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि।

प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति।।3.33।।
transliteration:
sadṛiśhaṁ cheṣhṭate svasyāḥ prakṛiter jñānavān api
prakṛitiṁ yānti bhūtāni nigrahaḥ kiṁ kariṣhyati
word_meanings: sadṛiśham—accordingly; cheṣhṭate—act; svasyāḥ—by their own; prakṛiteḥ—modes of nature; jñāna-vān—the wise; api—even; prakṛitim—nature; yānti—follow; bhūtāni—all living beings; nigrahaḥ—repression; kim—what; kariṣhyati—will do
translations: ।।3.33।। सम्पूर्ण प्राणी प्रकृतिको प्राप्त होते हैं। ज्ञानी महापुरुष भी अपनी प्रकृतिके अनुसार चेष्टा करता है। फिर इसमें किसीका हठ क्या करेगा?
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

The lower self should be controlled with firmness by the Self of pure intellect. The turbulent senses and mind should be subdued with the help of pure intellect or reason. Pure reason is a great power. Whenever senses raise their heads and hiss, they should be hammered by the powerful rod of pure intellect or reason. Reason is the faculty of determination.
Pure intellect is like a clear mirror. A pure intellect is Brahman itself. It can be easily merged in Brahman. When pure intellect merges in Brahman, the reflected intelligence, Chidabhasa or Jiva, is also absorbed in Brahman. The Jiva becomes identical with Brahman, just as ether in the pot becomes one with universal ether when pot is broken.
The self is the aggregate of body and senses.
Through repeated practice of Pratyahara (abstraction) and Dama (self-restraint), the aspirant withdraws senses from their respective objects again and again. Gradually, senses are fixed in the Self. Their outgoing tendencies are totally curbed. The aspirant attains supreme control of senses through constant meditation, by practicing dispassion, he conquers Raga (attachment), and through practice of pure love or cosmic love or divine Prem, he conquers hatred. He abandons all luxuries and keeps only those objects necessary for bare maintenance of body. He has neither attachment nor hatred even for those objects.

text:
इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ।

तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ।।3.34।।
transliteration:
indriyasyendriyasyārthe rāga-dveṣhau vyavasthitau
tayor na vaśham āgachchhet tau hyasya paripanthinau
word_meanings: indriyasya—of the senses; indriyasya arthe—in the sense objects; rāga—attachment; dveṣhau—aversion; vyavasthitau—situated; tayoḥ—of them; na—never; vaśham—be controlled; āgachchhet—should become; tau—those; hi—certainly; asya—for him; paripanthinau—foes
translations: ।।3.34।। इन्द्रिय-इन्द्रियके अर्थमें (प्रत्येक इन्द्रियके प्रत्येक विषयमें) मनुष्यके राग और द्वेष व्यवस्थासे (अनुकूलता और प्रतिकूलताको लेकर) स्थित हैं। मनुष्यको उन दोनोंके वशमें नहीं होना चाहिये; क्योंकि वे दोनों ही इसके (पारमार्थिक मार्गमें विघ्न डालनेवाले) शत्रु हैं।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"Solitude has its own charms. The spiritual vibrations in solitude are wonderfully elevating. Meditation will come by itself without exertion. All saints and sages who have attained Self-realization have remained in solitude for a number of years. You can enjoy the peace of solitude during the Christmas and Easter holidays. It is necessary to live in solitude for at least a month or a fortnight every year for householders. Instead of wasting time, energy, and money in Calcutta or any other city, live in holy places like Rishikesh, Uttarakasi, or Naimisaranya by doing intense and systematic spiritual practices or Japa of a Mantra and attain immortality. If you once taste the bliss of solitude, you will never forget it. Eat to live, eat in moderation, and have a light body and light, cheerful, and serene mind. Observe Mauna or the vow of silence for a week or a month, practice Ahimsa and Brahmacharya, meditate on the Self or on the Lord Hari with four hands, Lord Krishna, Rama, or Siva, be regular in your meditation, and gradually increase the period of meditation from 15 minutes to 3 or 6 hours at a sitting. If you are a whole-time aspirant, spend the whole time in meditation. Watch the mind and cultivate dispassion. Energy will leak out through the senses if you are careless and non-vigilant. Dispassion is indifference to sensual enjoyments here and hereafter, absence of desire for visible and invisible objects. You must have steady, lasting, and sustained dispassion. It should not wane. It should be a constant attitude of the mind."

text:
श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्।

स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः।।3.35।।
transliteration:
śhreyān swa-dharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt sv-anuṣhṭhitāt
swa-dharme nidhanaṁ śhreyaḥ para-dharmo bhayāvahaḥ
word_meanings: śhreyān—better; swa-dharmaḥ—personal duty; viguṇaḥ—tinged with faults; para-dharmāt—than another’s prescribed duties; su-anuṣhṭhitāt—perfectly done; swa-dharme—in one’s personal duties; nidhanam—death; śhreyaḥ—better; para-dharmaḥ—duties prescribed for others; bhaya-āvahaḥ—fraught with fear
translations: ।।3.35।। अच्छी तरह आचरणमें लाये हुए दूसरेके धर्मसे गुणोंकी कमीवाला अपना धर्म श्रेष्ठ है। अपने धर्ममें तो मरना भी कल्याणकारक है और दूसरेका धर्म भयको देनेवाला है।
commentaries:
18.53 अहङ्कारम् = Egoism
बलम् = Strength
दर्पam् = Arrogance
कामम् = Desire
क्रोधam् = Anger
परिग्रहम् = Covetousness
विमुच्य = Having abandoned
निर्ममः = Without mineness
शान्तः = Peaceful
ब्रह्मभूयाय = For becoming Brahman
कल्पते (he) is fit.

text:
अर्जुन उवाच

अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयं पापं चरति पूरुषः।

अनिच्छन्नपि वार्ष्णेय बलादिव नियोजितः।।3.36।।
transliteration:
arjuna uvācha
atha kena prayukto ’yaṁ pāpaṁ charati pūruṣhaḥ
anichchhann api vārṣhṇeya balād iva niyojitaḥ
word_meanings: arjunaḥ uvācha—Arjun said; atha—then; kena—by what; prayuktaḥ—impelled; ayam—one; pāpam—sins; charati—commit; pūruṣhaḥ—a person; anichchhan—unwillingly; api—even; vārṣhṇeya—he who belongs to the Vrishni clan, Shree Krishna; balāt—by force; iva—as if; niyojitaḥ—engaged
translations: ।।3.36।। अर्जुन ने कहा -- हे वार्ष्णेय ! फिर यह पुरुष बलपूर्वक बाध्य किये हुये के समान अनिच्छा होते हुये भी किसके द्वारा प्रेरित होकर पाप का आचरण करता है?
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

"Having attained Brahman, he is tranquil-minded. He neither grieves nor desires. When this state is attained, the multiplicity of objects disappears and he perceives unity everywhere. The waking and dream consciousness that gives rise to false knowledge passes away. He does not grieve about his bodily needs, neither in success nor failure. He puts himself in the position of others and feels their pain. His heart is tender and soft, and he is extremely compassionate and merciful. He considers the pleasure and pain of all beings as his own. All barriers that separate man from man, such as jealousy, narrow-mindedness, prejudices, and dislike for others, vanish completely. He has cosmic love and is a cosmic benefactor. He is the friend of all. This state of expansion is beyond description, and one has to experience it for oneself. Such a devotee or aspirant attains supreme devotion to Me, which is the fourth or highest of the four kinds of devotion mentioned in verse 16 of chapter VII, namely devotion of knowledge of the wise man."

text:
श्री भगवानुवाच

काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः।

महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम्।।3.37।।
transliteration:
śhrī bhagavān uvācha
kāma eṣha krodha eṣha rajo-guṇa-samudbhavaḥ
mahāśhano mahā-pāpmā viddhyenam iha vairiṇam
word_meanings: śhri-bhagavān uvācha—the Supreme Lord said; kāmaḥ—desire; eṣhaḥ—this; krodhaḥ—wrath; eṣhaḥ—this; rajaḥ-guṇa—the mode of passion; samudbhavaḥ—born of; mahā-aśhanaḥ—all-devouring; mahā-pāpmā—greatly sinful; viddhi—know; enam—this; iha—in the material world; vairiṇam—the enemy
translations: ।।3.37।। श्रीभगवान् बोले - रजोगुणसे उत्पन्न हुआ  यह काम ही क्रोध  है। यह बहुत खानेवाला और महापापी है। इस विषयमें तू इसको ही वैरी जान।
commentaries:
The sentence "18.55 भक्त्या by devotion? माम् Me? अभिजानाति (he) knows? यावान् what? यः who? च and? अस्मि (I) am? तत्त्वतः in truth? ततः then? माम् Me? तत्त्वतः in truth? ज्ञात्वा having known? विशते (he) enters? तत् that? अनन्तरम् afterwards." has been translated into English as follows:

"My devotee, O Arjuna, who has attained union with Me through single-minded and unflinching devotion is truly My very Self. Devotion culminates in knowledge. Devotion begins with two and ends in one. ParaBhakti (supreme devotion) and Jnana are one. Devotion is the mother, Knowledge is the son. By devotion, he knows that I am all-pervading pure consciousness, unborn, immutable, and self-luminous. He knows that I am devoid of all the differences caused by limiting adjuncts. He knows that I am the support, source, womb, basis, and substratum of everything. He knows that I am the ruler of all beings, the controller of Maya, and that this world is a mere appearance. Thus, knowing Me in truth or essence, he enters into Me soon after attaining Self-knowledge."

In summary, the sentence is discussing the idea that through devotion and self-inquiry, one can attain union with the ultimate reality, which is described as being beyond all limitations and duality. The text uses various metaphors and analogies to convey this idea, but ultimately, it is up to the individual to realize the Self through direct experience.

text:
धूमेनाव्रियते वह्निर्यथाऽऽदर्शो मलेन च।

यथोल्बेनावृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम्।।3.38।।
transliteration:
dhūmenāvriyate vahnir yathādarśho malena cha
yatholbenāvṛito garbhas tathā tenedam āvṛitam
word_meanings: dhūmena—by smoke; āvriyate—is covered; vahniḥ—fire; yathā—just as; ādarśhaḥ—mirror; malena—by dust; cha—also; yathā—just as; ulbena—by the womb; āvṛitaḥ—is covered; garbhaḥ—embryo; tathā—similarly; tena—by that (desire); idam—this; āvṛitam—is covered
translations: ।।3.38।। जैसे धुएँसे अग्नि और मैलसे दर्पण ढक जाता है तथा जैसे जेरसे गर्भ ढका रहता है, ऐसे ही उस कामके द्वारा यह ज्ञान ( विवेक) ढका हुआ है।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"All actions (18.56) are Mine, also (always)? Doing? Taking refuge in Me? By My grace? Obtains? The eternal (Brahmic seat of ineffable splendour)? State or abode? Indestructible."

text:
आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा।

कामरूपेण कौन्तेय दुष्पूरेणानलेन च।।3.39।।
transliteration:
āvṛitaṁ jñānam etena jñānino nitya-vairiṇā
kāma-rūpeṇa kaunteya duṣhpūreṇānalena cha
word_meanings: āvṛitam—covered; jñānam—knowledge; etena—by this; jñāninaḥ—of the wise; nitya-vairiṇā—by the perpetual enemy; kāma-rūpeṇa—in the form of desires; kaunteya—Arjun the son of Kunti; duṣhpūreṇa—insatiable; analena—like fire; cha—and
translations: ।।3.39।। और हे कुन्तीनन्दन ! इस अग्निके समान कभी तृप्त न होनेवाले और विवेकियोंके नित्य वैरी इस कामके द्वारा मनुष्यका विवेक ढका हुआ है।
commentaries:
Sure, here is the translation of the sentence you provided:

"Mentally, with the discriminative faith that knowledge finally leads to liberation when the heart is purified through selfless works done with the spirit of offering to God, surrender all actions to Me. All actions, producing visible and invisible results, do thou dedicate to Me. Take Me, Vaasudeva, as the supreme goal, and His whole self centered in Me. Resorting to Buddhi Yoga as thy sole refuge, steadymindedness."

text:
इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते।

एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम्।।3.40।।
transliteration:
indriyāṇi mano buddhir asyādhiṣhṭhānam uchyate
etair vimohayatyeṣha jñānam āvṛitya dehinam
word_meanings: indriyāṇi—the senses; manaḥ—the mind; buddhiḥ—the intellect; asya—of this; adhiṣhṭhānam—dwelling place; uchyate—are said to be; etaiḥ—by these; vimohayati—deludes; eṣhaḥ—this; jñānam—knowledge; āvṛitya—clouds; dehinam—the embodied soul
translations: The organs, mind, and intellect are said to be its abode. This one diversely deludes the embodied being, veiling Knowledge with the help of these.
commentaries:
Sure, here is the translation of the sentence:

"By fixing your mind on Me, you will overcome all obstacles through My grace. But if you don't take My teaching to heart and become proud, you will be ruined."

text:
तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ।

पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम्।।3.41।।
transliteration:
tasmāt tvam indriyāṇyādau niyamya bharatarṣhabha
pāpmānaṁ prajahi hyenaṁ jñāna-vijñāna-nāśhanam
word_meanings: tasmāt—therefore; tvam—you; indriyāṇi—senses; ādau—in the very beginning; niyamya—having controlled; bharata-ṛiṣhabha—Arjun, the best of the Bharatas; pāpmānam—the sinful; prajahi—slay; hi—certainly; enam—this; jñāna—knowledge; vijñāna—realization; nāśhanam—the destroyer
translations: ।।3.41।। इसलिये हे भरतवंशियोंमें श्रेष्ठ अर्जुन ! तू सबसे पहले इन्द्रियोंको वशमें करके इस ज्ञान और विज्ञानका नाश करनेवाले महान् पापी कामको अवश्य ही बलपूर्वक मार डाल।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"18.59 What is egoism? Having taken refuge in what? Not? I will fight thus. Thou thinkest it vain. This (thou) is this? Resolve it. Thy nature will constrain thee. Thy nature as a warrior will compel thee to fight."

text:
इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः।

मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्यो बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः।।3.42।।
transliteration:
indriyāṇi parāṇyāhur indriyebhyaḥ paraṁ manaḥ
manasas tu parā buddhir yo buddheḥ paratas tu saḥ
word_meanings: indriyāṇi—senses; parāṇi—superior; āhuḥ—are said; indriyebhyaḥ—than the senses; param—superior; manaḥ—the mind; manasaḥ—than the mind; tu—but; parā—superior; buddhiḥ—intellect; yaḥ—who; buddheḥ—than the intellect; parataḥ—more superior; tu—but; saḥ—that (soul)
translations: ।।3.42 -- 3.43।। इन्द्रियोंको (स्थूलशरीरसे) पर (श्रेष्ठ, सबल, प्रकाशक, व्यापक तथा सूक्ष्म) कहते हैं। इन्द्रियोंसे पर मन है, मनसे भी पर बुद्धि है औऱ जो बुद्धिसे भी पर है, वह (काम) है। इस तरह बुद्धिसे पर - (काम-) को जानकर अपने द्वारा अपने-आपको वशमें करके हे महाबाहो ! तू इस कामरूप दुर्जय शत्रुको मार डाल।
commentaries:
18.60 Born of (thy) own nature? O son of Kunti?

Nibaddhah bound?
Svena (thy) own?
Karmnash by action?
Kartum to do?
Nah not?
Ichchasi (thou) wishest?
Yat which?
Mohah from delusion?
Karishyasí (thou) shalt do?
Avashah helpless?
Api also?
That.

text:
एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना।

जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम्।।3.43।।
transliteration:
evaṁ buddheḥ paraṁ buddhvā sanstabhyātmānam ātmanā
jahi śhatruṁ mahā-bāho kāma-rūpaṁ durāsadam
word_meanings: evam—thus; buddheḥ—than the intellect; param—superior; buddhvā—knowing; sanstabhya—subdue; ātmānam—the lower self (senses, mind, and intellect); ātmanā—by higher self (soul); jahi—kill; śhatrum—the enemy; mahā-bāho—mighty-armed one; kāma-rūpam—in the form of desire; durāsadam—formidable
translations: ।।3.42 -- 3.43।। इन्द्रियोंको (स्थूलशरीरसे) पर (श्रेष्ठ, सबल, प्रकाशक, व्यापक तथा सूक्ष्म) कहते हैं। इन्द्रियोंसे पर मन है, मनसे भी पर बुद्धि है औऱ जो बुद्धिसे भी पर है वह (काम) है। इस तरह बुद्धिसे पर - (काम-) को जानकर अपने द्वारा अपने-आपको वशमें करके हे महाबाहो ! तू इस कामरूप दुर्जय शत्रुको मार डाल।
commentaries: The Lord is Isvara, the Ruler of the universe. He abides in the hearts of all beings and has given them a gift of movement through His power. The Lord is the real actor within, causing all beings to revolve like wooden dolls mounted on a machine due to Maya or illusion.

text:
सञ्जय उवाच

तं तथा कृपयाऽविष्टमश्रुपूर्णाकुलेक्षणम्।

विषीदन्तमिदं वाक्यमुवाच मधुसूदनः।।2.1।।
transliteration:
sañjaya uvācha
taṁ tathā kṛipayāviṣhṭamaśhru pūrṇākulekṣhaṇam
viṣhīdantamidaṁ vākyam uvācha madhusūdanaḥ
word_meanings: sañjayaḥ uvācha—Sanjay said; tam—to him (Arjun); tathā—thus; kṛipayā—with pity; āviṣhṭam—overwhelmed; aśhru-pūrṇa—full of tears; ākula—distressed; īkṣhaṇam—eyes; viṣhīdantam—grief-stricken; idam—these; vākyam—words; uvācha—said; madhusūdanaḥ—Shree Krishn, slayer of the Madhu demon
translations: ।।2.1।। संजय बोले - वैसी कायरता से आविष्ट उन अर्जुन के प्रति, जो कि विषाद कर रहे हैं और आँसुओं के कारण जिनके नेत्रों की देखने की शक्ति अवरुद्ध हो रही है, भगवान् मधुसूदन ये (आगे कहे जानेवाले) वचन बोले।
commentaries:
18.62 to Him? Even? Take refuge? With all thy being? O Bharata? By His grace? Supreme? Peace? The abode? Thou shalt obtain? Eternal.

Translation:

Total and perfect surrender to the Lord is required, without any secrets or hidden desires. Desire and egoism are the two main obstacles that hinder self-surrender. One must kill them ruthlessly and run to the Lord for shelter with all their being for liberation from the troubles, afflictions, and sorrows of samsara. Take the Lord as the sole refuge and attain supreme peace and eternal abode through His grace.

text:
श्री भगवानुवाच

कुतस्त्वा कश्मलमिदं विषमे समुपस्थितम्।

अनार्यजुष्टमस्वर्ग्यमकीर्तिकरमर्जुन।।2.2।।
transliteration:
śhrī bhagavān uvācha
kutastvā kaśhmalamidaṁ viṣhame samupasthitam
anārya-juṣhṭamaswargyam akīrti-karam arjuna
word_meanings: śhrī-bhagavān uvācha—the Supreme Lord said; kutaḥ—wherefrom; tvā—to you; kaśhmalam—delusion; idam—this; viṣhame—in this hour of peril; samupasthitam—overcome; anārya—crude person; juṣhṭam—practiced; aswargyam—which does not lead to the higher abodes; akīrti-karam—leading to disgrace; arjuna—Arjun
translations: ।।2.2।। श्रीभगवान् बोले (टिप्पणी प0 38.1) - हे अर्जुन! इस विषम अवसरपर तुम्हें यह कायरता कहाँसे प्राप्त हुई, जिसका कि श्रेष्ठ पुरुष सेवन नहीं करते, जो स्वर्गको देनेवाली नहीं है और कीर्ति करनेवाली भी नहीं है।
commentaries:
18.63 इति - Thus
ते - to thee
ज्ञानम् - wisdom
आख्यातम् - has been declared
गुह्यात् - than the secret
गुह्यतरम् - more secret
मया - by Me
विमृश्य - reflecting over
एतat - this
अशेषेण - fully
यथा - as
इच्छसि - (thou) wishest
कुरु - act.

text:
क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते।

क्षुद्रं हृदयदौर्बल्यं त्यक्त्वोत्तिष्ठ परन्तप।।2.3।।
transliteration:
klaibyaṁ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitat tvayyupapadyate
kṣhudraṁ hṛidaya-daurbalyaṁ tyaktvottiṣhṭha parantapa
word_meanings: klaibyam—unmanliness; mā sma—do not; gamaḥ—yield to; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; na—not; etat—this; tvayi—to you; upapadyate—befitting; kṣhudram—petty; hṛidaya—heart; daurbalyam—weakness; tyaktvā—giving up; uttiṣhṭha—arise; param-tapa—conqueror of enemies
translations: ।।2.3।। हे पृथानन्दन अर्जुन ! इस नपुंसकताको मत प्राप्त हो; क्योंकि तुम्हारेमें यह उचित नहीं है। हे परंतप ! हृदयकी इस तुच्छ दुर्बलताका त्याग करके युद्धके लिये खड़े हो जाओ।
commentaries:
The sentence "18.64 सर्वगुह्यतमम् the most secret of all? भूयः again? श्रृणु hear? मे My? परमam् supreme? वचः word? इष्टः beloved? असि (thou) art? मे of Me? दृढम् dearly? इति thus? ततः therefore? वक्ष्यामि (I) will speak? ते thy? हितम् what is good." can be translated into English as:

"18.64 The most secret of all? Again? Hear? Me? Supreme? Word? Beloved? Thou art? Of Me? Dearly? Thus? Therefore? I will speak? Thou?"

text:
अर्जुन उवाच

कथं भीष्ममहं संख्ये द्रोणं च मधुसूदन।

इषुभिः प्रतियोत्स्यामि पूजार्हावरिसूदन।।2.4।।
transliteration:
arjuna uvācha
kathaṁ bhīṣhmam ahaṁ sankhye droṇaṁ cha madhusūdana
iṣhubhiḥ pratiyotsyāmi pūjārhāvari-sūdana
word_meanings: arjunaḥ uvācha—Arjun said; katham—how; bhīṣhmam—Bheeshma; aham—I; sankhye—in battle; droṇam—Dronacharya; cha—and; madhu-sūdana—Shree Krishn, slayer of the Madhu demon; iṣhubhiḥ—with arrows; pratiyotsyāmi—shall I shoot; pūjā-arhau—worthy of worship; ari-sūdana—destroyer of enemies
translations: ।।2.4।। अर्जुन बोले - हे मधुसूदन! मैं रणभूमिमें भीष्म और द्रोणके साथ बाणोंसे युद्ध कैसे करूँ? क्योंकि हे अरिसूदन! ये दोनों ही पूजाके योग्य हैं।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"With mind fixed on Me? Be devoted to Me? Make sacrifices to Me? Come to Me? Bow down? Even? Yes, you shall come to Me. Truth? It is to thee. I promise. Dear one, you are mine."

text:
गुरूनहत्वा हि महानुभावान्

श्रेयो भोक्तुं भैक्ष्यमपीह लोके।

हत्वार्थकामांस्तु गुरूनिहैव

भुञ्जीय भोगान् रुधिरप्रदिग्धान्।।2.5।।
transliteration:
gurūnahatvā hi mahānubhāvān
śhreyo bhoktuṁ bhaikṣhyamapīha loke
hatvārtha-kāmāṁstu gurūnihaiva
bhuñjīya bhogān rudhira-pradigdhān
word_meanings: gurūn—teachers; ahatvā—not killing; hi—certainly; mahā-anubhāvān—noble elders; śhreyaḥ—better; bhoktum—to enjoy life; bhaikṣhyam—by begging; api—even; iha loke—in this world; hatvā—killing; artha—gain; kāmān—desiring; tu—but; gurūn—noble elders; iha—in this world; eva—certainly; bhuñjīya—enjoy; bhogān—pleasures; rudhira—blood; pradigdhān—tainted with
translations: ।।2.5।। महानुभाव गुरुजनोंको न मारकर इस लोकमें मैं भिक्षाका अन्न खाना भी श्रेष्ठ समझता हूँ।  क्योंकि गुरुजनोंको मारकर यहाँ रक्तसे सने हुए तथा धनकी कामनाकी मुख्यतावाले भोगोंको ही तो भोगूँगा!
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"18.66 All duties? Having abandoned? Me? Alone? Refuge? Take? I? Thou? From all sins? Will liberate? Don't grieve."

Note: The sentence contains some Hindi words and phrases, which have been left untranslated as they are part of the original text.

text:
न चैतद्विद्मः कतरन्नो गरीयो

यद्वा जयेम यदि वा नो जयेयुः।

यानेव हत्वा न जिजीविषाम

स्तेऽवस्थिताः प्रमुखे धार्तराष्ट्राः।।2.6।।
transliteration:
na chaitadvidmaḥ kataranno garīyo
yadvā jayema yadi vā no jayeyuḥ
yāneva hatvā na jijīviṣhāmas
te ’vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣhṭrāḥ
word_meanings: na—not; cha—and; etat—this; vidmaḥ—we know; katarat—which; naḥ—for us; garīyaḥ—is preferable; yat vā—whether; jayema—we may conquer; yadi—if; vā—or; naḥ—us; jayeyuḥ—they may conquer; yān—whom; eva—certainly; hatvā—after killing; na—not; jijīviṣhāmaḥ—we desire to live; te—they; avasthitāḥ—are standing; pramukhe—before us; dhārtarāṣhṭrāḥ—the sons of Dhritarashtra
translations: ।।2.6।। हम यह भी नहीं जानते कि हमलोगोंके लिये युद्ध करना और न करना - इन दोनोंमेंसे कौन-सा अत्यन्त श्रेष्ठ है; और हमें इसका भी पता नहीं है कि हम उन्हें जीतेंगे अथवा वे हमें जीतेंगे। जिनको मारकर हम जीना भी नहीं चाहते, वे ही धृतराष्ट्रके सम्बन्धी हमारे सामने खड़े हैं।
commentaries:
18.67 इदम् this?

This can be translated to "What is this?" in English.

text:
कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः

पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसंमूढचेताः।

यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्िचतं ब्रूहि तन्मे

शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम्।।2.7।।
transliteration:
kārpaṇya-doṣhopahata-svabhāvaḥ
pṛichchhāmi tvāṁ dharma-sammūḍha-chetāḥ
yach-chhreyaḥ syānniśhchitaṁ brūhi tanme
śhiṣhyaste ’haṁ śhādhi māṁ tvāṁ prapannam
word_meanings: kārpaṇya-doṣha—the flaw of cowardice; upahata—besieged; sva-bhāvaḥ—nature; pṛichchhāmi—I am asking; tvām—to you; dharma—duty; sammūḍha—confused; chetāḥ—in heart; yat—what; śhreyaḥ—best; syāt—may be; niśhchitam—decisively; brūhi—tell; tat—that; me—to me; śhiṣhyaḥ—disciple; te—your; aham—I; śhādhi—please instruct; mām—me; tvām—unto you; prapannam—surrendered
translations: With my very nature, overpowered by the taint of pity, and with my mind, utterly confused as to the right action at this present juncture, I ask you: Tell me definitely what would be good for me; I am your pupil; please teach me, who is taking refuge in You.
commentaries:
The translation of the sentence is:

18.68 Who are you? This is supreme? Are these secrets hidden in My devotees? Shall I declare them? Is there devotion in Me? May they come even to Me? Doubtless.

text:
न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्या

द्यच्छोकमुच्छोषणमिन्द्रियाणाम्।

अवाप्य भूमावसपत्नमृद्धम्

राज्यं सुराणामपि चाधिपत्यम्।।2.8।।
transliteration:
na hi prapaśhyāmi mamāpanudyād
yach-chhokam uchchhoṣhaṇam-indriyāṇām
avāpya bhūmāv-asapatnamṛiddhaṁ
rājyaṁ surāṇāmapi chādhipatyam
word_meanings: na—not; hi—certainly; prapaśhyāmi—I see; mama—my; apanudyāt—drive away; yat—which; śhokam—anguish; uchchhoṣhaṇam—is drying up; indriyāṇām—of the senses; avāpya—after achieving; bhūmau—on the earth; asapatnam—unrivalled; ṛiddham—prosperous; rājyam—kingdom; surāṇām—like the celestial gods; api—even; cha—also; ādhipatyam—sovereignty
translations: Even if I were to win unchallenged sovereignty of a prosperous earth or even lordship over the Devas, I do not feel that it would dispel the grief that withers up my senses.
commentaries: "He who transmits this Gita to My devotees does immense service to Me. He is very dear to Me. There is none in the present generation who does dearer service to Me, nor shall there be in the future also in this world."

text:
सञ्जय उवाच

एवमुक्त्वा हृषीकेशं गुडाकेशः परन्तप।

न योत्स्य इति गोविन्दमुक्त्वा तूष्णीं बभूव ह।।2.9।।
transliteration:
sañjaya uvācha
evam-uktvā hṛiṣhīkeśhaṁ guḍākeśhaḥ parantapa
na yotsya iti govindam uktvā tūṣhṇīṁ babhūva ha
word_meanings: sañjayaḥ uvācha—Sanjay said; evam—thus; uktvā—having spoken; hṛiṣhīkeśham—to Shree Krishna, the master of the mind and senses; guḍākeśhaḥ—Arjun, the conquerer of sleep; parantapaḥ—Arjun, the chastiser of the enemies; na yotsye—I shall not fight; iti—thus; govindam—Krishna, the giver of pleasure to the senses; uktvā—having addressed; tūṣhṇīm—silent; babhūva—became ha

commentaries:
18.70 अध्येष्यते shall study?

* यः (Yah) - He/She/It

text:
तमुवाच हृषीकेशः प्रहसन्निव भारत।

सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये विषीदन्तमिदं वचः।।2.10।।
transliteration:
tam-uvācha hṛiṣhīkeśhaḥ prahasanniva bhārata
senayorubhayor-madhye viṣhīdantam-idaṁ vachaḥ
word_meanings: tam—to him; uvācha—said; hṛiṣhīkeśhaḥ—Shree Krishna, the master of mind and senses; prahasan—smilingly; iva—as if; bhārata—Dhritarashtra, descendant of Bharat; senayoḥ—of the armies; ubhayoḥ—of both; madhye—in the midst of; viṣhīdantam—to the grief-stricken; idam—this; vachaḥ—words
translations: To him who was despondent in the midst of the two armies, Krishna, smiling, O Bharata, spoke these words.
commentaries:
18.71 Full of faith? Free from malice? May hear? Also? Who? Man? He? Also? Liberated? Happy? Worlds? Shall attain? Of those of righteous deeds.

Translation:
Are you full of faith? Are you free from malice? Can you hear? Can you also? Is it a man? Is he? Additionally, are you liberated and happy? Will the worlds attain? Of those who have performed righteous deeds.

text:
श्री भगवानुवाच

अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे।

गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः।।2.11।।
transliteration:
śhrī bhagavān uvācha
aśhochyān-anvaśhochas-tvaṁ prajñā-vādānśh cha bhāṣhase
gatāsūn-agatāsūnśh-cha nānuśhochanti paṇḍitāḥ
word_meanings: śhrī-bhagavān uvācha—the Supreme Lord said; aśhochyān—not worthy of grief; anvaśhochaḥ—are mourning; tvam—you; prajñā-vādān—words of wisdom; cha—and; bhāṣhase—speaking; gata āsūn—the dead; agata asūn—the living; cha—and; na—never; anuśhochanti—lament; paṇḍitāḥ—the wise
translations: The Blessed Lord said, "You have grieved for those who should not be grieved for; yet, you speak words of wisdom. The wise grieve neither for the living nor for the dead."
commentaries: 18.72 whether? Have you heard? O son of Kunti (Arjuna)? By thee? Onepointed? By mind? Whether? Has the delusion of thy ignorance been destroyed? Lord Krishna asks Arjuna, indicating that he should have understood and grasped the teaching through his own effort and not just relied on blind faith. The delusion of ignorance refers to the lack of discrimination caused by not understanding the true nature of reality, which is the aim of all spiritual practices.

text:
न त्वेवाहं जातु नासं न त्वं नेमे जनाधिपाः।

न चैव न भविष्यामः सर्वे वयमतः परम्।।2.12।।
transliteration:
na tvevāhaṁ jātu nāsaṁ na tvaṁ neme janādhipāḥ
na chaiva na bhaviṣhyāmaḥ sarve vayamataḥ param
word_meanings: na—never; tu—however; eva—certainly; aham—I; jātu—at any time; na—nor; āsam—exist; na—nor; tvam—you; na—nor; ime—these; jana-adhipāḥ—kings; na—never; cha—also; eva—indeed; na bhaviṣhyāmaḥ—shall not exist; sarve vayam—all of us; ataḥ—from now; param—after
translations: Nor, at any time, was I not, nor thou, nor these rulers of men; nor, verily, shall we ever cease to be hereafter.
commentaries:
18.73 नष्टः is destroyed? - Not destroyed
मोहः delusion? - Delusion
स्मृतिः memory (knowledge)? - Knowledge
लब्धा has been gained? - Gained
त्वत्प्रसादात् through Thy grace? - Through thy grace
मया by me? - Me
अच्युत O Krishna? - Unfortunate (Krishna)
स्थितः अस्मि I remain? - Remain
गतसन्देहः freed from doubts? - Freedom from doubts
करिष्ये (I) will do? - Will do
वचनम् word? - Word
तav Thy. - Thy

text:
देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा।

तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति।।2.13।।
transliteration:
dehino ’smin yathā dehe kaumāraṁ yauvanaṁ jarā
tathā dehāntara-prāptir dhīras tatra na muhyati
word_meanings: dehinaḥ—of the embodied; asmin—in this; yathā—as; dehe—in the body; kaumāram—childhood; yauvanam—youth; jarā—old age; tathā—similarly; deha-antara—another body; prāptiḥ—achieves; dhīraḥ—the wise; tatra—thereupon; na muhyati—are not deluded
translations: Just as boyhood, youth, and old age come to the embodied soul in this body, so too is the attainment of another body; the wise man is not deluded by this.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence into English:

"18.74 indeed? I am Ahimsa (non-violence)? Of Krishna? Partha's (Arjuna) wonder? And? Mahatman (high-souled)? Samvaadam (dialogue)? This? Aham (I) have heard? Amazing! Which deals with Yoga and transcendental spiritual matters that pertain to the mysterious immortal Self. Whenever good and higher emotions manifest themselves in the heart, the hair stands on end. Devotees often experience this horripilation."

text:
मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः।

आगमापायिनोऽनित्यास्तांस्तितिक्षस्व भारत।।2.14।।
transliteration:
mātrā-sparśhās tu kaunteya śhītoṣhṇa-sukha-duḥkha-dāḥ
āgamāpāyino ’nityās tans-titikṣhasva bhārata
word_meanings: mātrā-sparśhāḥ—contact of the senses with the sense objects; tu—indeed; kaunteya—Arjun, the son of Kunti; śhīta—winter; uṣhṇa—summer; sukha—happiness; duḥkha—distress; dāḥ—give; āgama—come; apāyinaḥ—go; anityāḥ—non-permanent; tān—them; titikṣhasva—tolerate; bhārata—descendant of the Bharat
translations: O son of Kunti! The touches with the matras cause feelings of cold and heat, pleasure and pain; they are of the nature of coming and going and are transient. Bear them, O Descendant of Bharata!
commentaries:
The translation of the given sentence in English is:

"Through Vyasa's grace, I have heard this dialogue directly from Krishna. This dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna is called Yoga because it deals with Yoga and leads to the union with the Lord."

text:
यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ।

समदुःखसुखं धीरं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते।।2.15।।
transliteration:
yaṁ hi na vyathayantyete puruṣhaṁ puruṣharṣhabha
sama-duḥkha-sukhaṁ dhīraṁ so ’mṛitatvāya kalpate
word_meanings: yam—whom; hi—verily; na—not; vyathayanti—distressed; ete—these; puruṣham—person; puruṣha-ṛiṣhabha—the noblest amongst men, Arjun; sama—equipoised; duḥkha—distress; sukham—happiness; dhīram—steady; saḥ—that person; amṛitatvāya—for liberation; kalpate—becomes eligible
translations: That firm man, whom surely these afflictions do not, O chief among men, to whom pleasure and pain are the same, is fit for attaining immortality.
commentaries:
The sentence "18.76 राजन् O King? संस्मृत्य having remembered? संवादम् the dialogue? इमम् this? अद्भुतम् wonderful? केशवार्जुनयोः between Kesava and Arjuna? पुण्यम् holy? हृष्यामि (I) rejoice? च and? मुहुः again? मुहुः again." can be translated into English as:

"18.76 O King? Have you remembered? The dialogue? What is this? Wonderful! Between Kesava and Arjuna? Holy? I rejoice! And again?"

text:
नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः।

उभयोरपि दृष्टोऽन्तस्त्वनयोस्तत्त्वदर्शिभिः।।2.16।।
transliteration:
nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ
ubhayorapi dṛiṣhṭo ’nta stvanayos tattva-darśhibhiḥ
word_meanings: na—no; asataḥ—of the temporary; vidyate—there is; bhāvaḥ—is; na—no; abhāvaḥ—cessation; vidyate—is; sataḥ—of the eternal; ubhayoḥ—of the two; api—also; dṛiṣhṭaḥ—observed; antaḥ—conclusion; tu—verily; anayoḥ—of these; tattva—of the truth; darśhibhiḥ—by the seers
translations: The unreal has no being; there is no non-being of the real; the truth about both has been seen by the knowers of the truth (or the seers of the essence).
commentaries:
18.77 तत् that?
Ch and?
संस्मृत्य having remembered?
रूपम् the form?
अत्यद्भुतम् the most wonderful?
हरेः of Hari?
विस्मयः wonder?
मे my?
महान् great?
राजन् O King?
हृष्यामि (I) rejoice?
च and?
पुनः again?
पुनः again.

text:
अविनाशि तु तद्विद्धि येन सर्वमिदं ततम्।

विनाशमव्ययस्यास्य न कश्चित् कर्तुमर्हति।।2.17।।
transliteration:
avināśhi tu tadviddhi yena sarvam idaṁ tatam
vināśham avyayasyāsya na kaśhchit kartum arhati
word_meanings: avināśhi—indestructible; tu—indeed; tat—that; viddhi—know; yena—by whom; sarvam—entire; idam—this; tatam—pervaded; vināśham—destruction; avyayasya—of the imperishable; asya—of it; na kaśhchit—no one; kartum—to cause; arhati—is able
translations: Know that to be indestructible, by which all this is pervaded. No one can cause the destruction of that, the Imperishable.
commentaries:
The sentence "18.78 यत्र wherever? योगेश्वरः the Lord of Yoga? कृष्णः Krishna? यत्र wherever? पार्थः Arjuna? धनुर्धरः the archer? तत्र there? श्रीः prosperity? विजयः victory? भूतिः happiness? ध्रुवा firm? नीतिः policy? मतिः conviction? मम my." can be translated into English as:

"Wherever there is the Lord of Yoga, Krishna, or Arjuna, the archer, there is prosperity, victory, and happiness. The policies are firm and the convictions are strong. My (Krishna's)."

text:
अन्तवन्त इमे देहा नित्यस्योक्ताः शरीरिणः।

अनाशिनोऽप्रमेयस्य तस्माद्युध्यस्व भारत।।2.18।।
transliteration:
antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śharīriṇaḥ
anāśhino ’prameyasya tasmād yudhyasva bhārata
word_meanings: anta-vantaḥ—having an end; ime—these; dehāḥ—material bodies; nityasya—eternally; uktāḥ—are said; śharīriṇaḥ—of the embodied soul; anāśhinaḥ—indestructible; aprameyasya—immeasurable; tasmāt—therefore; yudhyasva—fight; bhārata—descendant of Bharat, Arjun
translations: These destructible bodies are said to belong to the everlasting, indestructible, and indeterminable embodied One. Therefore, O descendant of Bharata, join the battle.
commentaries:
The sentence you provided contains some Hindi words, but I will provide the one-to-one translation of each word into English:

1. ये - Who? (The word "ye" is not used in English, so I will simply translate it as "who".)
2. शास्त्रविधिम् - The ordinances of the scriptures? (This phrase can be translated as "the teachings of the scriptures".)
3. उत्सृज्य - Setting aside? (This word can be translated as "abandoning" or "giving up".)
4. यजन्ते - Perform sacrifice? (The word "yajante" is not used in English, so I will translate it as "perform sacrifices".)
5. श्रद्धया - With faith? (This phrase can be translated as "with devotion".)
6. अन्विताः - Endowed? (The word "anvitah" is not used in English, so I will translate it as "endowed".)
7. तेषाम् - Their? (This word can be translated as "their".)
8. निष्ठा - Condition? (This word can be translated as "state".)
9. तु - Verily? (The word "tu" is not used in English, so I will translate it as "verily".)
10. का - What? (This word can be translated as "what".)
11. कृष्ण - Krishna? (This name can be translated as "Krishna".)
12. सत्त्वम् - Sattva? (The word "sattva" is not used in English, so I will translate it as "Sattva".)
13. आहो - Or? (This word can be translated as "or".)
14. रजः - Rajas? (The word "raajah" is not used in English, so I will translate it as "Rajas".)
15. तमः - Tamas. (This word can be translated as "Tamas".)

Now, let me provide the translation of the entire sentence:

"Who are the people who are endowed with faith? They follow a path in accordance with their inherent nature -- either Sattvic, Rajasic or Tamasic. Arjuna says to Krishna that it is very difficult to grasp the meaning of the scriptures, and it is even more difficult to get a spiritual preceptor who can teach them. The vast majority of persons are not endowed with a pure, subtle, sharp, and one-pointed intellect. The span of life is short, and the scriptures are endless. The obstacles on the spiritual path are many, and facilities for learning are not always available. There are conflicting statements in the scriptures that have to be reconciled. Krishna says that liberation is not possible without a knowledge of the scriptures. An ordinary man, though ignorant of or unable to follow this teaching, does charity, performs rituals, worships the Lord with faith, tries to follow the footsteps of sages and saints just as a child copies letters that have been written out for him as a model, or as a blind man makes his way by the aid of another who possesses sight. What faith is his? How should the state of such a man be described -- Sattvic, Rajasic, or Tamasic?"

text:
य एनं वेत्ति हन्तारं यश्चैनं मन्यते हतम्।

उभौ तौ न विजानीतो नायं हन्ति न हन्यते।।2.19।।
transliteration:
ya enaṁ vetti hantāraṁ yaśh chainaṁ manyate hatam
ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṁ hanti na hanyate
word_meanings: yaḥ—one who; enam—this; vetti—knows; hantāram—the slayer; yaḥ—one who; cha—and; enam—this; manyate—thinks; hatam—slain; ubhau—both; tau—they; na—not; vijānītaḥ—in knowledge; na—neither; ayam—this; hanti—slays; na—nor; hanyate—is killed
translations: He who considers It (the self) to be the slayer, and he who thinks of It as slain—both are ignorant. For, the self neither slays nor is being slain.
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

"Faith assumes a threefold aspect under the influence of the three alities. When Sattva is strongly developed, it is easy for him to attain Self-realization or knowledge of the Self. If Rajas is predominant, faith becomes the handmaid of activity. If Tamas or inertia prevails, faith is annihilated. Those who are endowed with Sattvic faith aim at the attainment of liberation. Those who are endowed with Rajasic faith run after inferior duties or worldly activities. Those whose faith is Tamasic are cruel. They kill animals for sacrifice. They invoke the spirits and talk with ghosts."

The sentence is a commentary on the threefold nature of faith, which is influenced by the three alities or gunas of Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas. The commentary discusses how faith can manifest differently depending on the predominant quality of an individual's mind, and how it can lead to different outcomes such as liberation or worldly activities.

text:

अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो

न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे।।2.20।।

ajo nityaḥ śhāśhvato ’yaṁ purāṇo
na hanyate hanyamāne śharīre
word_meanings: na jāyate—is not born; mriyate—dies; vā—or; kadāchit—at any time; na—not; ayam—this; bhūtvā—having once existed; bhavitā—will be; vā—or; na—not; bhūyaḥ—further; ajaḥ—unborn; nityaḥ—eternal; śhāśhvataḥ—immortal; ayam—this; purāṇaḥ—the ancient; na hanyate—is not destroyed; hanyamāne—is destroyed; śharīre—when the body
translations: ।।2.20।। यह आत्मा किसी काल में भी न जन्मता है और न मरता है और न यह एक बार होकर फिर अभावरूप होने वाला है। यह आत्मा अजन्मा, नित्य, शाश्वत और पुरातन है,  शरीर के नाश होने पर भी इसका नाश नहीं होता।।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"Everyone's faith conforms to their inherent nature or natural temperament. A person is shaped by their faith, and it shows what their character is. A person becomes what their faith has made them, and their conduct in life is molded by their faith. Each man's faith is according to their specific tendencies or self-reproducing latent impressions from past actions. The faith of each person takes on the color and nature from the stuff of their being, their temperament, tendencies, or Samskaras."

text:
वेदाविनाशिनं नित्यं य एनमजमव्ययम्।

word_meanings: veda—knows; avināśhinam—imperishable; nityam—eternal; yaḥ—who; enam—this; ajam—unborn; avyayam—immutable; katham—how; saḥ—that; puruṣhaḥ—person; pārtha—Parth; kam—whom; ghātayati—causes to be killed; hanti—kills; kam—whom

commentaries:
The sentence "17.4 यजन्ते worship?" has been translated into English as follows:

"Who worship? The pure men? The gods? The Yakshas and the Rakshasas? The passionate? The ghosts? The hosts of Bhutas or the naturespirits? And others? Worship? The Tamasic?"

In this translation, I have attempted to preserve the original sentence's structure and syntax while replacing the Hindi words with their English equivalents.

text:

नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि।

translations: As after rejecting worn-out clothes, a man takes up other new ones, likewise, after rejecting worn-out bodies, the embodied one unites with other new ones.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"Not enjoined by scriptures? Terrific! Practise? Who? Austerity? Men? Given to hypocrisy and egoism? By the force of lust and attachment. They are puffed up with vanity, proud of their wealth, perform unauthorized austerities, take innocent lives in the name of sacrifice, and inflict pain on themselves and others. Pitiable indeed is their lot. They are doomed to destruction."

Note: The word "Tapas" in Hindi has been translated as "austerity" in English.

text:
अच्छेद्योऽयमदाह्योऽयमक्लेद्योऽशोष्य एव च।

नित्यः सर्वगतः स्थाणुरचलोऽयं सनातनः।।2.24।।
transliteration:
achchhedyo ’yam adāhyo ’yam akledyo ’śhoṣhya eva cha
nityaḥ sarva-gataḥ sthāṇur achalo ’yaṁ sanātanaḥ
word_meanings: achchhedyaḥ—unbreakable; ayam—this soul; adāhyaḥ—incombustible; ayam—this soul; akledyaḥ—cannot be dampened; aśhoṣhyaḥ—cannot be dried; eva—indeed; cha—and; nityaḥ—everlasting; sarva-gataḥ—all-pervading; sthāṇuḥ—unalterable; achalaḥ—immutable; ayam—this soul; sanātanaḥ—primordial
translations: ।।2.24।। यह शरीरी काटा नहीं जा सकता, यह जलाया नहीं जा सकता, यह गीला नहीं किया जा सकता और यह सुखाया भी नहीं जा सकता। कारण कि यह नित्य रहनेवाला सबमें परिपूर्ण, अचल, स्थिर स्वभाववाला और अनादि है।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"Everything in this world is threefold. The food is either Sattvic, Rajasic or Tamasic according to its character and effect upon the body and the mind. You can find out the nature or temperament of a man from the nature of the food he takes. You can find out your own nature whether you are Sattvic, Rajasic or Tamasic from your predilection to particular food and then abandon the Rajasic and the Tamasic foodstuffs and take to the Sattvic diet. Why is there also a triple division in sacrifice, austerity and charity? Because this threefold division is according to the nature of the Gunas. You can find out and abandon the Rajasic and the Tamasic ones and take recourse exclusively to the Sattvic ones."

तस्मादेवं विदित्वैनं नानुशोचितुमर्हसि।।2.25।।

word_meanings: avyaktaḥ—unmanifested; ayam—this soul; achintyaḥ—inconceivable; ayam—this soul; avikāryaḥ—unchangeable; ayam—this soul; uchyate—is said; tasmāt—therefore; evam—thus; viditvā—having known; enam—this soul; na—not; anuśhochitum—to grieve; arhasi—befitting
translations: ।।2.25।। यह देही प्रत्यक्ष नहीं दीखता, यह चिन्तनका विषय नहीं है और यह निर्विकार कहा जाता है। अतः इस देहीको ऐसा जानकर शोक नहीं करना चाहिये।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"What increases life? purity? strength? health? joy? cheerfulness and good appetite? savory? oleaginous? substantial? agreeable? foods? Sattvic foods are dear to the pure. According to a Hindi proverb, 'As is the food, so is the mind.' The seven elements of the body are formed from food, and ideas or concepts are generated in the mind corresponding to these elements. Just as water becomes hot when placed over fire, the nature and constitution of the mind are also influenced by the nature and constitution of the food or the seven elements."

text:

commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

"Those who are bitter? sour? saline? excessively hot? pungent? dry and burning? foods? of the Rajasic nature? are liked? They produce grief and disease. Excessive consumption of such foods leads to restlessness in the mind, evil thoughts, excitement, craving now for one thing and then for another, pain, trouble, and disease."

The man whose taste is of a Tamasic nature will eat food in the afternoon that has been cooked on the previous day. He also likes that which is halfcooked or burnt to a cinder. He and all the members of his family sit together and eat from the same dish or plate? food that has been mixed into a mess by his children.
The food eaten by Tamasic people is stale? dry? without juice? unripe or overcooked. They do not relish it? till it begins to rot and ferment. They take prohibited foods and drinks. They take liors? fermented toddy? etc. They are horrible people with devilish tendencies.

text:
अव्यक्तादीनि भूतानि व्यक्तमध्यानि भारत।
