commentaries:
17.11 अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिः by men desiring no fruit? यज्ञः sacrifice? विधिदृष्टः as enjoined by the ordinance? यः which? इज्यते is offered? यष्टव्यम् ought to be offered? एव only? इति thus? मनः the mind? समाधाय having fixed? सः that? सात्विकः Sattvic or pure.

Translation:

17.11 What is the significance of अफलाकाङ्к्षिभिः (offerings without desire for fruit)? Should we perform sacrifice as enjoined by the ordinance? Which one are you referring to? Is it being offered? Ought to be offered? Only? Thus? The mind? Having fixed the goal? That (sacrifice)? Sattvic or pure.

text:
आश्चर्यवत्पश्यति कश्चिदेन

माश्चर्यवद्वदति तथैव चान्यः।

आश्चर्यवच्चैनमन्यः श्रृणोति

श्रुत्वाप्येनं वेद न चैव कश्चित्।।2.29।।
transliteration:
āśhcharya-vat paśhyati kaśhchid enan
āśhcharya-vad vadati tathaiva chānyaḥ
āśhcharya-vach chainam anyaḥ śhṛiṇoti
śhrutvāpyenaṁ veda na chaiva kaśhchit
word_meanings: āśhcharya-vat—as amazing; paśhyati—see; kaśhchit—someone; enam—this soul; āśhcharya-vat—as amazing; vadati—speak of; tathā—thus; eva—indeed; cha—and; anyaḥ—other; āśhcharya-vat—similarly amazing; cha—also; enam—this soul; anyaḥ—others; śhṛiṇoti—hear; śhrutvā—having heard; api—even; enam—this soul; veda—understand; na—not; cha—and; eva—even; kaśhchit—some
translations: ।।2.29।। कोई इस शरीरीको आश्चर्यकी तरह देखता है और वैसे ही अन्य कोई इसका आश्चर्यकी तरह वर्णन करता है तथा अन्य कोई इसको आश्चर्यकी तरह सुनता है; और इसको सुनकर भी कोई नहीं जानता। अर्थात यह शरीरी दुर्विज्ञेय है।
commentaries:
Sure, here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"Who seeks what by performing a sacrifice? Indeed, for what purpose? Fruit? For ostentation? Even so? Which one is offered? Oh, best of the Bharatas! That which is sacrificed is of a Rajasic nature, for the purpose of increasing one's own importance, popularizing one's name in the world, gaining some reward, or making an exhibition of one's riches for one's own glorification. There is no aspiration for attaining the knowledge of the Self."

text:
देही नित्यमवध्योऽयं देहे सर्वस्य भारत।

तस्मात्सर्वाणि भूतानि न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि।।2.30।।
transliteration:
dehī nityam avadhyo ’yaṁ dehe sarvasya bhārata
tasmāt sarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṁ śhochitum arhasi
word_meanings: dehī—the soul that dwells within the body; nityam—always; avadhyaḥ—immortal; ayam—this soul; dehe—in the body; sarvasya—of everyone; bhārata—descendant of Bharat, Arjun; tasmāt—therefore; sarvāṇi—for all; bhūtāni—living entities; na—not; tvam—you; śhochitum—mourn; arhasi—should
translations: O descendant of Bharata, this embodied Self existing in everyone's body can never be killed; therefore, you ought not to grieve for all these beings.
commentaries:
The sentence "17.13 विधिहीनम् without keeping to ordinance? असृष्टान्नम् in which no food is distributed? मन्त्रहीनम् which is devoid of Mantras? अदक्षिणम् which is devoid of gifts? श्रद्धाविरहितम् which is devoid of faith? यज्ञम् sacrifice? तामसम् Tamasic? परिचक्षते (they) declare." can be translated into English as:

"A sacrifice performed without adhering to the prescribed rituals is never guided by any consideration for the scriptures. No food is distributed, nor are the prescribed fees given to the priests. The mantras are not pronounced properly, and the hymns are recited defectively in terms of utterance and accent. Sometimes there is no recitation at all. There is no faith, and such a sacrifice does not bring any merit."

text:
स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि।

धर्म्याद्धि युद्धाछ्रेयोऽन्यत्क्षत्रियस्य न विद्यते।।2.31।।
transliteration:
swa-dharmam api chāvekṣhya na vikampitum arhasi
dharmyāddhi yuddhāch chhreyo ’nyat kṣhatriyasya na vidyate
word_meanings: swa-dharmam—one’s duty in accordance with the Vedas; api—also; cha—and; avekṣhya—considering; na—not; vikampitum—to waver; arhasi—should; dharmyāt—for righteousness; hi—indeed; yuddhāt—than fighting; śhreyaḥ—better; anyat—another; kṣhatriyasya—of a warrior; na—not; vidyate—exists
translations: ।।2.31।। अपने स्वधर्म (क्षात्रधर्म) को देखकर भी तुम्हें विकम्पित अर्थात् कर्तव्य-कर्मसे विचलित नहीं होना चाहिये; क्योंकि धर्ममय युद्धसे बढ़कर क्षत्रियके लिये दूसरा कोई कल्याणकारक कर्म नहीं है।
commentaries:
The sentence in English translation is:

"Control of the mind is difficult for beginners, so it is said to control the senses first. The mind operates through the senses, so controlling the senses goes hand in hand with controlling the mind. An attack on the senses from outside and an eradication of desires within the mind can easily conquer the mind. Control of the mind or control of the senses can be done according to one's liking, capacity, taste, and temperament. As you advance in your practice, your doubts will gradually disappear, and you will enjoy supreme peace and joy."

text:
यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम्।

सुखिनः क्षत्रियाः पार्थ लभन्ते युद्धमीदृशम्।।2.32।।
transliteration:
yadṛichchhayā chopapannaṁ swarga-dvāram apāvṛitam
sukhinaḥ kṣhatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddham īdṛiśham
word_meanings: yadṛichchhayā—unsought; cha—and; upapannam—come; swarga—celestial abodes; dvāram—door; apāvṛitam—wide open; sukhinaḥ—happy; kṣhatriyāḥ—warriors; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; labhante—obtain; yuddham—war; īdṛiśham—such
translations: ।।2.32।। अपने-आप प्राप्त हुआ युद्ध खुला हुआ स्वर्गका दरवाजा भी है। हे पृथानन्दन ! वे क्षत्रिय बड़े सुखी (भाग्यशाली) हैं, जिनको ऐसा युद्ध प्राप्त होता है।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"The man who practices the austerity of speech does not cause pain to others. His words bring cheer and solace to others. His words are beneficial to all. The organ of speech causes great distraction of mind. Controlling speech is a difficult discipline, but if you want to attain supreme peace, you will have to practice it."

Note: I have tried my best to provide an accurate translation of the given sentence, but please keep in mind that Hindi and English are two different languages with different grammatical structures and nuances, so there may be some subtle differences in the translation.

text:
अथ चैत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि।

ततः स्वधर्मं कीर्तिं च हित्वा पापमवाप्स्यसि।।2.33।।
transliteration:
atha chet tvam imaṁ dharmyaṁ saṅgrāmaṁ na kariṣhyasi
tataḥ sva-dharmaṁ kīrtiṁ cha hitvā pāpam avāpsyasi
word_meanings: atha chet—if, however; tvam—you; imam—this; dharmyam saṅgrāmam—righteous war; na—not; kariṣhyasi—act; tataḥ—then; sva-dharmam—one’s duty in accordance with the Vedas; kīrtim—reputation; cha—and; hitvā—abandoning; pāpam—sin; avāpsyasi—will incur
translations: ।।2.33।। अब अगर तू यह धर्ममय युद्ध नहीं करेगा,  तो अपने धर्म और कीर्तिका त्याग करके पापको प्राप्त होगा।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence into English:

"What is the serenity of mind? Is it goodheartedness? Is silence austerity? Is mental control self-control? What is purity of nature? Is it this or is it something else? Even austerity is called mental. Silence of speech is preceded by controlling thought, and the result is here used to stand for the cause, that is, controlling thought so far as it concerns speech. Mauna is the condition of the sage, that is, practice of meditation with one-pointedness of mind. Self-control is a general control of the mind. In Asamprajnata Samadhi, all modifications of the mind are controlled, and the mind cannot run after the senses, and the senses cannot run after their objects."

text:
अकीर्तिं चापि भूतानि कथयिष्यन्ति तेऽव्ययाम्।

संभावितस्य चाकीर्तिर्मरणादतिरिच्यते।।2.34।।
transliteration:
akīrtiṁ chāpi bhūtāni
kathayiṣhyanti te ’vyayām
sambhāvitasya chākīrtir
maraṇād atirichyate
word_meanings: akīrtim—infamy; cha—and; api—also; bhūtāni—people; kathayiṣhyanti—will speak; te—of your; avyayām—everlasting; sambhāvitasya—of a respectable person; cha—and; akīrtiḥ—infamy; maraṇāt—than death; atirichyate—is greater
translations: ।।2.34।। और सब प्राणी भी तेरी सदा रहनेवाली अपकीर्तिका कथन अर्थात निंदा करेंगे। वह अपकीर्ति सम्मानित मनुष्यके लिये मृत्युसे भी बढ़कर दुःखदायी होती है।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the sentence:

"With faith? परया highest? तप्तम् practised? तपः austerity? तत् that? त्रिविधम् threefold? नरैः by men? अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिः desiring no fruit? युक्तैः steadfast? सात्त्विकम् Sattvic? परिचक्षते (they) declare."

Here is the word-for-word translation:

1. श्रद्धया - Sraddhaya (With faith)
2. परया - Parayā (highest)
3. तप्तम् - Tapattam (practised)
4. तपः - Tapah (austerity)
5. तत् - Tat (that)
6. त्रिविधम् - Trividham (threefold)
7. नरैः - Naraiḥ (by men)
8. अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिः - Afalakāṅkṣibhiḥ (desiring no fruit)
9. युक्तैः - Yuktaiḥ (steadfast)
10. सात्त्विकम् - Sattvicam (Sattvic)
11. परिचक्षते - Parichakshate (they declare)

text:
भयाद्रणादुपरतं मंस्यन्ते त्वां महारथाः।

येषां च त्वं बहुमतो भूत्वा यास्यसि लाघवम्।।2.35।।
transliteration:
bhayād raṇād uparataṁ mansyante tvāṁ mahā-rathāḥ
yeṣhāṁ cha tvaṁ bahu-mato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam
word_meanings: bhayāt—out of fear; raṇāt—from the battlefield; uparatam—have fled; maṁsyante—will think; tvām—you; mahā-rathāḥ—warriors who could single handedly match the strength of ten thousand ordinary warriors; yeṣhām—for whom; cha—and; tvam—you; bahu-mataḥ—high esteemed; bhūtvā—having been; yāsyasi—you will loose; lāghavam—decreased in value
translations: ।।2.35।।  महारथीलोग तुझे भयके कारण युद्धसे उपरत (हटा) हुआ मानेंगे। जिनकी धारणामें तू बहुमान्य हो चुका है, उनकी दृष्टिमें तू लघुताको प्राप्त हो जायगा।
commentaries:
The given sentence in Hindi can be translated into English as:

"Penance that is performed without sincere belief, for mere show, or with a view to increase self-importance, yields fruit only in this world. A good Brahmana of great austerities is honored with rising from one's seat and saluting with reverence."

Here's the word-for-word translation:

17.18 सत्कारमानपूजार्थम् - penance for gaining good reception, honour and worship
तपः - austerity
दम्भेन - with hypocrisy
च - and
एव - even
यत् - which?
क्रियते - is practised?
तत् - that?
इह - here?
प्रोक्तम् - is said?
राजसम् - Rajasic (of a passionate nature)
चलम् - unstable
अध्रुवam - transitory

The commentary explains that penance performed without sincere belief or with ulterior motives bears no fruit and is of little use. It may even result in negative consequences. The phrase "without Niyama or fixity" highlights the importance of consistency and dedication in one's spiritual practices.

text:
अवाच्यवादांश्च बहून् वदिष्यन्ति तवाहिताः।

निन्दन्तस्तव सामर्थ्यं ततो दुःखतरं नु किम्।।2.36।।
transliteration:
avāchya-vādānśh cha bahūn vadiṣhyanti tavāhitāḥ
nindantastava sāmarthyaṁ tato duḥkhataraṁ nu kim
word_meanings: avāchya-vādān—using harsh words; cha—and; bahūn—many; vadiṣhyanti—will say; tava—your; ahitāḥ—enemies; nindantaḥ—defame; tava—your; sāmarthyam—might; tataḥ—than that; duḥkha-taram—more painful; nu—indeed; kim—what
translations: ।।2.36।। तेरे शत्रुलोग तेरी सार्मथ्यकी निन्दा करते हुए न कहनेयोग्य बहुत-से वचन भी कहेंगे। उससे बढ़कर और दुःखकी बात क्या होगी?
commentaries:
Sure, here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"17.19 out of a foolish notion? The self? Which? With torture? Is practised? Austerity? Of another? For the purpose of destroying? Or? That? Tamasic is declared."

Here's the word-for-word translation:

17.19 - मूढग्राहेण (muudhgraahen) = out of a foolish notion
आत्मनः (atmanah) = of the self
यत् (yat) = which
पीडया (piedyaa) = with torture
क्रियते (kriyehte) = is practised
तपः (tapah) = austerity
परस्य (parsya) = of another
उत्सादनार्थम् (utsadanartham) = for the purpose of destroying
वा (vaa) = or
तत् (tatt) = that
तामसम् (tamasam) = Tamasic (relating to darkness, ignorance, and inertia)
उदाहृतम् (udahritam) = is declared.

text:
हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम्।

तस्मादुत्तिष्ठ कौन्तेय युद्धाय कृतनिश्चयः।।2.37।।
transliteration:
hato vā prāpsyasi swargaṁ jitvā vā bhokṣhyase mahīm
tasmād uttiṣhṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛita-niśhchayaḥ
word_meanings: hataḥ—slain; vā—or; prāpsyasi—you will attain; swargam—celestial abodes; jitvā—by achieving victory; vā—or; bhokṣhyase—you shall enjoy; mahīm—the kingdom on earth; tasmāt—therefore; uttiṣhṭha—arise; kaunteya—Arjun, the son of Kunti; yuddhāya—for fight; kṛita-niśhchayaḥ—with determination
translations: ।।2.37।। अगर युद्धमें तू मारा जायगा तो तुझे स्वर्गकी प्राप्ति होगी और अगर युद्धमें तू जीत जायगा तो पृथ्वीका राज्य भोगेगा। अतः हे कुन्तीनन्दन! तू युद्धके लिये निश्चय करके खड़ा हो जा।
commentaries:
17.20 ought to be given? Thus? That? Gift? Is given? To one who does no service (in return)? In a fit place? In time? And? To a worthy person? That? Sattvic? Is held to be.

Translation: The gift should be given to someone who cannot repay the good or to someone from whom no such return is expected. It is necessary to give the gift in a sacred place like Kurukshetra or Varanasi, or any other auspicious location during solar or lunar eclips. The gift should be given to a pious person who is well-versed in the scriptures (the Vedas and the Vedangas), who is able to protect themselves and the donor, etc. At such a time and place, there should be a person who is worthy of receiving the gift, someone who is the very embodiment of purity and goodness. The donor should not boast of their charity.

text:
सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ।

ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व नैवं पापमवाप्स्यसि।।2.38।।
transliteration:
sukha-duḥkhe same kṛitvā lābhālābhau jayājayau
tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṁ pāpam avāpsyasi
word_meanings: sukha—happiness; duḥkhe—in distress; same kṛitvā—treating alike; lābha-alābhau—gain and loss; jaya-ajayau—victory and defeat; tataḥ—thereafter; yuddhāya—for fighting; yujyasva—engage; na—never; evam—thus; pāpam—sin; avāpsyasi—shall incur
translations: ।।2.38।। जय-पराजय, लाभ-हानि और सुख-दुःखको समान करके फिर युद्धमें लग जा। इस प्रकार युद्ध करनेसे तू पापको प्राप्त नहीं होगा।
commentaries:
17.21 यत् indeed?

प्रत्युपकारार्थम् with a view to receive in return?

फलम् fruit?

उद्दिश्य looking for?

वा or?

पुनः again?

दीयते is given?

च and?

परिक्लिष्टम् reluctantly?

तत् that?

दानam gift?

राजसम् Rajasic?

स्मृतम् is held to be.

text:
एषा तेऽभिहिता सांख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां श्रृणु।

बुद्ध्यायुक्तो यया पार्थ कर्मबन्धं प्रहास्यसि।।2.39।।
transliteration:
eṣhā te ’bhihitā sānkhye
buddhir yoge tvimāṁ śhṛiṇu
buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha
karma-bandhaṁ prahāsyasi
word_meanings: eṣhā—hitherto; te—to you; abhihitā—explained; sānkhye—by analytical knowledge; buddhiḥ yoge—by the yog of intellect; tu—indeed; imām—this; śhṛiṇu—listen; buddhyā—by understanding; yuktaḥ—united; yayā—by which; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; karma-bandham—bondage of karma; prahāsyasi—you shall be released from
translations: ।।2.39।। हे पार्थ! यह समबुद्धि तेरे लिए पहले सांख्ययोगमें कही गयी, अब तू इसको कर्मयोगके विषयमें सुन; जिस समबुद्धिसे युक्त हुआ तू कर्मबन्धनका त्याग कर देगा।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"At a wrong place and time, giving alms or other charity to the poor and needy is not restricted. However, if done without respect, pleasant speech, washing of feet, or worship, it does not count as true generosity, even if made at an appropriate time and place. The donor must give in good faith and treat the recipient with dignity, offering them a seat and showing them respect. Krishna explains to Arjuna that the qualities of faith, charity, and austerity are affected by the three attributes of passion, ignorance, and darkness. By setting aside these lower qualities, the third, or purest quality, becomes more clearly visible and attainable. Therefore, to illustrate the true nature of purity, Krishna describes the other two qualities."

text:
नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते।

स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात्।।2.40।।
transliteration:
nehābhikrama-nāśho ’sti pratyavāyo na vidyate
svalpam apyasya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt
word_meanings: na—not; iha—in this; abhikrama—efforts; nāśhaḥ—loss; asti—there is; pratyavāyaḥ—adverse result; na—not; vidyate—is; su-alpam—a little; api—even; asya—of this; dharmasya—occupation; trāyate—saves; mahataḥ—from great; bhayāt—danger
translations: ।।2.40।। मनुष्यलोकमें इस समबुद्धिरूप धर्मके आरम्भका नाश नहीं होता, इसके अनुष्ठानका उलटा फल भी नहीं होता और इसका थोड़ासा भी अनुष्ठान (जन्म-मरणरूप) महान् भयसे रक्षा कर लेता है।
commentaries:
Om Tat Sat is the root of the universe.
Om represents the unchanging, indefinable Brahman.
Tat means the Supreme Being, the abode of all living things.
Sat signifies reality.
Para Brahman refers to the supreme being beyond names and classes.
The Vedas have given a name to Him, but a newborn baby has no name and will answer according to its nature.
Men seek refuge in the deity by calling Him by His given name, revealing what is hidden within themselves.
These three words have divine power, arousing the latent divinity within and securing a response from the cosmic being they represent.
When a sacrifice or spiritual discipline is found defective, it can be perfected through the utterance of Om Tat Sat or one of the three designations.
With the repetition of Om or Om Tat Sat, all acts of sacrifice, study of sacred scriptures, and meditation are initiated.
Om Tat Sat has been declared to be the triple designation of Brahman in Vedanta by those who know Brahman.
The power of creation emanates from this mantra, and when repeated, the creator achieved the power to create.
Then he created the Brahmanas, gave them the Vedas as a guide, and directed them to perform sacrifices and other rites.

text:
व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन।

बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम्।।2.41।।
transliteration:
vyavasāyātmikā buddhir ekeha kuru-nandana
bahu-śhākhā hyanantāśh cha buddhayo ’vyavasāyinām
word_meanings: vyavasāya-ātmikā—resolute; buddhiḥ—intellect; ekā—single; iha—on this path; kuru-nandana—descendent of the Kurus; bahu-śhākhāḥ—many-branched; hi—indeed; anantāḥ—endless; cha—also; buddhayaḥ—intellect; avyavasāyinām—of the irresolute
translations: ।।2.41।। हे कुरुनन्दन! इस समबुद्धिकी प्राप्तिके विषयमें व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धि एक ही होती है। अव्यवसायी मनुष्योंकी बुद्धियाँ अनन्त और बहुशाखाओंवाली ही होती हैं।
commentaries:
The sentence "17.24 तस्मात् therefore? Om? इति thus? उदाहृत्य uttering?" can be translated into English as:

"Therefore, Om? Thus? Uttering?"

text:
यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः।

वेदवादरताः पार्थ नान्यदस्तीति वादिनः।।2.42।।
transliteration:
yāmimāṁ puṣhpitāṁ vāchaṁ pravadanty-avipaśhchitaḥ
veda-vāda-ratāḥ pārtha nānyad astīti vādinaḥ
 kāmātmānaḥ swarga-parā janma-karma-phala-pradām
kriyā-viśheṣha-bahulāṁ bhogaiśhwarya-gatiṁ prati
word_meanings:
yām imām—all these; puṣhpitām—flowery; vācham—words; pravadanti—speak; avipaśhchitaḥ—those with limited understanding; veda-vāda-ratāḥ—attached to the flowery words of the Vedas; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; na anyat—no other; asti—is; iti—thus; vādinaḥ—advocate;
 kāma-ātmānaḥ—desirous of sensual pleasure; swarga-parāḥ—aiming to achieve the heavenly planets; janma-karma-phala—high birth and fruitive results; pradāṁ—awarding; kriyā-viśheṣha—pompous ritualistic ceremonies; bahulām—various; bhoga—gratification; aiśhwarya—luxury; gatim—progress; prati—toward
translations: -. O son of Prtha! Those whose very nature is desire, whose goal is heaven, who esteem only the Vedic declaration [of fruits], who declare that there is nothing else, who proclaim this flowery speech about the paths to the lordship of the objects of enjoyment—paths that are full of different actions—and who desire action alone as a fruit of their birth—they are men without insight.
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

"17.25 That? इति thus? अनभिसन्धाय without aiming at? फलम् fruit? यज्ञतपःक्रियाः acts of sacrifice and austerity? दानक्रियाः acts of charity such as gifts of land? gold? rice? clothes? etc. The immortal Soul which transcends the whole world? the three Gunas? the three bodies? the three states of waking? dreaming and deep sleep? which illumines everything? which is the basis of all? and the source of everything is connoted by the word Tat. The sages and the aspirants meditate on Tat. They utter the word Tat and say? May all our actions and the fruits of them be in the name of Tat (That or Brahman). Thus they offer all actions and their fruits to Brahman and practise renunciation. They are freed from egoism and the bondage of Karma. They attain Self-realisation through purity of heart caused by selfless? motiveless and desireless actions. The actions that is ennobled and sanctified by uttering Om at the beginning and which is offered to That is transformed into the nature of Brahman. All actions in their entirety? O Arjuna? culminate in wisdom (IV.33). He who does the actions with the spirit of sacrifice becomes Brahman eventually."

text:
कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्मफलप्रदाम्।

क्रियाविशेषबहुलां भोगैश्वर्यगतिं प्रति।।2.43।।
transliteration:
kāmātmānaḥ svarga-parā 

 janma-karma-phala-pradām

 kriyā-viśeṣa-bahulāṁ

 bhogaiśvarya-gatiṁ prati
word_meanings: kāmaātmānaḥ—desirous   of  sense   gratification;  svarga-parāḥ—aiming to  achieve heavenly    planets;    janma-karma-phala-pradām—resulting  in  fruitive    action, good        birth,     etc.;      kriyā-viśeṣa—pompous       ceremonies;        bahulām—various; bhoga—sense       enjoyment;     aiśvarya—opulence;     gatim—progress;    prati—towards.
translations: Full of desires, with heaven as their goal, (they speak words that are directed to ends) leading to new births as the result of their works, and prescribe various methods abounding in specific actions, for the attainment of pleasure and power.
commentaries:
The given sentence in Hindi can be translated to English as:

"What is the reality of existence? Is it goodness or something else? Is 'च' (ch) used in this context? Is 'सत्' (Sat) used here? Is 'युज्यते' (yujyate) used in this sentence? Is 'प्रयुज्यते' (prayujyate) used to indicate auspiciousness? Is 'कर्मणि' (karmani) used in the sense of an action? Is 'तथा' (tatha) used to indicate equivalence? Is 'सत्' (Sat) used to refer to the ultimate reality? Is 'शब्दः' (shabdah) used to refer to a word? Is 'पार्थ' (Partha) used in this context? Does 'युज्यते' (yujyate) indicate the use of the word 'Sat'?"

In English, the sentence can be translated as:

"What is the reality of existence? Is it goodness or something else? Is 'CH' used in this context? Is 'SAT' used here? Is 'YUJYATE' used to indicate auspiciousness? Is 'KARMANI' used in the sense of an action? Is 'TAHTHA' used to indicate equivalence? Is 'SAT' used to refer to the ultimate reality? Is 'SHABDAH' used to refer to a word? Is 'PARTHA' used in this context? Does 'YUJYATE' indicate the use of the word 'SAT'?"

text:
भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानां तयापहृतचेतसाम्।

व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिः समाधौ न विधीयते।।2.44।।
transliteration:
bhogaiśwvarya-prasaktānāṁ tayāpahṛita-chetasām
vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate
word_meanings: bhoga—gratification; aiśhwarya—luxury; prasaktānām—whose minds are deeply attached; tayā—by that; apahṛita-chetasām—bewildered in intellect; vyavasāya-ātmikā—resolute; buddhiḥ—intellect; samādhau—fulfilment; na—never; vidhīyate—occurs
translations: One-pointed conviction does not become established in the minds of those who delight in enjoyment and affluence, and whose intellects are carried away by it.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"Will you perform sacrifice? austerity? gift and all actions in a spirit of total surrender to the Lord or the Eternal Being with purity and sincerity of heart? You will attain the highest goal of life or immortality? freedom and eternal bliss. If you do them in the name and for the sake of Brahman, you will attain perfection and supreme peace of the Absolute. If you pin your faith on the glory and power of this name Om or Om Tat Sat, you will be freed from the bondage of birth and death. Even if you perform any sacrifice? austerity or charity or any action in a selfless and motiveless spirit, surrendering all actions and their rewards to the Lord, and if you utter the word Sat with faith? feeling and devotion, you will attain perfection and success in the action. Even imperfect and non-Sattvic acts of sacrifice? austerity and gift will be turned into perfect and Sattvic ones."

text:
त्रैगुण्यविषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन।

निर्द्वन्द्वो नित्यसत्त्वस्थो निर्योगक्षेम आत्मवान्।।2.45।।
transliteration:
trai-guṇya-viṣhayā vedā nistrai-guṇyo bhavārjuna
nirdvandvo nitya-sattva-stho niryoga-kṣhema ātmavān
word_meanings: trai-guṇya—of the three modes of material nature; viṣhayāḥ—subject matter; vedāḥ—Vedic scriptures; nistrai-guṇyaḥ—above the three modes of material nature, transcendental; bhava—be; arjuna—Arjun; nirdvandvaḥ—free from dualities; nitya-sattva-sthaḥ—eternally fixed in truth; niryoga-kṣhemaḥ—unconcerned about gain and preservation; ātma-vān—situated in the self
translations: O Arjuna, the Vedas [Meaning only the portion dealing with rites and duties (karma-kanda).] have the three qualities as their object. You become free from worldliness, free from the pairs of duality, ever-poised in the quality of sattva, without (desire for) acquisition and protection, and self-collected.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"Without faith, sacrifice is meaningless. Austerity and gifts done without devotion to the Lord are futile. Energy, money, and time spent without faith are wasted. The Upanishads, the glorious Bhagavad Gita, and the science of Yoga teach that true sacrifice is not just external actions but requires faith and devotion to the Lord."

text:
यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः संप्लुतोदके।

तावान्सर्वेषु वेदेषु ब्राह्मणस्य विजानतः।।2.46।।
transliteration:
yāvān artha udapāne sarvataḥ samplutodake
tāvānsarveṣhu vedeṣhu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ
word_meanings: yāvān—whatever; arthaḥ—purpose; uda-pāne—a well of water; sarvataḥ—in all respects; sampluta-udake—by a large lake; tāvān—that many; sarveṣhu—in all; vedeṣhu—Vedas; brāhmaṇasya—one who realizes the Absolute Truth; vijānataḥ—who is in complete knowledge
translations: To the Brahmana who has known the Self, all the Vedas are of as much use as a reservoir of water would be in a place where there is a flood.
commentaries:
entirely into English and returns only the translated sentence:

The Lord describes the three types of nature that belong to sentient beings in the ninth discourse, including the nature of gods, Asuras, and Rakshasas. The divine nature leads to liberation, while the Asuric and Rakshasic natures lead to bondage. Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas are the three Gunas that make up the individual's nature, and each has its own characteristics. Sattva is fearlessness, purity of heart, and self-control, while Rajas is pride, ambition, and passion, and Tamas is darkness, inertia, and indolence. The Lord also describes the importance of cultivating Sattva qualities to attain salvation.

text:
कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन।

मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि।।2.47।।
transliteration:
karmaṇy-evādhikāras te mā phaleṣhu kadāchana
mā karma-phala-hetur bhūr mā te saṅgo ’stvakarmaṇi
word_meanings: karmaṇi—in prescribed duties; eva—only; adhikāraḥ—right; te—your; mā—not; phaleṣhu—in the fruits; kadāchana—at any time; mā—never; karma-phala—results of the activities; hetuḥ—cause; bhūḥ—be; mā—not; te—your; saṅgaḥ—attachment; astu—must be; akarmaṇi—in inaction
translations: Your right is only to work, but not to its results; do not let the results of action be your motive, nor let your attachment be to inaction.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the Hindi sentence into English:

16.2 Harmlessness? Truth? Absence of anger? Renunciation? Peacefulness? Absence of crookedness? Compassion? In beings? Noncovetousness? Gentleness? Modesty? Absence of fickleness?

Ahimsa: Noninjury in thought, word, and deed. By refraining from injuring living creatures, the outgoing forces of Rajas are curbed. Ahimsa is divided into physical, verbal, and mental.

Satyam: Truthfulness - speaking of things as they are, without uttering unpleasant words or lies. This includes self-restraint, absence of jealousy, forgiveness, patience, endurance, and kindness.

Akrodhah: Absence of anger when insulted, ridiculed, or beaten - even under the gravest provocation.

Tyagah: Renunciation - literally, giving up one's egoism and the fruits of action. Charity is also Tyaga. This has already been mentioned in the previous verse.

Santih: Serenity of mind.

Apaisunam: Absence of narrow-mindedness.

Daya: Compassion towards those who are in distress. A compassionate person has a tender heart, and he lives only for the benefit of the world. Compassion indicates realization of unity or oneness with other creatures.

Aloluptvam: Noncovetousness - the senses are not affected or excited when they come in contact with their respective objects; the senses are withdrawn from the objects of the senses, just as the limbs of the tortoise are withdrawn into its own shell.

Hrih: Shame felt in performing actions contrary to the rules of the Vedas or society.

Achapalam: Not to speak or move the hands and legs in vain avoidance of useless action.

Straightforwardness, noninjury, absence of anger, etc. are special attributes of Brahmanas. They are Sattvic virtues that belong to them.

text:
योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय।

सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते।।2.48।।
transliteration:
yoga-sthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā dhanañjaya
siddhy-asiddhyoḥ samo bhūtvā samatvaṁ yoga uchyate
word_meanings: yoga-sthaḥ—being steadfast in yog; kuru—perform; karmāṇi—duties; saṅgam—attachment; tyaktvā—having abandoned; dhanañjaya—Arjun; siddhi-asiddhyoḥ—in success and failure; samaḥ—equipoised; bhūtvā—becoming; samatvam—equanimity; yogaḥ—Yog; uchyate—is called
translations: ।।2.48।। हे धनञ्जय ! तू आसक्तिका त्याग करके सिद्धि-असिद्धिमें सम होकर योगमें स्थित हुआ कर्मोंको कर; क्योंकि समत्व ही योग कहा जाता है।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the sentence you provided:

"Tejas (vigour), Kshama (forgiveness), Dhriti (fortitude), Saucham (purity), Adroha (absence of hatred), Naatimanita (absence of over-pride), Bhavaanti (belong), Samapadam (state), Daivim (divine), Abhijati (born for the one), Bhava (exist), Nata (to the one born), Dharmas (virtues) are the special qualities of the Kshatriyas, Vaisyas, and Sudras. The divine wealth consists of 26 attributes and is an inexhaustible gift from the Lord, leading to the eternal bliss of Moksha."

text:
दूरेण ह्यवरं कर्म बुद्धियोगाद्धनञ्जय।

बुद्धौ शरणमन्विच्छ कृपणाः फलहेतवः।।2.49।।
transliteration:
dūreṇa hy-avaraṁ karma buddhi-yogād dhanañjaya
buddhau śharaṇam anvichchha kṛipaṇāḥ phala-hetavaḥ
word_meanings: dūreṇa—(discrad) from far away; hi—certainly; avaram—inferior; karma—reward-seeking actions; buddhi-yogāt—with the intellect established in Divine knowledge; dhanañjaya—Arjun; buddhau—divine knowledge and insight; śharaṇam—refuge; anvichchha—seek; kṛipaṇāḥ—miserly; phala-hetavaḥ—those seeking fruits of their work
translations: O Dhananjaya, indeed, action is inferior to the yoga of wisdom. Take refuge in wisdom. Those who thirst for rewards are pitiable.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"The six demonical alities are hypocrisy, arrogance, self-conceit, wrath, harshness, and ignorance. Even more so, there is an evil nature that is born to the one who is born for the purpose of the Asuras. People with an Asuric nature have no faith and dispute every doctrine. They do not believe in God or the cycle of the world process, and they are consumed by sensual indulgence. They rob people and take away their neighbors' wives, and they kill ruthlessly. They have no idea of right conduct, purity, or self-restraint."

text:
बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते।

तस्माद्योगाय युज्यस्व योगः कर्मसु कौशलम्।।2.50।।
transliteration:
buddhi-yukto jahātīha ubhe sukṛita-duṣhkṛite
tasmād yogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karmasu kauśhalam
word_meanings: buddhi-yuktaḥ—endowed with wisdom; jahāti—get rid of; iha—in this life; ubhe—both; sukṛita-duṣhkṛite—good and bad deeds; tasmāt—therefore; yogāya—for Yog; yujyasva—strive for; yogaḥ—yog is; karmasu kauśhalam—the art of working skillfully
translations: ।।2.50।। बुद्धि-(समता) से युक्त मनुष्य यहाँ जीवित अवस्थामें ही पुण्य और पाप दोनोंका त्याग कर देता है। अतः तू योग-(समता-) में लग जा, क्योंकि योग ही कर्मोंमें कुशलता है।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"16.5 divine? state? for liberation? निबन्धाय for bondage? the demoniacal? is deemed? not? grieve? सम्पदम् state? the divine? born for? thou art? O Pandava. Commentary Sampat Endowment? wealthy state? nature? virtue. Moksha Liberation from the bondage of Samsara? release from the round of birth and death. The divine nature leads to salvation, while the demonic nature leads to bondage. As Arjuna was already grief-stricken and dejected, Lord Krishna assured him not to feel alarmed at this description of the Asuric qualities that bring grief and delusion, for he was born with Sattvic tendencies leading towards salvation. Arjuna, upon hearing the words of Lord Krishna, may have thought to himself, 'Do I possess divine nature or demonic nature? The Lord said, 'Grieve not, O Arjuna, thou art born with divine qualities. Thou art fortunate, and thou mayest attain to the happiness of Self-realization.' Do not think that by engaging yourself in battle and killing people, you will become an Asura. Grieve not on this score. You will establish the kingdom of righteousness by fighting this righteous battle."

text:
कर्मजं बुद्धियुक्ता हि फलं त्यक्त्वा मनीषिणः।

जन्मबन्धविनिर्मुक्ताः पदं गच्छन्त्यनामयम्।।2.51।।
transliteration:
karma-jaṁ buddhi-yuktā hi phalaṁ tyaktvā manīṣhiṇaḥ
janma-bandha-vinirmuktāḥ padaṁ gachchhanty-anāmayam
word_meanings: karma-jam—born of fruitive actions; buddhi-yuktāḥ—endowed with equanimity of intellect; hi—as; phalam—fruits; tyaktvā—abandoning; manīṣhiṇaḥ—the wise; janma-bandha-vinirmuktāḥ—freedom from the bondage of life and death; padam—state; gachchhanti—attain; anāmayam—devoid of sufferings
translations: ।।2.51।। समतायुक्त मनीषी साधक कर्मजन्य फलका त्याग करके जन्मरूप बन्धनसे मुक्त होकर निर्विकार पदको प्राप्त हो जाते हैं।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"There are two creations of beings - divine and demonic. Everyone in this world comes under one or the other of these creations. I will now describe to you the characteristics of those endowed with demonic qualities, so that you may avoid them. The demonic nature is described in detail until the end of this discourse, as there is some reference to it in chapter IX, verses 9-11 and 12, but the description is incomplete, so it is being completed here."

text:
यदा ते मोहकलिलं बुद्धिर्व्यतितरिष्यति।

तदा गन्तासि निर्वेदं श्रोतव्यस्य श्रुतस्य च।।2.52।।
transliteration:
yadā te moha-kalilaṁ buddhir vyatitariṣhyati
tadā gantāsi nirvedaṁ śhrotavyasya śhrutasya cha
word_meanings: yadā—when; te—your; moha—delusion; kalilam—quagmire; buddhiḥ—intellect; vyatitariṣhyati—crosses; tadā—then; gantāsi—you shall acquire; nirvedam—indifferent; śhrotavyasya—to what is yet to be heard; śhrutasya—to what has been heard; cha—and
translations: When your mind goes beyond the turbidity of delusion, then you will acquire dispassion for what has to be heard and what has already been heard.
commentaries:
The sentence "16.7 प्रवृत्तिम् action? च and? निवृत्तिम् inaction? च and? जनाः men? न not? विदुः know? आसुराः the demoniac? न not? शौचम् purity? न not? अपि also? च and? आचारः (right) conduct? न not? सत्यम् truth? तेषु in them? विद्यते is." has been translated into English as follows:

"The demoniacal do not understand the nature of action and inaction (right abstinence). They have no consideration for others' interests. They work for their own bodies or sensual enjoyment. They are greedy, selfish, and cruel. Therefore, they have neither good conduct nor good behavior. They are untruthful, unjust, and impure. They do not know what actions they should perform to attain the goal of life or end of human existence, nor from what actions they should refrain to avoid evil. Those who are endowed with demoniacal qualities are sunk in the mire of ignorance. They are totally ignorant of what is prescribed or prohibited action. They have no idea of purity or cleanliness. Their actions are crooked. They know neither right Pravritti nor right Nivritti. They have no idea of virtue or vice, or of scriptural injunctions or prohibitions. They will never speak loving words. They are hypocrites and liars."

text:
श्रुतिविप्रतिपन्ना ते यदा स्थास्यति निश्चला।

समाधावचला बुद्धिस्तदा योगमवाप्स्यसि।।2.53।।
transliteration:
śhruti-vipratipannā te yadā sthāsyati niśhchalā
samādhāv-achalā buddhis tadā yogam avāpsyasi
word_meanings: śhruti-vipratipannā—not allured by the fruitive sections of the Vedas; te—your; yadā—when; sthāsyati—remains; niśhchalā—steadfast; samādhau—in divine consciousness; achalā—steadfast; buddhiḥ—intellect; tadā—at that time; yogam—Yog; avāpsyasi—you will attain
translations: ।।2.53।। जिस कालमें शास्त्रीय मतभेदोंसे विचलित हुई तेरी बुद्धि निश्चल हो जायगी और परमात्मामें अचल हो जायगी, उस कालमें तू योगको प्राप्त हो जायगा।
commentaries:
The sentence "16.8 असत्यम् without truth? अप्रतिष्ठam् without (moral) basis? they? जगत् the world? आहुः say? अनीश्वरम् without a God? अपरस्परसम्भूतम् brought about by mutual union?" can be translated into English as:

"16.8 Without truth? Without (moral) basis? They? The world? Do they say? Without a God? Brought about by mutual union?"

In this sentence, the following words are used in Hindi and their English translations are provided:

* असत्यम् (asatyam) - without truth
* अप्रतिष्ठम् (apratishtham) - without (moral) basis
* ते (te) - they
* जगत् (jagat) - world
* आहुः (aham) - they
* अनीश्वरम् (anishvaram) - without a God
* अपरस्परसम्भूतम् (aparasparsambhutam) - brought about by mutual union
* किम् (ki) - what
* अन्यत (anyat) - else
* कामहैतुकम् (kamaheytukam) - with lust for its cause.

text:
अर्जुन उवाच

स्थितप्रज्ञस्य का भाषा समाधिस्थस्य केशव।

स्थितधीः किं प्रभाषेत किमासीत व्रजेत किम्।।2.54।।
transliteration:
arjuna uvācha
sthita-prajñasya kā bhāṣhā samādhi-sthasya keśhava
sthita-dhīḥ kiṁ prabhāṣheta kim āsīta vrajeta kim
word_meanings: arjunaḥ uvācha—Arjun said; sthita-prajñasya—one with steady intellect; kā—what; bhāṣhā—talk; samādhi-sthasya—situated in divine consciousness; keśhava—Shree Krishna, killer of the Keshi Demon; sthita-dhīḥ—enlightened person; kim—what; prabhāṣheta—talks; kim—how; āsīta—sits; vrajeta—walks; kim—how
translations: ।।2.54।। अर्जुन बोले - हे केशव ! परमात्मामें स्थित स्थिर बुद्धिवाले मनुष्यके क्या लक्षण होते हैं? वह स्थिर बुद्धिवाला मनुष्य कैसे बोलता है, कैसे बैठता है और कैसे चलता है?
commentaries:
16.9 एताम् this?

This means "What is the meaning of 16.9?"

दृष्टिम् view?

This means "What do you see?" or "What is your perspective?"

अवष्टभ्य holding?

This means "Why are you holding on to something?" or "What are you grasping onto?"

नष्टात्मानः ruined souls?

This means "Ruined souls" or "Souls that have been corrupted."

अल्पबुद्धयः of small intellect?

This means "Those with a limited understanding" or "People with a small mind."

प्रभवन्ति come forth?

This means "Are you coming forward?" or "What are you bringing forth?"

उग्रकर्माणः of fierce deeds?

This means "Deeds that are violent or aggressive" or "Actions that are intense or harsh."

क्षयाय for the destruction?

This means "What is the cause of destruction?" or "What brings about ruin?"

जगतः of the world?

This means "The world" or "The universe."

अहिताः enemies.

This means "Enemies" or "Opponents."

text:
श्री भगवानुवाच

प्रजहाति यदा कामान् सर्वान् पार्थ मनोगतान्।

आत्मन्येवात्मना तुष्टः स्थितप्रज्ञस्तदोच्यते।।2.55।।
transliteration:
śhrī bhagavān uvācha
prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha mano-gatān
ātmany-evātmanā tuṣhṭaḥ sthita-prajñas tadochyate
word_meanings: śhrī-bhagavān uvācha—The Supreme Lord said; prajahāti—discards; yadā—when; kāmān—selfish desires; sarvān—all; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; manaḥ-gatān—of the mind; ātmani—of the self; eva—only; ātmanā—by the purified mind; tuṣhṭaḥ—satisfied; sthita-prajñaḥ—one with steady intellect; tadā—at that time; uchyate—is said
translations: ।।2.55।। श्रीभगवान् बोले - हे पृथानन्दन ! जिस कालमें साधक मनोगत सम्पूर्ण कामनाओंका अच्छी तरह त्याग कर देता है और अपने-आपसे अपने-आपमें ही सन्तुष्ट रहता है, उस कालमें वह स्थितप्रज्ञ कहा जाता है।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"16.10 desire? abiding in? insatiable? full of hypocrisy? pride and arrogance? through delusion? having held? evil ideas? they work? with impure resolves."

Translation:

"Desire is insatiable like fire, enjoyment cannot satisfy the desires, the more you enjoy, the stronger the desire becomes, after enjoying an object, a desire to continue the enjoyment forever arises, various devices are used to preserve the objects, although a person is not righteous, he pretends to be righteous, there is false dignity, although a person does not possess great things, he superimposes them on himself, these Asuras make impure resolutions, I will worship such and such a deity by repeating such and such a Mantra and gain hold of such and such a woman, I will repeat such and such a Mantra and kill such and such a man."

text:
दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः।

वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते।।2.56।।
transliteration:
duḥkheṣhv-anudvigna-manāḥ sukheṣhu vigata-spṛihaḥ
vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhaḥ sthita-dhīr munir uchyate
word_meanings: duḥkheṣhu—amidst miseries; anudvigna-manāḥ—one whose mind is undisturbed; sukheṣhu—in pleasure; vigata-spṛihaḥ—without craving; vīta—free from; rāga—attachment; bhaya—fear; krodhaḥ—anger; sthita-dhīḥ—enlightened person; muniḥ—a sage; uchyate—is called
translations: ।।2.56।। दुःखोंकी प्राप्ति होनेपर जिसके मनमें उद्वेग नहीं होता और सुखोंकी प्राप्ति होनेपर जिसके मनमें स्पृहा नहीं होती तथा जो राग, भय और क्रोधसे सर्वथा रहित हो गया है, वह मननशील मनुष्य स्थिरबुद्धि कहा जाता है।
commentaries:
16.11 cares?
अपरिमेयाम् immeasurable?
च and?
प्रलयान्तम् ending only with death?
उपाश्रिताः refuged in?
कामोपभोगपरमाः regarding gratification of lust as their highest aim?
एतावत् that is all?
इति thus?
निश्चिताः feeling sure.

text:
यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम्।

नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता।।2.57।।
transliteration:
yaḥ sarvatrānabhisnehas tat tat prāpya śhubhāśhubham
nābhinandati na dveṣhṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣhṭhitā
word_meanings: yaḥ—who; sarvatra—in all conditions; anabhisnehaḥ—unattached; tat—that; tat—that; prāpya—attaining; śhubha—good; aśhubham—evil; na—neither; abhinandati—delight in; na—nor; dveṣhṭi—dejected by; tasya—his; prajñā—knowledge; pratiṣhṭhitā—is fixed
translations: ।।2.57।। सब जगह आसक्तिरहित हुआ जो मनुष्य उस-उस शुभ-अशुभको प्राप्त करके न तो अभिनन्दित होता है और न द्वेष करता है, उसकी बुद्धि प्रतिष्ठित है।
commentaries:
16.12 आशापाशशतैः - by a hundred ties of hope?
बद्धाः - bound?
कामक्रोधपरायणाः - given over to lust and anger?
ईहन्ते (they) - strive (to attain)?
कामभोगार्थम् - for sensual enjoyment?
अन्यायेन - by unlawful means?
अर्थसञ्चयान् - hoards of wealth.

text:
यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः।

इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता।।2.58।।
transliteration:
yadā sanharate chāyaṁ kūrmo ’ṅgānīva sarvaśhaḥ
indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣhṭhitā
word_meanings: yadā—when; sanharate—withdraw; cha—and; ayam—this; kūrmaḥ—tortoise; aṅgāni—limbs; iva—as; sarvaśhaḥ—fully; indriyāṇi—senses; indriya-arthebhyaḥ—from the sense objects; tasya—his; prajñā—divine wisdom; pratiṣhṭhitā—fixed in
translations: ।।2.58।। जिस तरह कछुआ अपने अङ्गोंको सब ओरसे समेट लेता है, ऐसे ही जिस कालमें यह कर्मयोगी इन्द्रियोंके विषयोंसे इन्द्रियोंको सब प्रकारसे समेट लेता (हटा लेता) है, तब उसकी बुद्धि प्रतिष्ठित हो जाती है।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"I will acquire all that the world possesses. Then I will be the lord of all wealth. No one will be equal to me on the surface of this earth. In the future, next year's wealth will also be mine. I will be known to the world as a man of immense wealth. People will address me as my lord. Those demons who think like this become self-conceited due to their wealth. Their heads are swollen with pride. They regard everyone else as worthless as straw. Pride of wealth destroys their power of discrimination. They strive for happiness but they never obtain it. They are entangled in the meshes of Maya. They are wedded to sin and misery both here and hereafter."

text:
विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः।

रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते।।2.59।।
transliteration:
viṣhayā vinivartante nirāhārasya dehinaḥ
rasa-varjaṁ raso ’pyasya paraṁ dṛiṣhṭvā nivartate
word_meanings: viṣhayāḥ—objects for senses; vinivartante—restrain; nirāhārasya—practicing self restraint; dehinaḥ—for the embodied; rasa-varjam—cessation of taste; rasaḥ—taste; api—however; asya—person’s; param—the Supreme; dṛiṣhṭvā—on realization; nivartate—ceases to be
translations: Leaving their taste behind, the sense-objects retreat from the embodied one who abstains from food; his taste too disappears when he beholds the Supreme.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"I will be the lord of all I survey. I will kill everyone who will not serve me. In fact, I am the lord of all creation. I will be successful in all my undertakings. I have got plenty of landed property, cattle, and immense wealth. I have got plenty of children and grandchildren. Even Indra is not equal to me. I am not an ordinary man. I am very powerful, strong, healthy, and happy in every respect."

text:
यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः।

इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मनः।।2.60।।
transliteration:
yatato hyapi kaunteya puruṣhasya vipaśhchitaḥ
indriyāṇi pramāthīni haranti prasabhaṁ manaḥ
word_meanings: yatataḥ—while practicing self-control; hi—for; api—even; kaunteya—Arjun, the son of Kunti; puruṣhasya—of a person; vipaśhchitaḥ—one endowed with discrimination; indriyāṇi—the senses; pramāthīni—turbulent; haranti—carry away; prasabham—forcibly; manaḥ—the mind
translations: The turbulent senses, O Arjuna, can violently carry away the mind of a wise person, even though they are striving to control them.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"Am I rich? Well-born? I am. Who is there in the whole world equal to me? Born in a family learned in the scriptures for seven generations. None is equal to me in this respect. I will perform sacrificial rites to gain name and fame. None is equal to me in this respect also. I will give money and presents to those who entertain me with dance, music, and songs in praise of me. None is equal to me in charity (giving) also. I will indulge in eating, drinking, and women."

text:
तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः।

वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता।।2.61।।
transliteration:
tāni sarvāṇi sanyamya yukta āsīta mat-paraḥ
vaśhe hi yasyendriyāṇi tasya prajñā pratiṣhṭhitā
word_meanings: tāni—them; sarvāṇi—all; sanyamya—subduing; yuktaḥ—united; āsīta—seated; mat-paraḥ—toward me (Shree Krishna); vaśhe—control; hi—certainly; yasya—whose; indriyāṇi—senses; tasya—their; prajñā—perfect knowledge pratiṣhṭhitā
translations: Having restrained them all, he should sit steadfast, intent on Me; his wisdom is steady whose senses are under control.
commentaries:
The sentence "16.16 अनेकचित्तविभ्रान्ताः bewildred by many a fancy? मोहजालसमावृताः entangled in the snare of delusion? प्रasakti intoxicated? कामभोगेषु to the gratification of lust? पतन्ति (they) fall? नरके into hell?" has been translated as follows:

"Bewildered by many desires, entangled in the snare of delusion, intoxicated, indulging in lustful gratification, falling, and entering hell."

text:
ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते।

सङ्गात् संजायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते।।2.62।।
transliteration:
dhyāyato viṣhayān puṁsaḥ saṅgas teṣhūpajāyate
saṅgāt sañjāyate kāmaḥ kāmāt krodho ’bhijāyate
word_meanings: dhyāyataḥ—contemplating; viṣhayān—sense objects; puṁsaḥ—of a person; saṅgaḥ—attachment; teṣhu—to them (sense objects); upajāyate—arises; saṅgāt—from attachment; sañjāyate—develops; kāmaḥ—desire; kāmāt—from desire; krodhaḥ—anger; abhijāyate—arises
translations: When one thinks of objects, attachment to them arises; from attachment, desire is born; from desire, anger arises.
commentaries:
Sure! Here's the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"They are puffed up with unbounded pride. They highly esteem themselves. They are not honored or respected by the righteous or pious. Their minds are filled with a sense of their own importance. They treat others with contempt, thinking them inferior. They stand erect like a pillar, intoxicated with wealth. They pretend to perform sacrifices but ignore the proper materials and rules. They perform sacrifices to increase their fame, not out of reverence or faith. Their pride consists in supposing themselves worthy of high honor due to wealth or learning. Wealth and learning have turned their heads, leading to intoxication (Mada)."

text:
क्रोधाद्भवति संमोहः संमोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः।

स्मृतिभ्रंशाद् बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति।।2.63।।
transliteration:
krodhād bhavati sammohaḥ sammohāt smṛiti-vibhramaḥ
smṛiti-bhranśhād buddhi-nāśho buddhi-nāśhāt praṇaśhyati
word_meanings: krodhāt—from anger; bhavati—comes; sammohaḥ—clouding of judgement; sammohāt—from clouding of judgement; smṛiti—memory; vibhramaḥ—bewilderment; smṛiti-bhranśhāt—from bewilderment of memory; buddhi-nāśhaḥ—destruction of intellect; buddhi-nāśhāt—from destruction of intellect; praṇaśhyati—one is ruined
translations: Anger leads to delusion, which causes the loss of memory; the loss of memory leads to the destruction of discrimination, and with the destruction of discrimination, one is lost.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

16.18 Egoism? Power? Haughtiness? Lust? Anger? Pride? Hypocrisy? These Asuras (demons) are self-sufficient and puffed up with mental and material power, posing too much, resenting it much if belittled, living solely for their bodies, using brutal force to gain selfish ends, abusing and ill-treating those who are truthful and charitable towards Me.

Egoism is the self-arrogating principle, the effect or modification of ignorance, the source of all defects and perversities in human nature and evil actions. Lust, anger, greed, pride, and hypocrisy are all attendants of egoism. It is difficult to overcome this dire enemy, but through vichara (right enquiry), it can be annihilated.

The Asuras have deep ignorance, esteeming themselves highly for their attributes and those they falsely superimpose upon themselves. They use their financial supremacy to humiliate and destroy others, bribing people to give false evidence and misusing their powers to attain selfish ends.

Power, accompanied by lust and attachment, is used to humiliate and destroy others. If a person does not have purity of heart, mind surcharged with evil tendencies, or practices concentration of mind without establishing themselves in Yama (the fivefold canon of ethical perfection consisting of non-injury, truthfulness, non-stealing, celibacy, and non-covetousness), they will misuse or abuse their powers and try to humiliate or abuse others.

Haughtiness is a man whose heart is filled with haughtiness, becoming insolent and unjust, assuming an overbearing and domineering attitude towards others, never respecting elders or Gurus. This is a peculiar vice that has its seat in the mind, causing one to swerve from the path of virtue when it manifests itself.

Anger manifests itself when one gets something unpleasant or comes across something disagreeable.

The Asuras hate Me, the Lord who dwells in their own bodies as the silent witness of their thoughts and actions, thinking that I am also a human being and hate Me. They do not understand My all-pervading and imperishable nature, and they do not care at all to know and follow My injunctions given in the Vedas and the Smritis. If anyone violates My injunctions, it is surely tantamount to an act of hatred towards Me. These people are very malicious and have evil intentions or impure motives. They are jealous of those persons who are virtuous and tread the path of righteousness, their hearts burning when they notice good attributes in others, which is Matsarya, a form of jealousy. If a man superimposes evil attributes on a virtuous man who is endowed with good attributes, this is Asuya. If his heart burns when he sees a wealthy or prosperous man, this is Irshya.

text:
रागद्वेषवियुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन्।

आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति।।2.64।।
transliteration:
rāga-dveṣha-viyuktais tu viṣhayān indriyaiśh charan
ātma-vaśhyair-vidheyātmā prasādam adhigachchhati
word_meanings: rāga—attachment; dveṣha—aversion; viyuktaiḥ—free; tu—but; viṣhayān—objects of the senses; indriyaiḥ—by the senses; charan—while using; ātma-vaśhyaiḥ—controlling one’s mind; vidheya-ātmā—one who controls the mind; prasādam—the Grace of God; adhigachchhati—attains
translations: But the self-controlled soul, who moves among sense objects, free from attachment or repulsion, wins eternal peace.
commentaries:
The sentence "16.19 तान् those? अहम् I? द्विषतः (the) hating (ones)? क्रूरान् cruel? संसारेषु in the worlds? नराधमान् worst among men? क्षिपामि (I) hurl? अजस्रम् for ever? अशुभान् evildoers? आसुरीषु of demons? एव only? योनिषु in wombs." can be translated into English as:

"Those? Am I? Hating (ones)? Cruel? In the worlds? Worst among men? I hurl? Forever? Evildoers? Of demons? Only? In wombs."

text:
प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते।

प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धिः पर्यवतिष्ठते।।2.65।।
transliteration:
prasāde sarva-duḥkhānāṁ hānir asyopajāyate
prasanna-chetaso hyāśhu buddhiḥ paryavatiṣhṭhate
word_meanings: prasāde—by divine grace; sarva—all; duḥkhānām—of sorrows; hāniḥ—destruction; asya—his; upajāyate—comes; prasanna-chetasaḥ—with a tranquil mind; hi—indeed; āśhu—soon; buddhiḥ—intellect; paryavatiṣhṭhate—becomes firmly established
translations: Upon attaining serenity, all miseries are extinguished in succession; the ability to make decisions is quickly stabilized in the mind of one who is serene.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

The degraded Asuras are cast into demoniacal wombs. They are reduced to the lowest condition or the most appalling state. They are cast into utter darkness and fall into lower wombs in response to their own satanic desires and actions, and their extreme Tamasic nature. From the birth of a tiger, they will get the birth of a serpent, from that, they will get the birth of a worm, and so on. In Sanskrit, the suffix "Tara" denotes comparative degree, and "Tama" is superlative degree. These people get the lowest wombs. They do not reach Me as their minds are filled with impurities, as they do not tread the path of righteousness in accordance with the injunctions of the scriptures. The diabolical nature is inimical to spiritual progress, so you will have to annihilate the evil tendencies by cultivating divine attributes and practicing regular meditation. Only then will you attain liberation.

text:
नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना।

न चाभावयतः शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतः सुखम्।।2.66।।
transliteration:
nāsti buddhir-ayuktasya na chāyuktasya bhāvanā
na chābhāvayataḥ śhāntir aśhāntasya kutaḥ sukham
word_meanings: na—not; asti—is; buddhiḥ—intellect; ayuktasya—not united; na—not; cha—and; ayuktasya—not united; bhāvanā—contemplation; na—nor; cha—and; abhāvayataḥ—for those not united; śhāntiḥ—peace; aśhāntasya—of the unpeaceful; kutaḥ—where; sukham—happiness
translations: There is no Buddhi for the unintegrated, nor is there contemplation of the self for him, and without contemplation of the self, there is no peace; and for one who lacks peace, where is the happiness?
commentaries:
The given sentence in Hindi is:

16.21 त्रिविधम् triple? नरकस्य of hell? इदम् this? द्वारम् gate? नाशनम् destructive? आत्मनः of the self? कामः lust? क्रोधः anger? तथा also? लोभः greed? तस्मात् therefore? एतत् this? त्रयam् three? त्यजेत् (one) should abandon.

And here is the direct translation of the sentence into English:

Triple? hell? what is this? gate? self-destruction? lust? anger? greed? therefore? abandon it? three? one should renounce.

text:
इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते।

तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि।।2.67।।
transliteration:
indriyāṇāṁ hi charatāṁ yan mano ’nuvidhīyate
tadasya harati prajñāṁ vāyur nāvam ivāmbhasi
word_meanings: indriyāṇām—of the senses; hi—indeed; charatām—roaming; yat—which; manaḥ—the mind; anuvidhīyate—becomes constantly engaged; tat—that; asya—of that; harati—carries away; prajñām—intellect; vāyuḥ—wind; nāvam—boat; iva—as; ambhasi—on the water
translations: For, when the mind follows the senses, experiencing their objects, his understanding is carried away by them, just as the wind carries away a ship on the waters.
commentaries:
The sentence "16.22 एतैः from these? विमुक्तः liberated? कौन्तेय O Kaunteya? तमोद्वारैः gates to darkness? त्रिभिः (by) three? नरः the man? आचरतi practises? आत्मनः for him? श्रेयः what is good? ततः and then? याति goes to? पराम् the Supreme? गतिम् Goal." has been translated as follows:

"What about these gates of darkness? Can one be liberated? Oh Kaunteya! Abandoning these gates of darkness, the path to salvation becomes clear for the seeker. He gets the company of sages, which leads to liberation. He listens to spiritual instructions, practices them, reflects on the scriptures, and attains Self-realization. The gate of darkness leading to hell, which is full of pain and delusion."

text:
तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः।

इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता।।2.68।।
transliteration:
tasmād yasya mahā-bāho nigṛihītāni sarvaśhaḥ
indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣhṭhitā
word_meanings: tasmāt—therefore; yasya—whose; mahā-bāho—mighty-armed one; nigṛihītāni—restrained; sarvaśhaḥ—completely; indriyāṇi—senses; indriya-arthebhyaḥ—from sense objects; tasya—of that person; prajñā—transcendental knowledge; pratiṣhṭhitā—remains fixed
translations: Therefore, O mighty-armed one, he whose senses are restrained from going after their objects on all sides, his wisdom is firmly established.
commentaries:
The sentence in English is:

"Who does not care for the Self, who gives free rein to these three sins, is a traitor to the Self. He who has renounced the authority of the Vedas, which are like a mother to all and point out what is good and what is evil, does not attain perfection nor happiness nor the Supreme Goal. He who pays no attention to prescribed actions and follows the promptings of desire awakened by the senses does not obtain God."

text:
या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी।

यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः।।2.69।।
transliteration:
yā niśhā sarva-bhūtānāṁ tasyāṁ jāgarti sanyamī
yasyāṁ jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśhā paśhyato muneḥ
word_meanings: yā—which; niśhā—night; sarva-bhūtānām—of all living beings; tasyām—in that; jāgarti—is awake; sanyamī—self-controlled; yasyām—in which; jāgrati—are awake; bhūtāni—creatures; sā—that; niśhā—night; paśhyataḥ—see; muneḥ—sage
translations: That which is night to all beings, in that the self-controlled man is awake; when all beings are awake, that is night for the sage who sees.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the sentence you provided:

"One should not disregard the scriptures' teachings, for a man who is anxious to obtain eternal bliss should respect the Vedas and the Smritis, which lay down the code of right conduct. He should readily renounce whatever the scriptures teach him to abandon and accept whatever he is directed to accept. The scriptures are kinder than a mother, as they restrain us from doing evil and bestow on us the greatest good (liberation or Moksha). Therefore, treat the scriptures with great respect."

text:

समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत्।

तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे

स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी।।2.70।।
transliteration:
āpūryamāṇam achala-pratiṣhṭhaṁ
samudram āpaḥ praviśhanti yadvat
tadvat kāmā yaṁ praviśhanti sarve
sa śhāntim āpnoti na kāma-kāmī
word_meanings: āpūryamāṇam—filled from all sides; achala-pratiṣhṭham—undisturbed; samudram—ocean; āpaḥ—waters; praviśhanti—enter; yadvat—as; tadvat—likewise; kāmāḥ—desires; yam—whom; praviśhanti—enter; sarve—all; saḥ—that person; śhāntim—peace; āpnoti—attains; na—not; kāma-kāmī—one who strives to satisfy desires
translations: He attains peace into whom desires flow as rivers into the ocean, which, though brimming with water, remains ever the same; not he whom desires carry away.
commentaries:
The sentence in English would be:

15.1 The peepul tree is rooted above, while its branches are below. The Asvattha is the support of everything, eternal and great. Brahman is the root of this tree, and it is called Urdhva. Samsara is the cosmic manifestation, and it has its roots in Brahman. The name Asvattha means not standing or enduring, and it is appropriate for this worldtree that is ever changing and passing away. The Lord teaches Arjuna about the nature of Brahman and the path to union with Him, describing Samsara as a peepul tree to create non-attachment. He who knows this tree and its root is a knower of the Vedas and omniscient.

text:
विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः।

निर्ममो निरहंकारः स शांतिमधिगच्छति।।2.71।।
transliteration:
vihāya kāmān yaḥ sarvān pumānśh charati niḥspṛihaḥ
nirmamo nirahankāraḥ sa śhāntim adhigachchhati
word_meanings: vihāya—giving up; kāmān—material desires; yaḥ—who; sarvān—all; pumān—a person; charati—lives; niḥspṛihaḥ—free from hankering; nirmamaḥ—without a sense of proprietorship; nirahankāraḥ—without egoism; saḥ—that person; śhāntim—perfect peace; adhigachchhati—attains
translations: That person, who, by abandoning all desires, consumes [objects] without longing, without a sense of ownership, and without egotism, attains peace.
commentaries:
The sentence in English translation is:

The countless objects, big and small, that life requires are all produced by the five elements through the action of the alities. This tree of Samsara is nourished by the three Nature-ally traits. The sense objects are its buds, and the roots that grow downward are the bonds of karma for those who lead a life of passion and attachment in this world, who are under the influence of likes and dislikes. The sprouts of this magnificent tree are the attractive sensory objects with their characteristics of sound, touch, color, taste, and smell. The roots—the karmic tendencies from past lives—grow downward to generate the bonds of karma in the world of men, strengthening them further through action.

The primal root is ignorance, from which emerges the eightfold Nature—the five elements, mind, intellect, and egoism. From the stem of the tree spring four branches called Svedaja, Andaja, Jarayuja, and Udbhijja. Eighty-four lakhs (eight million and four hundred thousand) of species have evolved. One branch shoots straight upward, yielding the fruit of enjoyment in heaven. Another branch is the branch of dispassion, yielding the fruit of Self-realization. The sun, planets, manes, and sages have also emerged from this wonderful tree. Above them are the branches of the worlds of Indra and the gods. Still higher are those of the sages and the men of austerities and penance. Still higher is the Satyaloka where Hiranyagarbha dwells.

Whatever regions are attained in accordance with one's nature of knowledge or action are the branching paths of the tree of Samsara. They are nourished and fattened by the three Gunas, which form their material basis. The sense objects—such as sound, touch, color, taste, and smell—represent the buds that sprout from the physical bodies, which are the products of actions.

The highest root of this magnificent tree is Brahman. The secondary roots are the latent impressions (Samskaras) of likes and dislikes, which spread in this world of men and impel them to perform virtuous and vicious actions and bind them fast to actions.

Now listen to the way by which this tree can be cut off. Only he who thus cuts his bondage to this tree of Samsara can be happy even in this world. He has the highest wisdom, for he stands as a spectator of this tree and knows it as it is, without being tied to it.

text:
एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति।

word_meanings: eṣhā—such; brāhmī sthitiḥ—state of God-realization; pārtha—Arjun, the son of Pritha; na—never; enām—this; prāpya—having attained; vimuhyati—is deluded; sthitvā—being established; asyām—in this; anta-kāle—at the hour of death; api—even; brahma-nirvāṇam—liberation from Maya; ṛichchhati—attains
translations: O son of Prtha! This is the Brahmanic state; having attained this, one never gets deluded again. Even by remaining in this [state] for a while, one attains at the time of death the Brahman, the Transcendent One.
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"Its form as such is not perceived by anyone here, like a dream or a mirage. The tree of Samsara is inherently deep-rooted and cannot be uprooted easily, even with a strong axe sharpened on the whetstone of discrimination. One must turn their mind towards the Supreme Being with a strong determination to attain eternal bliss in Him alone, and renounce all desires for sensual pleasure."

"The individual soul uses the mind along with each sense separately and enjoys or experiences the objects of the senses, such as sound? touch? form? taste and smell. It sits on the marvellous car of its mind? passes through the gateway of the ear in the twinkling of an eye and enjoys the various kinds of music of this world. text:

translations: ।।1.7।। हे द्विजोत्तम! हमारे पक्ष में भी जो मुख्य हैं, उनपर भी आप ध्यान दीजिये। आपको याद दिलाने के लिये मेरी सेना के जो नायक हैं, उनको मैं कहता हूँ।
commentaries:
Here is the translation of the given sentence entirely into English:

"The one who departs (15.10) stays (स्थितम्)? Is it 'or' (वा) or 'also' (अपि)? Do they enjoy (भुञ्जानम्)? Is it 'or' (विमूढाः) or do they not (न)? Can they see (पश्यन्ति) or behold (ज्ञानचक्षुषः) Him? Those who possess the inner eye of intuition can behold Him, but the ignorant and deluded cannot because their minds are swayed by the attributes of Nature and they identify the Self with the body."
